title: 2015 GMC Canyon
subTitle: What it felt like to get into one of the most important trucks of the 2015 model year.
promoTeaserSmall: What it felt like to get into one of the most important trucks of the 2015 model year.
promoTeaser: What it felt like to get into one of the most important trucks of the 2015 model year.
metaDescription: What it felt like to get into one of the most important trucks of the 2015 model year.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Driving this Canyon made me think of the importance of mobility to the women in my family. My mom had her own GMC pickup, which I made my husband buy from her at an outrageous price after she wrung the life from it. He remains grumpy long after it hit the scrap heap.

My dad’s mom had, at the turn of the century, her own horse and buggy on the farm in Nebraska. You can read his poignant essay here about how the car impacted her life.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/7oSlaI9wCqs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Vital Stats

Type: Mid-size pickup truck
Base price for 2WD model: 2015 GMC Canyon Extended Cab SL 2WD, $21,880 (includes destination charge)
Base price for 4WD model: 2015 GMC Canyon 4WD SLE Crew Short Box, $34,935 (includes destination charge)
Price as tested: $39,090 (includes destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 305 horsepower, with six-speed automatic transmission (base model has 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 200 horsepower, with six-speed manual transmission)

Safety features: Rearview camera, electronic stability control, traction control, six airbags; not yet rated for safety by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration or Insurance Institute for Highway Safety
Tech features: EZ Lift-and-Lower locking tailgate, OnStar 4G LTE wireless hotspot, Bose premium audio system ($500), eight-inch touchscreen with navigation and Intellilink ($495)

image.altText: Gmc Canyon Pickup Box With Factory Spray In Bedliner

pageElements.text:
Options on this model: All-Terrain package ($1,190) includes Z71 suspension, off-road hill descent control, all-terrain tires, heated seats, rear body-color bumper, and front passenger power lumbar support; off-road assist steps ($745); SLE Convenience package ($500), including remote vehicle start, automatic air conditioning; spray-on bedliner ($475), trailering equipment package ($250)
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway (with the uplevel 305-horsepower 3.6-liter V6 engine and six-speed automatic transmission); base model, 19/26 mpg with the standard 200-horsepower 2.5-liter inline four-cylinder engine and six-speed manual transmission).
Chief competitors: 2015 Toyota Tacoma ($21,650), 2015 Nissan Frontier ($23,560), 2015 Chevrolet Colorado ($20,995); all prices include destination charges

Key Points

• This 2015 Canyon is an all-new product. General Motors did not offer the Chevrolet Colorado or GMC Canyon siblings in 2013 or 2014. The trucks were last built in August 2012 as 2012 models.
• GM has said the Toyota Tacoma is the “only target” for the redesigned Colorado and Canyon.
• Notice that the Colorado, starting under $21,000, offers slightly better value, but the Canyon offers a near-luxury experience, especially with the high-end model.
• At the same time, it’s extremely capable, with a maximum payload of 1,620 pounds and a 7,000-pound trailering rating (on V-6 models with optional trailering package).
• Connectivity is a plus, with OnStar 4G LTE and standard built-in Wi-Fi hotspot (it’s on whenever the car is on).
• Nice touches like standard LED daytime running lights on all models, standard CornerStep rear bumper design. EZ Lift-and-Lower locking tailgate (for one-handed use) is standard on Canyon SLE and SLT models and optional on base models.
• Standard front bucket seats and a center console with floor-mounted shifter are supposed to ease transition for consumers who previously owned cars.
• The SLT can make luxury claims with its quiet cabin, excellent ride quality, standard heated front seats, remote vehicle starter system, and power front seats for both driver and passenger.

title: 2016 Toyota Avalon
subTitle: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.
promoTeaserSmall: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.
promoTeaser: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.
metaDescription: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway
Most interesting option: Qi wireless charging, part of Premium Audio package with Navigation and App Suite (standard on XLE Premium model)

There's much to admire in the refreshed 2016 Toyota Avalon, which made its debut at the Chicago Auto Show this week. Looking at it, we're reminded of the days when the Avalon was an underappreciated player in Toyota's popular passenger-car lineup. Not anymore.

The Avalon has shed its former image as a ride for retirees, starting with a major make-over in 2012 when it was re-engineered and restyled. As Toyota says, it was the first product to "meet Toyota President Akio Toyoda’s challenge to create cars that spark people’s emotions."

In fact, with that 2012 redesign, the made-in-the-U.S. Avalon was really the opening salvo of a product renaissance for Toyota. With it, the brand started its move away from the bland designs of past generations. It added sophisticated good looks, more driver gratification, and quicker response.

The combination of standout styling and improved agility propelled the Avalon to tops in the premium sedan class, racking up higher sales than competitors like the Chrysler 300, Hyundai Azera, and Kia Cadenza. And it’s not unfair to say that it outshines even its own corporate cousin, the Lexus ES350.

So, for 2016, Toyota is applying the “ain’t broke, don’t fix it” rule to a very modest refresh. The trim levels grow from four to five: XLE, XLE Plus, XLE Premium, Touring, and Limited. The 268-horsepower V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission are unchanged, as are EPA ratings of 21 mpg in the city, 31 mpg on the highway.

The Avalon Hybrid continues, with a combined 200 maximum horsepower from a 2.4-liter four-cylinder gasoline engine augmented by an electric motor. It's available in XLE Plus, XLE Premium, and Limited versions. EPA ratings are 40 mpg in the city, 39 mpg on the highway.

Toyota made only modest cosmetic changes to the 2016 Avalon, among them the addition of LED headlights to the Touring model. The front end sports a wider grille, new headlamps, and vertical turn signals. The fog lamps have disappeared, and Touring models have a slightly different front end treatment to go with the LED lights. The Touring also gets a dark gray finish; like the other Avalons, it has 18-inch wheels and tires.
New taillights and chrome bumper trim distinguish the 2016 rear end from the current Avalon.

While nothing changes under the hood, the chassis team has tweaked the suspension for smoother ride quality in most models. However, Touring models have been subtly stiffened, to keep sportier-minded drivers happy.
You'll be able to find the 2016 Avalon in the Toyota dealership this fall.

title: An Oscar-Worthy Volvo 240
subTitle: Reese Witherspoon is good as an endurance-hiking author, but the classic Volvo wagon is transcendent.
promoTeaserSmall: Reese Witherspoon is good as an endurance-hiking author, but the classic Volvo wagon is transcendent.
promoTeaser: Reese Witherspoon is good as an endurance-hiking author, but the classic Volvo wagon is transcendent.
metaDescription: Reese Witherspoon is good as an endurance-hiking author, but the classic Volvo wagon is transcendent.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: For her portrayal of author Cheryl Strayed in Wild, Reese Witherspoon earned an Academy Award nomination.

Cheryl solo-hikes the Pacific Crest Trail through most of California and all of Oregon in the hope of finding release from her torments. Chief among them is the premature death of her mother, Bobbi (Laura Dern), the free spirit who guided Cheryl and her brother through difficult circumstances.
Some scenes present the family car: a Volvo 245 wagon, perfectly cast for its role.
Flashbacks tell the story as Cheryl plods along under a heavy backpack, nicknamed Monster. Some scenes present the family car: a Volvo 245 wagon, perfectly cast for its role.

The real-life owner explains on Reddit that he had advertised the car for sale on Craigslist. A $500 offer would have sufficed, he wrote, but a movie scout made arrangements to use the car for a month, paying nearly $2,000. Recently, the car was once again going up for sale, with screenshots from the movie to be attached to the ad as “a fun selling point.”
In the United States, Volvo’s 240 models, introduced in 1974, have always been prized, especially as they became available in the used-car market.
Their reputation for safety was one draw, and for durability, another.

The 240 stayed in production until 1993. During those nineteen years, aerodynamic designs from Audi and Ford reshaped the automobile, yet the Volvo’s boxy styling spoke to people. How do kids draw cars? Three distinct sections—although even a child’s pencil might skid to a stop rather than make such goggling headlamps.

More than forty years since their debut, 240-series Volvos are still a regular sight on streets and highways. Individualists, nonconformists, former Deadheads, people trying to hide their wealth, and misfits with excellent automotive taste drive them. Many are dinged up (we mean the cars). Hipsters have started restoration jobs, though, and we think the final destination is the same garages with ratty, dropped-handlebar cafe racer motorcycles and Mercedes-Benz CLA sedans.

If the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awarded an Oscar for Best Vehicle in a Supporting Role, the Volvo wagon from Wild would unquestionably be a nominee, keeping company with great film cars like the Joads’ 1926 Hudson Super Six from The Grapes of Wrath and the Brass Era replicar in Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.
The common thread among them is transcendence.

title: 5 Car-Related Vacation Attractions
subTitle: As you plan for this year's family vacation, make room for one of these side trips.
promoTeaserSmall: As you plan for this year's family vacation, make room for one of these side trips.
promoTeaser: As you plan for this year's family vacation, make room for one of these side trips.
metaDescription: As you plan for this year's family vacation, make room for one of these side trips.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text:
1. An American racing institution up close and personal: Indianapolis Motor Speedway Tour and Museum

If your summer travels take you near Indiana this June or July, make sure to visit one of the most storied racetracks in the world. Take the ninety-minute grounds tour around the track, which has been hosting the classic 500-mile race since 1911. Begin your visit at the Hall of Fame Museum, a treasure house of Indy racers from inaugural victor the Marmon Wasp to A.J. Foyt’s four winning vehicles and beyond.
Another good reason to go there: Now through the end of November, there's a tribute to Dan Gurney, featuring a dozen cars he designed and/or drove.
Grounds tours depart from the museum, but not every day, so check ahead to make sure your visit coincides with an available tour date.

Once on the track, your bus driver will keep the speed reasonable, but expect to still feel a little thrill up on the nine-degree banked turns. Stops around the 2.5-mile track include Gasoline Alley, the Victory Podium, and the iconic brick-paved start/finish line. Admission is $30 for adults and $12 for kids aged six to fifteen, for both the museum and tour.

Due to upcoming track upgrades, tour dates are not yet available for August through December, so the best bet is to target the early summer for your pilgrimage to the racing Mecca.
Visitor Information

2. Go-Karting on a grand scale: “The Track” in Branson, Missouri

If your kids have always wanted to get behind the wheel, go-karting is the thrill they won’t get enough of. The whole family will find a multitude of driving experiences waiting for them at The Track’s four locations featuring fourteen different karting tracks, each with its own unique layout and character. Single-driver or passenger-equipped karts are available to careen around classic tracks like The Road Course track or take the fun up a story, or three or four, on the wooden LumberJack or Wild Woody.

As for adults? The Sprint Track isn’t the longest course, but it is banked and offers the fastest karts for maximum adult fun. On the other end of the spectrum, kids at least thirty-eight inches tall can pilot their own age-appropriate vehicles on the Kiddie-Kart track.

In between drives visitors can entertain themselves with arcade games, batting cages, laser tag, mini golf, and more, depending on track location. Prices per race range from $6.50 to $11.50, paid for with pre-purchased credits. Check out the website in advance for height requirements and age suitability of the various tracks and to buy a Go-Card online ahead of time to take advantage of discounts, including food and attraction credits.
Visitor Information

3. A unique peek into car design: Chevy Test Track at Disney’s Epcot in Florida

The Chevy Test Track experience, revamped in 2012, takes the Epcot philosophy of highlighting technology and puts it in your hands. Even the queue at the Chevy Test Track is stimulating: you inspect a deconstructed car of the future while waiting in line to design the vehicle you will be testing once the ride begins. First you customize the physical attributes of your car in the Chevrolet Design Center. Using a touchscreen interface, you can select the roof line, car length and width, wheels, and engine to customize every aspect of your unique virtual car. The possibilities are practically endless, which is why they give you a time limit to decide on your car’s Capability, Efficiency, Responsiveness, and Power that will soon be put to the test in the multi-passenger ride vehicle on the Sim Track.

Once buckled in, you cede control to the Sim Car as it puts your design through its paces. Slide over treacherous roads, feel the hills and dips, avoid a semi-truck, and finally end with an exhilarating acceleration on the outdoor 60-mph straight. After getting off the ride, visitors can check their car’s performance score, race their virtual vehicle, and investigate the latest models from Chevy in the showroom.
Visitor Information

4. Four-wheel sightseeing: Pink Jeep Tours and Off-Roading in Sedona, Arizona

Let the experienced guides at Pink Jeep Tours four-wheel the family around some of America’s most stunning desert landscapes on one of seven excursions. Choose to explore the red rock formations or archaeological sites on Pink’s open-air Jeep Wrangler tours for up to three hours, with prices that start at $52 for adults and $39 for kids twelve and under. If you are a believer that this scenic area is rich in "spiritual vortex" sites, there's a tour for that, complete with a knowledgeable interpretive guide. But the area is breathtaking enough to enjoy by Jeep even if you aren't.
Visitor Information

Perhaps you'd rather be the one driving off-road, rather than be a passenger, and who can blame you? You can rent a dune buggy from Sedona Off-Road Center. Maps and ice chests are provided for half- or full-day self-guided jaunts on the trails. The base price for a two-passenger trip, in a lightweight Tomcat off-roader, is $198 for four hours. A family-friendlier four-seat Tomcat starts at $249. Prices climb as you figure in tax, insurance, fees, and gasoline. Goggles and lots of water should come on board with you; Sedona's summer temperatures average the mid-90s.
Visitor Information

5. Animation Adventure: Cars Land at Disney’s California Adventure

Disney’s California Adventure, next door to Disneyland in Anaheim, has been gaining traction with theme park aficionados, partly because of the 2012 addition of Cars Land. Its feature attraction transports you into the autocentric animated world of Cars on the Radiator Springs Racers ride. Convertibles speed alongside one another on this trek through the fictional Radiator Springs desert both day and night, indoors and out.

The scenario is complete with body shop and lets the whole family encounter favorite characters from the movie, including Lightning McQueen, Mater, and Doc Hudson. There's even a mountain range shaped like classic Cadillac tailfins. Flo’s V8 Café is modeled after the kind of 1950s drive-in you might have found on Route 66. Luigi’s Flying Tires is closed for a refresh this summer, but there’s still plenty of cartoon car atmosphere to enjoy.
Visitor Information

pageElements.text:
2015 Chevrolet Trax LTZ AWD

Base price: $20,995 (LS, including destination charge)
This car: $27,405 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/31 mpg highway (all-wheel-drive model); 26/34 mpg (front-wheel-drive model)

My favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Cruise control (standard on LT and LTZ, not available on LS), heated seats (on LTZ only)
Notable standard features on this model: Remote start, rear park assist, OnStar with 4G LTE wireless hot spot, heated front seats
You might also be considering: Honda CR-V ($24,325); Jeep Renegade ($18,990); Mazda CX-5 ($22,425) (all prices include destination charge)

When you head out to the dealership to test drive new cars, it’s critical to drive only the level of car you can afford. Take the 2015 Chevrolet Trax, for instance. My tendency would be to go straight for the awesome Orange Rock Metallic Trax LTZ on the lot without noticing that it was the highest of the three trim levels and, at $26,530, almost five grand more than the base Trax LS ($20,995).

I would then find out that all the coolest features included in the LTZ model—Bose audio, power seats, remote start (a must-have), rear park assist, that flamboyantly awesome orange paint, and cruise control—are not even available as options on the base car. And then I would have to steel myself and pay the extra dollars. Because I at least need cruise control.
I found this out during my three-day test drive.

If you’re fond of slamming on the accelerator when you want to giddy-up (as I clearly am), be ready for the tortured roar of the 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine followed by a slow trot as acceleration climbs, until the turbo kicks in and things smooth out. With only 138 horsepower on tap, the Ecotec four-cylinder engine would prefer you feed in your request for power with a lighter foot, thank you. It will climb well past the speed limit, but each time you sneeze—unless you set the cruise control—you’ll find yourself going ten miles an hour slower.

Did I mention you can’t get cruise control on the Trax LS? Right. In fact, its minuscule options list offers not much beyond a handful of cargo area upgrades. I would get the heavy-duty cargo tray ($110). A notable exception is all-wheel drive, a $1,500 option on any of the three models and well worth every dollar.
Chevy clearly wants you to step up to the LS or LTZ. Do that, and the glittering array of standard luxuries and desirable options will be revealed.

Buzzing down the Interstate, the Trax feels much less prone to a crosswind than you might imagine of a vehicle that is basically square; it undoubtedly prefers being your city car. That useful square also delivers less fuel economy (24 mpg city/31 mpg highway for the all-wheel-drive model; the standard front-wheel-drive model gets 26/34 mpg) than you might expect these days. But it offsets that disappointment with a sterling 2015 five-star overall safety rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (a.k.a. the Government). The Trax also received a coveted 2015 Top Safety Pick rating from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

I actually like its funky shape and exceptionally well-screwed-together interior. Even in cloth trim, the Trax’s fit and finish are impeccable. Bezels surrounding air vents, cubbies, and the six-speed automatic shift lever (manual function button is on the shift knob) are plastic with galvano chrome, chrome, or liquid platinum finish. They look for all the world like metal, and are perfectly fitted in place. The instrument cluster is a clean, easy-to-read, yet cheerful array of bold colors, and the MyLink touchscreen works well if you take those gloves off, sir. The front passenger’s seat on all Trax models folds flat, allowing the already useful cargo area to swallow up longer items.

There is one major league feature that even the smallest and most Spartan of Chevrolets delivers on a silver platter: an AT&T 4G LTE wireless hot spot that will handle seven Bluetooth devices when the car is on.
I actually like that even better than cruise control.

images.caption: The view from inside: 2015 Chevrolet Trax.

title: 2015 Honda CR-V
subTitle: The eminently practical crossover gets a continuously variable transmission for 2015.
promoTeaserSmall: The eminently practical crossover gets a continuously variable transmission for 2015.
promoTeaser: The eminently practical crossover gets a continuously variable transmission for 2015.
metaDescription: The eminently practical crossover gets a continuously variable transmission for 2015.

pageElements.text: The Honda CR-V is a five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle, but it’s more appropriate to call it a crossover vehicle. It’s today’s version of the family station wagon, facing off against numerous others in a very competitive category that includes the Toyota RAV4, Ford Escape, Mazda CX-5, Chevrolet Trax, Buick Encore, and Hyundai Santa Fe Sport. Last year, the CR-V was the sales winner. If you’re interested in this category, you are probably looking for safety features, ground clearance, visibility, and the possibility of all-wheel drive. These are not exciting vehicles; they’re eminently practical, though. The CR-V is powered by a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine making 185 horsepower, teamed with a continuously variable automatic transmission. It’s priced starting in the low $20,000s, although the top model, with navigation and all-wheel drive, costs above $30,000.

New for 2015:

Continuously variable automatic transmission
Standard multi-angle rearview camera on all models

Competition:

Buick Encore
Chevrolet Trax
Ford Escape
Hyundai Santa Fe Sport
Toyota RAV4

Trim Levels (all prices include destination charge):

LX $24,325 (front-wheel drive), $25,575 (all-wheel drive)
EX $26,425 (FWD), $27,675 (AWD)
EX-L $29,025 (FWD), $31,775 (AWD)
Touring $31,645 (FWD), $32,895 (AWD)

Notable Features:

LED daytime running lights
Heated front seats (EX, EX-L, and Touring)
Power tailgate (Touring model only)

Cool Tech:

Seven-inch touchscreen with Honda satellite-linked navigation and HD digital traffic (optional on EX-L, standard on Touring)

Looks:

Tilting power moonroof (EX, EX-L, and Touring)
Leather-trimmed seats (EX-L and Touring)

Safety:

Top Safety Pick + from Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (when equipped with optional front crash prevention system)
Honda Sensing safety/driver assist technology (on Touring model) includes collision-mitigation braking, forward collision warning, lane-keeping assist, lane departure warning, adaptive cruise control

More to Read:

Jean's Driveway: 2015 Honda CR-V AWD Touring February 9, 2015
2015 Honda CR-V AWD Should you buy it? May 5, 2015

title: 2015 Hyundai Sonata Sport 2.0T
subTitle: A great car from one of the great unsung brands. I proved it on a drive from Michigan to Louisiana.
promoTeaserSmall: A great car from one of the great unsung brands. I proved it on a drive from Michigan to Louisiana.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Hyundai Sonata Sport 2.0T

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Base price: $23,985 (base Sonata Sport, including destination charge)
This car: $29,510 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 245 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/32 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Hands-free smart trunk
Options I can’t live without: Heated front seats (standard on Sport 2.0T)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, lane change assist, blind spot detection, rear cross-traffic alert
Notable options on this model: None
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion ($22,835), Honda Accord ($22,925), Toyota Camry ($24,460) (prices include destination charge)
If you’re still someone who hears the word “Hyundai” and thinks “cheap car,” you will be blown away by the 2015 Sonata, one of Hyundai’s most important vehicles.

Yes, it’s a reliable ride at a reasonable price. But if you’re looking for a gorgeous and lavishly appointed family sedan, state-of-the-art safety technology (forward collision, lane departure, blind spot, and cross-traffic warnings), a choice of two great four-cylinder engines, a flawless six-speed automatic transmission, and a reasonable price, the 2015 Sonata ought to be front and center on your shopping list.

Hyundai Motor America colonized the United States in 1985, sending its first car—the 1986 Excel—forth to prosper. It helped that it had a rock-bottom price, because it was a tad, shall we say, crappy.

The Sonata came in late 1988, designed by Ital Design in Turin, Italy, and built on a Mitsubishi Galant platform, a clever strategy by the fledgling Korean carmaker to play catch-up with the Japanese invasion. Do not be fooled. Hyundai’s price strategy kept the company in business while design and engineering raced furiously forward.

Twenty–seven years later, now in its seventh generation, the Sonata has been one of the brightest lights in a growing brand, first setting a record with more than 200,000 Sonatas sold in North America in 2010, and winning awards from major enthusiast magazines, consumer websites, and safety agencies along the way.

The Sonata played a role in helping Hyundai supplant all of its competition on the 2014 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study, ranking an impressive fourth behind Porsche (#1), Jaguar (#2), and Lexus (#3). Perhaps most satisfying: Hyundai ranks ahead of Toyota (#5), Honda (#8), and Ford (#16).

I took a 2015 Hyundai Sonata for a test drive, which just happened to be a round-trip from Michigan to Louisiana and back. My first concern was, would there be enough room for the luggage, the presents, the hunting gear, the fishing gear, and the variety of outerwear to cover every possible weather condition? What about the cooler full of pheasants to be swapped out with all the fish I was planning to catch? And a second cooler big enough to hold the wild boar my husband planned on bagging?

No problem whatsoever, other than that there would be no wild boar. There was, however, a cooler packed with ice and speckled trout. Ahem. Not only does the Sonata have best-in-class interior volume, it has a deep, wide trunk with a tall, wide opening. You’d be surprised by how many cars I’ve tested with a trunk opening too narrow to take a biggish piece of luggage.

I knew the Sonata would be fun—even in the more mountainous sections of our 2,100-mile round-trip drive—because we had the Sport 2.0T model. It’s the most fun-minded of the Sonata’s five trim levels, thanks to an impressive 2.0-liter four-cylinder turbo engine and a six-speed automatic transmission so competent that we never noticed it.
The standard features list includes my three safety must-haves: blind spot detection, cross-traffic alert, and a rearview camera. All three have saved my bacon out there.

Rather than digging us all into a hole trying to explain the multiple sub-levels of equipment packages available among the five trims (SE, Sport, Limited, Sport 2.0T, and Eco), I just won’t go there. Instead I’ll use my brilliant orange (“Urban Sunset”) 2.0T as an example. The base price is $29,385. There is exactly one item on the options list: a carpeted floor mat for $125. The impressive list of standard features includes my big three safety must-haves: blind spot detection, cross-traffic alert, and a rearview camera. All three have saved my bacon out there.

More standard delights are the hands-free trunk opener that reads the key fob in your pocket, heated front seats, and lots of leather. You can spring for the $4,950 Ultimate package if you need a panoramic sunroof and heated seats for your back-seat guests. The package also contains about fifteen other technology wonders.

Back to where we began. The Sonata has been one of the pillars of Hyundai’s U.S. success, and the 2015 model has reached new heights of engineering excellence. It’s also just flat out beautiful, one of the most important determining factors in the hotly contested family sedan class.  As one of the great unsung brands, Hyundai deserves its due.

images.caption: Rearview camera is standard on the 2015 Hyundai Sonata Sport 2.0T.
18-inch split-spoke alloy wheels on the 2015 Hyundai Sonata Sport 2.0T.

title: 1963 Studebaker Avanti
subTitle: A modern-day look back at the modernist classic.
promoTeaserSmall: A modern-day look back at the modernist classic.
promoTeaser: A modern-day look back at the modernist classic.
metaDescription: A modern-day look back at the modernist classic.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: “Love these.”
“One of the coolest cars ever, and way ahead of its time.”
“The most beautiful car ever.”
The Studebaker Avanti drew such comments on Facebook when I posted this photo from the Palm Springs Modernism Week car show.

You’d think Studebaker Corporation, which introduced the Avanti in 1963, would have won big with its sporty coupe. The independent automaker’s first all‐new body style in ten years solved an image problem.
I was eight years old when the Avanti came out and I found Studebakers no more appealing than my grandmother’s orthopedic shoes.

But Studebaker’s answer to the Chevrolet Corvette Sting Ray was definitely ahead of its time. Given the overwrought automotive shapes we were accustomed to in those days, it was actually a bit hard for some of us to understand.

The Avanti made a daringly distinct Modernist design statement. Strong lines bounded the surface volumes, yet within the overall simplicity there was voluptuousness. The extended front fenders created a kind of cove, and without a radiator grille, the headlamps’ roundness was exaggerated. (Fresh air was taken in below.)
Above all, ornamentation was limited.

Also read: My Father's Avanti Test Drive, by Jean Jennings

February 26, 2015

Inside, the spareness echoes that found inside custom homes in Palm Springs. In fact, for the design, Studebaker had turned to Raymond Loewy, from whose drawing board had sprung Coke bottles, locomotives, the Coldspot refrigerator, and the Lucky Strike cigarette package. Loewy’s Palm Springs house—the work of architect Albert Frey, a disciple of Le Corbusier—featured a swimming pool that flowed into the living room.

With a fiberglass body, the Avanti was relatively cheap to produce. A supercharged V-8 engine and Flightomatic automatic transmission were available to ensure lively performance. The supercharged 1963 example seen here belongs to our friend Bob Merlis.
The base price in 1963 was $4,445, and some 3,834 copies were produced. Sales dwindled to just 809 units the next year.

And then Studebaker, which had a long history in South Bend, Indiana, closed its factory there. Studebaker's Avanti line was discontinued after the company’s production was concentrated in Hamilton, Ontario. By 1966, Studebaker was finished.
An independent effort was responsible for production of a few Avanti II models into the mid-1970s, and the brand continued in various incarnations, under various owners, into the late 1980s.
Much rarer than it should have been, the Avanti still surprises and pleases after more than fifty years.
Photos by Ronald Ahrens

Strong lines 
bounded the surface volumes, yet within the overall simplicity there was 
voluptuousness.

pageElements.text: There isn’t a chance that I’ll ever forget the Studebaker Avanti, one of the first test cars that my automotive journalist father, Bob Lienert, brought home from his city job at Automotive News to our little country house stuffed with kids. Up to the point of writing this sentence, I thought that that lemon yellow Avanti was the first one ever made. Actually, I thought every test car my dad brought home was not only the first one ever made, but also the only one of its kind ever made. That may also have been true of the copper-colored Chrysler turbine car and a big red Mercury with little hand grips and thumb holes instead of a steering wheel, that he also brought home.
But those are stories for another day.

This lemon yellow Avanti may have been one of those first ten off the line in 1962, or a later version built in 1963, but even my Cray supercomputer-brained brother, Paul, doesn’t remember. He does remember that it was equipped with a Paxton supercharger, which made it insanely fast.
This is what we remember.

Our dad was the only driver in the family until our mom threatened to leave him if he didn’t teach her how to drive. Every night after dinner, he would drive over to Kret’s Garage and hang with the guys, or to Grandma’s to play cards and drink a little blackberry brandy. On special occasions, he’d drop all of us at the library.

On Saturdays he would go to the bank and then mail the bills at the post office.
On Sundays, he would drive us all to church, and sometimes for a ride in the countryside.
Rinse. Repeat.
Except the night he brought home the Avanti.

It looked like a spaceship that had landed from Mars. He must have been as excited as we were about it, because he asked us kids if we wanted a ride. There were two babies in the house, so that meant my older brother Paul, my younger brother Teddy, and me. I was seven.
We piled in. It felt really low to the ground compared to the family station wagon. I don’t remember if it had those orange seats, but that would have added major excitement to the experience.
Someone called shotgun, and I’m sure it was Paul. Teddy and I would have been in the back.
My dad turned left and shot down a smoother, wider dirt road and really let himself have at it, much to our thrill.

We lived on a rutty dirt road that ended at a stop sign facing the Catholic cemetery. Dad left the driveway and headed north, gathering a head of steam as he barreled up the hill to the stop. He turned left and shot down a smoother, wider dirt road and really let himself have at it, much to our thrill.

I think he may have been surprised by a tee junction coming up suddenly over a blind crest. He threw the wheel to the left, and the Avanti’s rear end slewed across the slippery graveled road surface. He spun the wheel hard right, but the entire car car slid off the road and into the ditch. He never lifted and somehow managed to drive it right out of the ditch and onto the road. And he kept going, even though Teddy and I were screaming in the back seat, “Daddy! Daddy! Stop! You’re going to kill us!”
But he went only far enough to make a slow U-turn and drive straight home.
“Don’t tell your mother,” he said. I don’t remember any other test rides after that.
Photo: 1963 Studebaker Avanti, courtesy of CZmarlin/Christopher Ziemnowicz

images.caption: My father drove an Avanti at 130   mph on the Bonneville Salt Flats in 1963.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL350
subTitle: Luxury for seven, plus a full slate of safety technology. Worth the money? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Luxury for seven, plus a full slate of safety technology. Worth the money? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Luxury for seven, plus a full slate of safety technology. Worth the money? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: Luxury for seven, plus a full slate of safety technology. Worth the money? Here's what we think.

pageElements.text:
2015 Mercedes-Benz GL350 BlueTec 4Matic

Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Base price: $64,525 (including destination charge)
This car: $86,825 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Attention Assist
Options I can’t live without: Driver Assistance package ($2,800): includes pre-safe braking, active blind spot assist, active lane keeping assist
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, collision prevention assist, LED daytime running lights, power liftgate, rain-sensing wipers, heated front seats with driver lumbar support
Notable options on this model: Ventilated front seats ($570), Appearance package ($1,200): includes 20-inch wheels and illuminated running boards; Parking Assist package ($1,290): includes active parking assist and surround-view camera; heated and cooled front cup holders (part of Premium package, $4,410)
You might also be considering: Audi Q7 ($48,625), Cadillac Escalade AWD ($77,560), Infiniti QX80 AWD ($67,345), Lexus LX570 ($84,105) (all prices include destination charges)

Would you live any differently if you suddenly doubled your income? That's a question that I'd like to ask a lot of people currently driving minivans or midrange crossover vehicles. Would they, given a lot less concern about money, spend more than $80,000 to carry the family around in one of these?

Take your time on that answer; the automakers aren't necessarily waiting for you to get rich anyway. There are already plenty of car shoppers (and you may already be one) who feel OK about that price tag. The luxury full-size SUV category is increasingly packed with more or less ostentatious, more or less boxy vehicles with lists of technology and features that approach the ridiculous.

In the category of seven- or eight-passenger vehicles at the high end, the Mercedes-Benz GL-Class occupies a place of high esteem and sales, and rightly so. One look at the attractively boxy exterior tells you that you can drive this SUV without feeling like the Ugly American. You can rationalize the purchase as a practical choice, too. It can haul your boat, swallow up every member of the family, and offer an outstanding level of safety, driver assist, and comfort technology.

The Mercedes-Benz GL-Class is the full-size SUV in the Mercedes family. The one we tried is the 240-horsepower turbo-diesel-powered GL350 with Mercedes' BlueTec "clean diesel" technology. It's teamed with 4Matic, or full-time all-wheel drive, plus a seven-speed automatic transmission with shift paddles.

There are three other GL-Class versions: the GL450, with a twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6 making 362 horsepower; the GL550, with a twin-turbocharged 4.7-liter V-8 making 429 horsepower; and Mercedes' AMG sport division's GL63 AMG, starting at nearly $120,000, which has a twin-turbo 5.5-liter V-8 handcrafted by AMG to make 550 horsepower. If we were completely unaware of these other choices, we'd still think the GL350's turbo-diesel had enough power for virtually anything we'd want to do in this size and shape of vehicle. It feels refined, powerful, and competent without a hint of truckiness. The ride is surprisingly smooth for the size, and it has the commanding view of the road that SUV buyers go for.

The three-pointed star, LED daytime running lamps, and overall exterior appearance are nice selling points, but the technology is what excites me about this SUV. I'm a fan of the seemingly endless list of ponderously named active and passive safety features. Attention Assist is the famous "cup of coffee" that lights up to tell you to take a break if you're tired. There's a rearview camera, attention and collision prevention assist technology, and Pre-Safe, which can tell if you're about to crash and will adjust seatbelts, headrests, windows, and sunroof to brace for impact. All of that is standard.

The car we tested had the optional Premium package, which adds some of the coolest technology and, if you're already spending this kind of money, is highly recommended at $4,410, along with a Parking Assist package ($1,290) and a Driver Assistance package ($2,800). With those, you get Parktronic park assist with a surround-view camera, active blind spot and lane keeping assistance, and more. Not only are you and all other occupants of the GL350 riding in comfort and luxury, but with protection, information, and driving assistance that was undreamed-of a decade ago. That's what I call a good family car.

But let's move straight from the sublime to the nearly ridiculous. On the list of stuff I never knew I needed is the set of heated/cooled front cup holders. On the list of things that just feel silly are the chrome hood fins (Accessory Chrome package, $225) and the illuminated running boards (Appearance package, which also adds 20-inch wheels, $1,200). I know some people will like those items, all options; they just weren't my cup of tea, cooled or otherwise.

No, what I think makes this SUV worth buying is the safety technology. Tied for a close second come the high level of comfort (three-zone climate control, a $1,450 option), and the flexibility. I was sold when I checked out the quick power-folding third row of seats. I was definitely excited about loading up the cavernous back end with boxes. My brother-in-law owns a GL350, and he calls the back cargo area "outstanding" and strongly recommends getting a rubber liner for the back, so tempting is it to cart around flowers and wood chips in the spring, or furniture when you move.
I'm a fan of the seemingly endless list of ponderously named safety features, starting with the famous Attention Assist and its coffee-cup icon.

The Verdict:

You'll only be looking at a vehicle this size if you are already prepared to drive around town in something big. You might also be looking at crossovers with a lower profile, though. My brother-in-law chose a GL-Class over an Audi Q7 for the opposite reason; he liked the bigger, more open, more SUV-like appearance of the Mercedes over the rounded edges of the Q7. And he doesn't even have a bunch of people to carry. Whether the aesthetics of this one are for you or not, there is much to recommend it from safety technology to creature comforts. The fuel economy of this turbo-diesel-powered GL350, at 26 mpg on the highway, is quite reasonable considering how much it carries. All that, and Attention Assist to remind you that an occasional coffee break makes the drive even more enjoyable, and if you've got the wherewithal, this might be your next family-car contender.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The GL350 BlueTec 4Matic was awaiting my return from a particularly sad trip, to Florida for my father's funeral. It gave me a little happiness to know that there was a luxury SUV in my driveway in snowy Michigan. It did not disappoint. The heated seats with massage eased me back into the reality of sub-zero temperatures. I slipped my hot cocoa into the cup holder and turned on the heat option. I dreamed of driving the GL in Florida, where I would opt to cool the seats and drinks with a flip of a switch. I did have a slight snafu when the car could not locate the key even though it was sitting on the console. The dash guided me to pull out the start/stop button and slip the key into the ignition. Success. I also was enamored with the rearview camera that displayed a bird's-eye view of the vehicle.

As I readjust to life this week, I find my mind wandering, but the GL made sure that I did not go astray on the road as it alerted me on any lane departure. Since, we are all a little distracted in our twenty-first-century lives, I say if you can afford the GL and need to haul people or things, make the purchase.

title: Bentley EXP 10 Speed 6 Concept
subTitle: Love at first sight.
promoTeaserSmall: Love at first sight.
promoTeaser: Love at first sight.
metaDescription: Love at first sight from Bentley.

pageElements.text: Bentley’s recent history is awash with ultra-posh dreadnoughts capable of nosebleed acceleration, despite curb weights in the Cadillac Escalade category.
Yet, for all their power and prestige, none of the Bentleys that have emerged since the company’s acquisition by Volkswagen Group in 1998 could be called a sports car.
Judging by this stunning car that made its debut this week at the Geneva Auto Show, that abstinence may soon come to an end.

Specifics concerning hardware were not part of the presentation. We’d guess the production version, should it get the green light, will be based on architecture from Bentley’s Continental series, since it’s lighter than that employed for the bigger Mulsanne sedans. Bentley has plenty of V-8 and W-12 power in its warehouse, but the press material refers to “the hybrid potential of this concept’s advanced powertrain.”

And then there’s the Speed Six reference, conjuring up this company’s glory days at the Le Mans 24 Hours, with legendary drivers Woolf Barnato, Tim Birkin, and others, when Bentley won four straight: 1927, ’28, ’29, and ’30. However, there’s no six-cylinder engine in the current Bentley inventory, so who knows.
In any case, the EXP wows on styling alone. Bentley’s advanced design chief, Sang Yup Lee, has a simple litmus test for a car: “Unless you fall in love with it at first sight, the car is a failure.”
Looks like love to us. Somewhere Woolf Barnato is smiling.

More to Read:

Inside the Bentley Factory, by Jean Jennings
I went to Bentley’s historic headquarters in Crewe, England, for the first time in my long career as an automotive journalist. I wasn't there to test cars (except for a few exceptional backseats behind a chauffeur). Instead, I was welcome where few have been invited—the back rooms where....

title: 5 Ways to Make Your Car Spring Forward
subTitle: Your car is a hot mess; admit it. Here are some ways to fix that.
promoTitle: 5 Ways to Make Your Car Spring Forward
promoTeaserSmall: Your car is a hot mess; admit it. Here are some ways to fix that.
promoTeaser: Your car is a hot mess; admit it. Here are some ways to fix that.
keywords: 5 Ways to Make Your Car Spring Forward
metaTitle: 5 Ways to Make Your Car Spring Forward - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Your car is a hot mess; admit it. Here are some ways to fix that.

pageElements.text: There’s nothing as wonderful as a bright spring morning, alive with the promise of melted snow and budding trees. Even in the warmest parts of the country, March brings with it the certitude that summer, and vacations, and vacation trips are not far away.
Your car is a hot mess, isn’t it?
That’s probably a bit how you feel after the long season of cold and darkness. With that in mind, here are five things you can do right now to help it spring forward.

1. Change the wiper blades.

If you live where there’s a lot of snow and ice, the blades have had a brutal winter. Even if you don’t live where there’s ice and salt ripping up the rubber, you probably haven’t gotten around to this in a while. It’ll change your view of the world.

2. Ditch the junk in your trunk.

Some people think it’s a jinx to take shovels and ice scrapers out of the trunk too soon. Be an optimist and remove kitty litter, gloves, boots, and whatever other winter things you have in your car. Leave in jumper cables, work gloves, tire iron, flares, and emergency triangle. Keep them corralled in a duffel or box. And leave in the emergency granola bars unless you’ve already eaten them at the first long traffic light.

3. Clean and vacuum.

Neat trick A: Wet down the removable floor mats with warm water, then wet-vac them, to get the maximum amount of road salt and grime off. Neat trick B: When vacuuming out the interior, use a stiff-bristled paintbrush to clear dirt out of the cracks and crevices. (I know, Martha Stewart-y, right?)

4. Get the insides of your windows clean.

REALLY clean. This is the most important improvement you can make to your quality of life inside the car. When I drove a cab, I kept automotive glass cleaner and a roll of paper towels in the trunk. Avoid using household glass cleaners with ammonia, which can interact badly with tinted car windows.

5. Don’t forget your tires, the only contact your car has with the earth.

Tire pressure is battered when temps soar from negative numbers to the balmy climates of spring. You can improve your gas mileage by up to three percent with properly inflated tires. Check yours monthly, and obviously change from winter to summer tires if you’ve put snow tires on your car. Spring, like fall, is a good time to find sales on new tires.

title: Are Cooling Seats Any Good?
subTitle: We check out a variety of ventilated seats to see if they're a worthwhile way to chill in the car.
promoTeaserSmall: We check out a variety of ventilated seats to see if they're a worthwhile way to chill in the car.
promoTeaser: We check out a variety of ventilated seats to see if they're a worthwhile way to chill in the car.
metaTitle: Are Cooling Seats Any Good? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: We check out a variety of ventilated seats to see if they're a worthwhile way to chill in the car.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: At home, you fight over the remote. In the car, the latest battleground is the thermostat. Heated seats and steering wheels are becoming common options, but the latest frontier is cooling.

This is not the best time of year to think about ventilation in our cars' seating, but summer is coming. The JKC staff has checked out ventilated seats in a range of vehicles recently, from the pricey 2015 Porsche Macan Turbo to the lean, mean, green 2015 Kia Soul EV. Those two choices prove that, once an unusual item, cooled seating is becoming more available. The cooling feature was priced as a $660 stand-alone option on the Macan (the one we tested costs a total of $97,065). It was included in the $4,420 Reserve Equipment option group on the Lincoln MKZ, which starts at $36,085; and it was on board as standard on the 2015 Kia Soul EV ($36,625 as tested).
If you’re in a temperate climate and don’t drive a lot, you may not see the benefit of this seat technology. But drivers who battle long commutes in sweltering heat will.

How do they work? you ask. With fans, in some cases: fans built into the seat to circulate cabin air. With this option, you may be able to control the fan level, but not the temperature of the air that comes out of the seat perforations. Cooled seats such as those found in the Lincoln MKZ (shown here) and Kia Optima use a thermal engine that is separate from the vehicle’s climate control system to cool the air first, then circulate it through the seatback and cushion.

If you’re in a temperate climate and don’t drive a lot, you may not see the benefit of this seat technology. But drivers who battle long commutes in sweltering heat will. They'll appreciate the cool air on their back and how it alleviates the problem of wrinkled shirts that stick to your skin like papier-mâché. And it can also be considered a safety feature.

On a 900-mile round trip in early March, JKC's Molly Jean regularly swapped temperature choices, utilizing to the full the massaging seats ("I don't want to get bedsores," she rationalized) and varying between heating or cooling the seats on a 2015 Range Rover Supercharged LWB she was driving. "You can have the heat on your feet and the cool on your rear end," she said. "Having the choice is what comfort is all about."
In other words, a relaxed driver is a more attentive driver and therefore a safer driver. That assurance alone should help sell ventilated seats to more customers in the future.

title: 2015 Audi A4
promoTeaserSmall: Designed to drive.
promoTeaser: Designed to drive.

metaDescription: Designed to drive. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Audi A4/S4

Type: Front- or all-wheel-drive compact sport sedan
Price range: $36,425–$49,325 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Premium, Premium Plus, Prestige
Engines: A4: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 220 horsepower
S4: Supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 333 horsepower
Transmissions: A4: Eight-speed automatic, six-speed manual, continuously variable automati
S4: Seven-speed automatic, six-speed manual
Fuel economy: A4, automatic: 22 mpg city/31 mpg highway; A4, manual: 22/32 mpg; A4, continuously variable: 24/32 mpg; S4, automatic: 18/28 mpg; S4, manual: 17/26 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Three-zone climate control in all A4s
Notable standard features on this model: LED daytime running lights and taillights
Notable options on this model: S line competition package, available on Premium Plus and Prestige trims, gives the A4 sharp black accents inside and out as well as a distinctive leather/Alcantara interior
You might also be considering: BMW 3 Series, Cadillac ATS, Infiniti Q50

Not a lot has changed this year for Audi’s A4 sedan, and that’s a good thing. It is still luxurious inside, handsome on the outside, and a capable performer on the road. If you're looking for a bit more excitement, Audi offers the S4 version, with all-wheel drive, a supercharged V-6, and your choice of either a seven-speed automatic or a six-speed manual transmission. The base A4 comes very well equipped but techno- and audiophiles will want to opt for the MMI Navigation Plus package with voice control and the Bang & Olufsen sound system. Advanced safety options are also available including Audi’s Side Assist that monitors blind spots and can detect fast-approaching vehicles.

There’s quite a span of A4’s to be had between the Premium and the S4 Prestige trims along with three transmission choices. The handling poise and classic styling of the A4 and S4 stack up nicely against the competition. Interiors in both feel airier than those of the BMW 3-series or the Cadillac ATS although the rear seat is a bit cozier than in those models and the 12.4-cubic-foot trunk is on the small side. For the exterior check out the new metallic paint options like Florett Silver, Mythos Black, and Utopia Blue to liven up your driveway. The A4 is luxurious, while the S4 is the higher-performance choice.

New for 2015

Three-zone climate control and the S line style package are now standard on all A4s.

title: 2015 Buick Verano
subTitle: Deserves a shout out.
promoTeaserSmall: Deserves a shout out.
promoTeaser: Deserves a shout out.
metaDescription: Deserves a shout out. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Price: $24,305 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Verano, Verano Turbo
Engines: Verano: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower; Verano Turbo: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 250 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Verano: 21 mpg city/32 mpg highway; Verano Turbo: 21/30 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Experience Buick Protection includes two years/24,000 miles of schedule maintenance (oil and filter changes, tire rotation)
Notable standard features on this model: Dual-zone automatic climate control, rearview camera, connectivity for up to 10 devices, text-to-voice
Notable options on this model: Heated seats, heated leather-wrapped steering wheel, blind spot and rear cross-traffic alerts, rear park assist
You might also be considering: Acura ILX, Audi A3, Lexus IS250

Buick claims the Verano is the quietest of all compact sedans. If what you’re seeking is refuge, this is it. The Verano comes with small luxuries like a dual-zone climate system, and the infotainment and connectivity are impressive. But the car has also spent some time at the gym. The standard 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine produces 180 horsepower, and with the optional turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder that makes 250 horsepower, you can specify a six-speed manual transmission. There are just enough of us out there who find this sporty choice appealing. Otherwise, the big story on the Verano is about its connectivity with the standard IntelliLink system and OnStar with 4G LTE. It’s hard to overtax this brain: imagine a five-passenger car being able to support ten connected devices. Text messaging will read incoming texts through the speakers. And no need to hold up your iPhone, because connectivity is voice controlled through Siri Eyes Free. On top of all this is OnStar, which is faster and more comprehensive than ever. With such a level of performance, specification, features, and attractive if conventional design, it’s hard to understand why the Verano keeps so quiet among compact sedans.

New for 2015

OnStar with 4G LTE and Wi-Fi hot spot, new dark sapphire blue metallic color, available appearance package for non-turbo Verano with bright chrome grille

More about the Buick Verano

2013 Buick Verano with video November 5, 2012

title: 2015 Toyota Avalon
subTitle: Dependable vanilla luxury.
promoTeaserSmall: Dependable vanilla luxury.
promoTeaser: Dependable vanilla luxury.
metaDescription: Dependable vanilla luxury. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Price range: $33,110—$42,525 (includes destination)
Trim levels: XLE, XLE Premium, Hybrid XLE Premium, XLE Touring, Hybrid XLE Touring, XLE Touring Sport Edition, Limited, Hybrid Limited
Engines: 2.5-liter four-cylinder/electric hybrid, 200 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 3.5-liter: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway; 2.5-liter hybrid: 40/39 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters for all non-hybrid models
Notable standard features on this model: Ten air bags
Notable options on this model: A pre-collision system that preps the seatbelts and brakes for optimal performance in a crash
You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Chevrolet Impala, Kia Cadenza

Now in its fourth generation, the Avalon continues to straddle the line between a mid-size and a full-size car. Although it has sporting aspirations, the Avalon is a tourer that excels at carrying its occupants in serene comfort. The remarkably spacious cabin is whisper quiet even at highway speeds and is traditionally styled. It comes standard with all the expected amenities including heated front seats, a rearview camera, and a multimedia system with a 6.1-inch touchscreen display, Bluetooth music streaming, and satellite radio. The XLE Touring trim adds the Entune Premium Audio system with navigation and a seven-inch touchscreen to access apps, check traffic and weather, and even pause a broadcast for later listening. Exclusive ambient interior lighting, aluminum scuff plates, and heated rear seats dress up the cabin of the top Limited model. There is also a full suite of safety and driver assistance systems available, the most interesting being a so-called Smart Stop system that overrides unintended acceleration. Toyota added a hybrid to the Avalon lineup in 2013 that achieves an impressive 40 mpg in city driving. The Avalon’s styling won’t set the neighborhood abuzz, but you’ll know you have a keeper every time you cross town or cross country in quiet comfort.

New for 2015

The XLE Touring Sport Edition gets painted black wheels, Attitude Black exterior paint, and a black leather interior with blue dash accents.

title: 2015 Toyota Prius
subTitle: The pioneer of the category is still going strong.
promoTeaserSmall: The pioneer of the category is still going strong.
promoTeaser: The pioneer of the category is still going strong.
metaKeywords: 2015 Toyota Prius; Prius c; Prius v; Prius plug-in; Toyota; Japanese; hatchback; hybrid
metaDescription: The pioneer of the category is still going strong. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Front-wheel-drive hybrid hatchback
Price range: $20,365–$35,730 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Prius, Two, Three, Four, Five, Persona, Special Edition, Prius c, c Two, c Three, c Four; Prius v, v Two, v Three, v Four, v Five; Prius Plug-in
Engines: 1.5-liter four-cylinder/electric hybrid, 99 horsepower; 1.8-liter four-cylinder/electric hybrid, 134 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: Prius: 51 mpg city/48 mpg highway; Prius c: 53/46 mpg; Prius Plug-in Hybrid: 50 mpg (combined, 95 mpg-3; Prius v: 44/40 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Prius/Prius v: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Prius: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Keyless entry and start
Notable standard features on this model: Multi-information display
Notable options on this model: Moonroof with integrated solar panels that power a venting system to cool the car when parked
You might also be considering: Ford C-Max Hybrid, Nissan Leaf, Volkswagen Jetta TDI

Toyota’s reputation as a leader in hybrid technology began with the original 2001 Prius. Over the years, the vehicle lineup has been expanded and now includes four distinct models that vary in size and propulsion type. The regular Prius is powered by a 1.8-liter engine supplemented by a battery-powered electric motor that achieves 44/40 mpg city/highway. The plug-in version of this body style adds a lithium-ion battery that can be charged externally and used to operate the vehicle in electric mode for a limited number of miles at speeds of up to 62 mph. It achieves 95 mpg-e or a combined rating of 50 mpg. The third variant, the Prius c, uses the same hybrid powertrain as the standard Prius but is nearly twenty inches shorter, starts at about $5,000 less, and averages 53 mpg in the city. And it comes in colors more vivid than a bag of jellybeans. Then there’s the Prius v, which is basically a stretched, wagon version of the Prius with a roomier rear seat and almost thirteen cubic feet of additional cargo space under the rear hatch.

All Prius models have multiple safety extras like driver’s knee and side curtain airbags, vehicle proximity notification, plus the Star Safety System that enhances braking ability, traction, and stability. An available moonroof even has a solar panel component to power a heat-venting system while parked. For all the high-tech amenities available, the interior remains rather sparse in feeling. The digital instrument display is nestled so deeply in the dash that it’s a bit challenging to read at a quick glance. None of the members of the Prius family are known for high-performance qualities, but with so many other great qualities, one of the Prius family cars might be just right for you.

New for 2015

A Special Edition gets its own seventeen-inch wheels, unique interior materials and features, and two exclusive exterior color choices.

title: 2015 Toyota Sequoia
subTitle: Big and brawny.
promoTeaserSmall: Big and brawny.
promoTeaser: Big and brawny.
metaKeywords: 2015 Toyota Sequoia; Toyota; Japanese; SUV; sport-utility
