pageElements.text:
Type: SUV
Price range: $45,320–$65,245 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SR5, Limited, Platinum
Engine: 5.7-liter V-8, 381 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): FWD: 13/18; AWD: 13/ 17 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: N/A
Our favorite standard feature: Second and third row retracable sunshades
Notable standard features on this model: Tow package
Notable options on this model: Blu-ray disc player
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Tahoe, Ford Explorer, Nissan Armada

One engine choice is all you get in the outsize Sequoia but at 381 horses this 5.7-liter V-8 is plenty to push this big sport-ute around. The brawny V-8, integrated hitch, and trailer-sway control system make towing—a maximum of 7,400 pounds—a breeze. You do have a choice of either two-wheel or four-wheel drive. If driving challenges like steep inclines or difficult weather figure regularly into your schedule, consider adding Toyota’s Multi-Mode 4-wheel-drive system with a limited-slip locking center differential. The interior is voluminous to be sure, seating eight adults while still maintaining 18.9 cubic feet of dedicated cargo space in the back. Fold down the second- and third-row seats and capacity reaches an expansive 120.1 cubic feet.

The ultra-wide dash accommodates all the necessary instrumentation, climate controls, and even double-decker glove compartments. Still, for its size this large SUV has one of the tightest turning circles you’ll find and handles the curves with unexpected grace. Adventure essentials like running boards, roof rack, and headlight-washers are standard on all three trims. Choose the SR5 Sport Appearance package for a unique black interior. The Limited offers some leather accents and Lexus-inspired gauges, while the Platinum ramps up the mechanical tech with adaptive air suspension and a laser-based cruise control system that measures the distance to the cars ahead and brakes when necessary. Fortunately, the Sequoia does not suffer from the boxy exterior design so common in its class giving it the kind of driveway appeal your neighbors may appreciate.

New for 2015

Entune audio system with navigation and the Toyota App suite.

title: 2015 Lamborghini Huracan
subTitle: So good, it could be a daily driver.
promoTeaserSmall: So good, it could be a daily driver.
promoTeaser: So good, it could be a daily driver.
metaKeywords: 2015 Lamborghini Huracan; Lamborghini; Italian; sports car; supercar
metaDescription: So good, it could be a daily driver. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, all-wheel-drive super coupe
Price range: $279,345 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Huracán LP 610-4, LP 620-2 Super Trofeo
Engine: 5.2-liter V-10, 610 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 14/20 (est.; city/highway)
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission
Notable standard features on this model: 12.3-inch customizable instrument display, all-wheel drive
Notable options on this model: A plethora of colors and finishes.
You might also be considering: Ferrari 458 Italia, McLaren P1

Replacing the Lamborghini Gallardo involved some risk. With 14,022 produced, the Gallardo was the brand’s best-selling model of all time. Rather than proceed timidly, Lamborghini offered the Huracán for 2015. Named for a feared fighting bull of 1879, the new car is far sexier and slightly more sinister, its face highlighted by glowering LED positioning lamps. The roofline and fenders have a purity that is risked by the repetition of polygons all over the car, including the interior, but ultimately the design holds together. Under the rear glass sits a revised, more powerful, 610-horsepower version of the 5.2-liter V-10. It’s now mated to a superb seven-speed dual-clutch automatic, which replaces the Gallardo’s slam-bang sequential semi-automatic six-speed. Yes, the car is fast: 0 to 60 mph in 3.2 seconds, with top speed of 202 mph.

Beyond this, the Huracán exudes genteel refinement, precision, and quality. With the driving mode set in Strada, for tooling around town, there’s an unexpectedly supple ride and lightness of touch. Yet advancing the modes through Sport to Corsa, for the track, brings about a serious mien that few other cars in the world would dare to muster. Inside, the driver faces a wondrous, customizable 12.3-inch instrument screen, and both occupants repose in exquisite leather seats. Options for individualizing your Huracán are hugely varied, but as always, we ask: Do you really want the available orange upholstery?

New for 2015

The Huracán LP 620-2 Super Trofeo is the lightweight version for duty in Lamborghini’s own racing series.

title: 2016 Cadillac CT6
subTitle: Big, posh, powerful, and dynamic enough to bring the glory days back.
promoTeaserSmall: Big, posh, powerful, and dynamic enough to bring the glory days back.
promoTeaser: Big, posh, powerful, and dynamic enough to bring the glory days back.
metaDescription: Big, posh, powerful, and dynamic enough to bring the glory days back.

pageElements.text:
Type: Rear- and all-wheel-drive luxury sedan
On-sale date: Early 2016
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 400 horsepower; turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 265 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 336 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Most interesting feature: Enhanced Night Vision
Potential competitors: Audi A8, BMW 7 Series, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class
To those old enough to remember, this handsome sedan seems a philosophical return to the days when Cadillacs were big, posh, powerful, and as coveted as any car in the world.
Those were the glory days, of course, and Cadillac’s prestige has long since been pre-empted by a trio of Germans, as well as a couple of upstarts from Japan.

Nevertheless, the new CT6 appears to have the other traits—big, posh, powerful—fully covered. And unlike those snooty leviathans of yesteryear, it’s reasonable to expect this new four-door to deliver dynamics that just weren’t part of the deal in the 1950s and ’60s. Not only will it dash, it’ll zig, zag, and stop with alacrity.
Cadillac boss Johan de Nysschen expects the CT6 to be the most agile among large luxury sedans.

Cadillac wasn’t ready to reveal dimensional specifics for its new rear-wheel-drive flagship, other than to say that the CT6 is bigger than the CTS sedan, but its curb weights are comparable with those of its mid-size cousin as well as those of cars like the big BMW 7 Series, flagship of the Bavarian sedan lineup.

Relatively modest mass and high chassis rigidity were achieved by employing a mix of eleven different structural materials, according to Cadillac engineering, a mix that includes thirteen different aluminum castings and 64 percent of the body panels . A stiff chassis is the prerequisite for responsive dynamics, something Cadillac will augment with its magnetic damping system, rear-wheel steering, and all-wheel drive.
Cadillac boss Johan de Nysschen expects the CT6 to be the “most agile among large luxury sedans.”

Three engines will be offered: a new twin-turbo V-6 rated for 400 horsepower, with cylinder deactivation to enhance fuel economy; a 2.0-liter turbo four-cylinder; and a normally aspirated 3.6-liter V-6. All are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission.
The look is unmistakably Cadillac, thanks to yet another interpretation of the now familiar grille and vertically stacked headlights, a look that wears well in this bigger sedan.
The pièce de résistance is a new ultra-premium audio option that entails thirty-four speakers.

And of course there’s luxury galore. A couple examples: “extended comfort,” seats with an adjustable massage feature; touchscreen displays integrated into the front-seat backs, allowing rear-seat passengers to exploit the new Caddy’s electronic connectivity features; and, the pièce de résistance, a new ultra-premium audio option that entails thirty-four speakers. Bose established a new subdivision, Panaray, to develop the system.

No mention of the audio system’s cost, of course, and no mention of the price of the car itself. We’ll know more late this year, when production begins. The car probably won’t reach showrooms much before January 1.

title: 2016 Mercedes-Benz GLE-Class
subTitle: New face, new rear, and just what was needed: more power.
promoTeaserSmall: New face, new rear, and just what was needed: more power.
promoTeaser: New face, new rear, and just what was needed: more power.
metaDescription: New face, new rear, and just what was needed: more power.

pageElements.text:
2016 Mercedes-AMG GLE63

Type: All-wheel-drive premium sport-utility vehicle
On-sale date: Late 2015
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 5.5-liter V-8, 550 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Most interesting feature: Night package (gloss black grille and mirror housings, 20-inch AMG gloss black light alloy wheels)
Potential competitors: BMW X6 M, Land Rover Range Rover Supercharged, Porsche Cayenne Turbo
GLE is a designation that describes vehicles we’ve known as ML since Mercedes got into the SUV business back in 1977.
And AMG, as is widely known, is the Mercedes performance subsidiary devoted to making everything in the corporate inventory go faster.

The massive Mercedes G65 is an excellent example. Weighing almost three tons, and exactly as aerodynamic as a big cube of basalt, it can nevertheless sprint to 60 mph in 5.3 seconds, according to Mercedes, leaving temporary vacuums and thunderclaps in its wake. Getting the G65 (yours for just $217,000) to overcome inertia to this degree requires massive thrust, specifically 621 horsepower and 738 pound-feet of torque from a twin-turbo V-12 engine.

AMG’s new GLE twins can reach mile-a-minute speeds considerably quicker, in 4.0 seconds or even less, with less drama and, presumably, for less money. Not bad for a big vehicle with curb weights exceeding 5,300 pounds.

The GLE lineup is wide-ranging, even including a hybrid. The sportiest versions are the AMGs, which sport freshened front and rear styling. Their suspension systems have also been revised, and, of course, there’s more of that essential commodity that sets AMG products apart from their stablemates: muscle.

The ML63 AMG brought 516 horsepower to the starting line, with 550 hp available via the optional Performance package. The Mercedes-AMG 63 has 550 horsepower on tap, and the 63 S (for Sport, replacing the Performance package) has 577 horsepower—all of this from the same 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 engine.
As with other members of the GLE lineup, the twin-turbo V-8 is paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission.

The new AMG GLE offerings are expected to reach U.S. Mercedes showrooms this fall. Pricing was not part of the Mercedes New York auto show presentation, but the ML63 started at a little over $95,000. We predict that these new AMG creations will start a little higher.

title: 2015 Chrysler 300
subTitle: Makes a statement.
promoTeaserSmall: Makes a statement.
promoTeaser: Makes a statement.
metaDescription: Makes a statement. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $32,390–$43,390 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Limited, 300S, 300C, 300C Platinum
Engines: 3.6-liter V-6, 292 horsepower; 5.7-liter V-8, 363 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): V-6 RWD: 19/31; V-6 AWD: 18/27; V-8: 16/25 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick
Our favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Notable standard features on this model: 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen media center
Notable option on this model: All-wheel drive
You might also be considering: Toyota Avalon, Chevrolet Impala, Buick LaCrosse

When the Chrysler 300 debuted back in 2005, its Bentley-like styling made it a big hit for Chrysler. By the time the second-generation car was introduced in 2011, the 300 had lost some of its novelty, but it is still the epitome of the large, rear-wheel-drive American sedan. For 2015, the 300 has a new front fascia with a larger grille, along with new taillamps and an interior that features upgraded materials and styling, including a rotary gear selector similar to the one used by Jaguar.

There are two available engines, a V-6 and a V-8, and all-wheel drive is a $2500 option on V-6 300s ($4195 on 300 Limited). Chrysler boasts that the V-6, at 31 mpg on the highway, makes the 300 the fuel-economy leader in the full-size sedan class. Also best in class is the 363 horsepower of the available Hemi V-8. This year, for the first time, both engines are available with the super-smooth eight-speed automatic transmission. There are four trim levels to choose from: the well-equipped Limited, the sporty 300S, the uplevel 300C, and the luxury 300C Platinum.

The Chrysler 300 is a big car, but you can dial up the sportiness by pressing the Sport button on the dashboard, which reduces shift times, firms up the steering, and increases engine responsiveness. In addition the 300 has a host of available safety features, such as forward collision warning, lane-departure warning, adaptive cruise control, and a 911 button you can push in case of an emergency.

New for 2015

A new midlevel trim, the 300S, as well a refreshed exterior, a new standard eight-speed automatic transmission, an optional selectable sport mode, and additional Uconnect capabilities.

More about the Chrysler 300

2015 Chrysler 300s: Walkaround December 24, 2014
2015 Chrysler 300 Limited AWD May 11, 2015

title: 2015 Kia K900
subTitle: Nailing luxury.
promoTeaserSmall: Nailing luxury.

metaDescription: Nailing luxury. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:

Trim levels: Premium, Luxury

Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 15/23 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: N/A

Notable standard features on this model: Rear-seat USB charger, 9.2-inch navigation display, surround view camera
Notable options on this model: LED headlamps with Dynamic Bending feature, soft-close doors, quilted Nappa leather seats, 16-way driver’s seat, heated and ventilated front seats and heated rear outboard seats
You might also be considering: Infiniti Q70, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

Kia built a Lexus? So we asked upon grasping the heated, wood-trimmed steering wheel in the Kia K900. It drives with dreamy smoothness, like a Lexus, yet issues a muted snarl from the exhaust when the gas pedal gets stomped. The 5.0-liter V-8 generates 420 horsepower, which is transmitted through an advanced eight-speed automatic. Three driving modes—Eco, Normal, Sport, —govern the big 4555-pound sedan’s behavior. The K900 is more than just a case of an existing car being endowed with a lot of gadgets. It’s 200.6 inches long and rather tall-shouldered, so that the 19-inch wheels don’t seem at all too large. In our driveway, it looked stately and prepossessing. The fact that it’s so well equipped for the price seems miraculous. There are two models, Premium and Luxury, sharing the same powertrain. The Premium comes with all the important stuff like illuminated door scuff plates and a power-operated rear sunshade, but the Luxury pursues overkill with an optional 12.3-inch instrument cluster, soft-close doors, and head-up display. As standard features, it adds key safety features (blind spot detection, rear cross traffic alert) and makes smart cruise control optional. A particular delight is the available quilted Nappa leather seat trim. And wait till you see the complexity of the clock that’s mounted in a dashboard. Details and craftsmanship, along with a sound grasp of the grand scheme, make Kia successful in its entry into the luxury segment.

New for 2015

The K900 is a new model this year.

More about the Kia K900

2015 Kia K900 Luxury, Should You Buy It? February 10, 2015
2015 Kia K900 Designer Walkaround December 6, 2013
2015 Kia K900: L.A. Show November 20, 2013

title: 2015 Kia Sedona
subTitle: Another step up in sophistication.
promoTeaserSmall: Another step up in sophistication.
promoTeaser: Another step up in sophistication.
metaDescription: Another step up in sophistication. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Minivan
Price range: $25,195–$40,595 (includes destination)
Trim levels: L, LX, EX, SX, SX Limited
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 276 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): L, LX, EX: 18/24; SX: 18/25; SX Limited: 17/22 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good, all categories; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Front and rear controls for air conditioning
Notable standard features on this model: Side-N-Stow second-row seat function, third-row 60-40 split and sinking seating, YES Essentials seat fabric protection, Bluetooth connectivity, backup warning system
Notable options on this model: Surround-view camera, 19-inch alloy wheels, Nappa leather seating, power liftgate, heated front and second-row seats, ventilated front seats, second- and third-row sunshade, blind spot detection
You might also be considering: Chrysler Town & Country, Honda Odyssey, Toyota Sienna

The great design being practiced at Kia extends to the Sedona. From its bull nose to the spoiler that finishes the tapering roofline, this minivan shows some attitude. The Sedona is large (although at 201.4 inches, it’s only .8 inch longer than the K900 luxury sedan). Nevertheless, it steps off smartly thanks to the direct-injection 3.3-liter V-6, which makes 276 horsepower. A six-speed automatic transmission modulates the output. Seven-passenger seating is standard, with the Side-N-Stow second-row seat function included to make additional cargo room. Eight-passenger seating is optional in the LX and SX, standard in the EX. Trim levels range from the L, which is basic without being a monk’s cell, to the rather opulent Limited. A wood-trimmed, heated steering wheel and Nappa leather contribute to the interior’s distinctiveness, power side doors and liftgate are included, and 19-inch wheels suggest a formidable paw print. Smart cruise control is available on the Limited. Both the SX and Limited come with a 110-volt inverter in the console zone, letting you plug in a laptop. The Limited has a second inverter in the rear cargo area. The Sedona’s design, engineering, and product development team have done a great job with the new minivan. All entries in this segment are quite comparable in specifications and feature content, but crisp body lines give the Sedona an edge.

New for 2015

This all-new model was introduced last fall.

title: 2015 Scion iQ
subTitle: Niche player.
promoTeaserSmall: Niche player.
promoTeaser: Niche player.
metaDescription: Niche player. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive minicar
Price range: $16,435–$17,290 (includes destination)
Trim levels: iQ, iQ Monogram Series
Engine: 1.3-liter four-cylinder, 94 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 36 mpg city/37 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in three categories, Average in head restraint category; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Touchscreen audio and navigation system
Notable standard features on this model: Six-speaker sound system, Bluetooth connectivity, keyless entry.
Notable options on this model: BeSpoke voice-controlled audio system
You might also be considering: Fiat 500, Smart Fortwo

The Scion iQ, which is soon to be discontinued, has brought an innovative approach to its task of being a fun-loving city car. It has a turning circle of 26.6 feet and a unique three-plus-one seating arrangement, yet with the rear seats folded flat it holds suitcases. The iQ is an inexpensive car but not a cheap one. The flat-bottomed steering wheel is leather wrapped, navigation is standard, and the six-speaker sound system gives this pod some thump. A 6.1-inch touchscreen is standard, and there’s a USB port. The available BeSpoke audio adds voice control and the downloadable Aha app for countless listening choices.

The iQ Monogram Series includes two-tone silver and black-currant metallic paint, graphite-look sixteen-inch alloy wheels, and a rear spoiler. Those who worry about the safety of such a small car should take a deep breath and count to eleven, because that’s how many air bags are included. For the sake of comparison, we will mention that the Toyota Sienna minivan has only eight air bags. In addition, the iQ is endowed with a suite of electronic safety systems including stability control. The Smart Fortwo may be a better-known microcar, but the Scion iQ brings formidable credentials to the tiny parking space derby.

New for 2015

No new features.

promoTeaserSmall: The beet(le) goes on.
promoTeaser: The beet(le) goes on.
metaDescription: The beet(le) goes on. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Hatchback, convertible
Price range: $21,515–$36,795 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 1.8T, TDI, R-Line, Beetle Classic
Engines: 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 170 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbo-diesel four cylinder, 150 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 210 horsepower
Transmissions: 5- or 6-speed manual, or 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 1.8T manual: 24/33; 1.8T automatic: 25/33; 2.0, manual: 23/31; 2.0-liter, automatic: 24/30; TDI: 31/41 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Coupe: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, head restraints & seats), marginal (small overlap front), Convertible: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Auxiliary port for portable audio players
Notable standard features on this model: Power windows with one-touch function, leatherette upholstery, leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel, Bluetooth connectivity, three-color ambient lighting
Notable options on this model: Rearview camera, panoramic sunroof, leather upholstery, remote keyless entry and remote start, premium audio system, navigation
You might also be considering: Audi A3, Fiat 500, Mini Cooper, Nissan Juke

Two developments in the 2015 Volkswagen Beetle lineup merit attention. One is the addition of the Beetle Classic, a value-priced offering in both coupe and convertible form. This least expensive Beetle ($21,515 coupe, $26,415 convertible) takes the standard features of the 1.8T and is then outfitted with a navigation system, a six-speed automatic transmission, and retro-style 17-inch wheels. Inside, it has two-tone leatherette and checked-cloth seats for a look that’s indeed classic. The Beetle Classic can be chosen in white, black, or silver. The second newsworthy item is the new diesel engine, the very latest from Volkswagen’s engineers. It makes an additional 10 horsepower and gets a 2 mpg fuel economy bump on the highway. With 236 pound-feet of torque available at just 1750 rpm—that’s 14 percent greater than the even high-output gasoline turbo engine in the Beetle R-Line—it provides lots of stomp. Also this year, a rearview camera is standard on all but the base versions of the 1.8T, Beetle Classic, and R-Line. A blind-spot monitor and rear traffic alert are available across the lineup. Each of the four models—1.8T, Classic, R-Line, and TDI—is available as a coupe or convertible. The beauty of a Beetle is the combination of heritage, sportiness, and utility while still pulling off a modern look all its own.

New for 2015

2.0-liter turbo-diesel engine, limited-edition Beetle Classic.

title: 2015 Porsche Macan Turbo
subTitle: Just the thing for a midlife crisis: 400 horsepower in my driveway. A short, sweet video review.

promoTeaser: Just the thing for a midlife crisis: 400 horsepower in my driveway. A short, sweet video review.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Porsche Macan Turbo

Type: All-wheel-drive compact luxury crossover
Base price: $50,895 (including destination charge)
This car: $97,065 (including destination charge)
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 400 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed double-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated sport steering wheel
Options I can't live without: Sport chrono package ($1,290)
Notable standard features on this model: Eighteen-way adaptive sport seats, Bose surround sound system, navigation system, xenon headlights, LED daytime running lights
Notable options on this model: Test car is fully loaded with 25 options. Some of the more noteworthy ones are a black leather interior ($1,730), garnet red seatbelts ($500), active cruise control ($1,600), and a fire extinguisher under the front passenger's seat ($140)
Safety features: Rearview camera, part of Park Assist package ($1,460)
You might also be considering: 2015 Audi Q5 ($40,225), 2015 BMW X3 ($39,450), 2015 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque ($42,025) (prices include destination charges)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/wks0jbPE8Ng" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points:

• This is the so-called “Baby Cayenne.”
• It may be the perfect mid-life crisis vehicle, since driving it doesn't make it obvious that you’re having one.
• The Macan is a sought-after luxury compact crossover/SUV with its sports-car-like handling, powerful engine options, and comfortable ride.
• The name Macan is Indonesian for "tiger."

• This one has its claws out for the competition and really plays in a space that has not been served: Competitors do not offer a luxury compact crossover with 400 horsepower and those optional garnet red seatbelts.
• The Macan Turbo sprints from 0 to 60 mph in 4.6 seconds and has a top track speed of 164 mph. Perfect for a grocery run.
• There's a shocking disparity between the base price of around $50,000 for the standard model to the fully loaded one shown here, priced at nearly $100,000.
• The standard Macan is not a spartan experience due to generous standard features. Also, Porsche doesn’t make a big deal out of this, but the base model also has a twin-turbo engine as noted above.
• Standard features include a multifunction sport steering wheel with paddle shifters, nineteen-inch wheels, a high-performance audio system, and a power tailgate.
• The base Macan is intriguing, since it’s the first time the 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6 is being used in a Porsche.

• From a design standpoint, the Macan takes some of its cues from the 918 Spyder and the 911. The Macan adopts the basic shape of the headlights from the 918 Spyder and the profile of the rear fenders from the 911.
• Our test car has the $420 Porsche Car Connect option, which lets you use your smartphone to locate your vehicle, access vehicle information, and contact Porsche in the event of a breakdown.
• The cabin has lots of buttons, but they are generally intuitive after some use.
• Test car has an optional $1,290 Sport Chrono package that adds a stopwatch with an analog and digital display to the cockpit.
• The performance display lets you view a range of driving stats, including your total driving time, current lap distance, and lap times recorded so far.
• The lateral and longitudinal forces acting on the vehicle are illustrated by the G-Force graphic on the color screen in the instrument cluster.
• Cargo space is limited.

images.caption: Dog crate (just) fits in 2015 Porsche Macan Turbo.
Lots of controls in the 2015 Porsche Macan Turbo.
2015 Porsche Maan Turbo has a seven-speed Porsche PDK transmission.
Navigation and eighteen-way sport seats are standard on 2015 Porsche Macan Turbo.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive wagon
Base price: $27,815 (including destination charge)
This car: $29,505 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual (standard); six-speed automatic (optional)
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/35 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Option I can't live without: Titan black leatherette interior (no-cost option)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, keyless access with push-button start, panoramic power tilting and sliding sunroof, cooled glove box, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob
Notable options on this model: Driver Assistance package (includes forward collision warning, park assist, $895)
You might also be considering: 2015 Honda Crosstour ($28,410); 2015 Subaru Outback ($25,745); 2015 Toyota Prius V ($27,575) (all prices include destination charges)

Let’s start with a little full-disclosure moment. The Jennings family owns a 2013 VW Jetta SportWagen TDI. We love our Jetta very much, and so does Bob, our Chesapeake show dog, for whom we bought our German wagen-with-an-e, equipped with a thrifty diesel engine.

We had been hauling Bob to dog shows around the country in a Chevrolet Suburban, equally loved (as is our Mazdaspeed Miata), but with the average fuel economy (14 mpg) of a Cessna. Once we confirmed that the Jetta diesel was delivering around 43 mpg on average (and our monthly fuel bill had dropped from $1,000 to a much more reasonable number), the Suburban became semi-retired, reserved for towing trailers and for three-dog-cage kennel transport..

Meanwhile, we have become enamored of the brand spanking new 2015 Golf SportWagen. It replaces the Jetta SportWagen, so, while my Jetta wagon is still cool, it has suddenly become obsolete. It is no more.

But that’s okay, because the new SportWagen looks radically more modern and sleek and everything cool, suddenly making my black Jetta wagon that much more drab and dusty next to it. (Note to self: Do not let husband buy a black car ever again.) The sheetmetal is more shapely, the headlamps and taillamps more artful and technically superior.
This SportWagen is all Golf, and all Golfs are good. Even the ones that aren’t sports cars like the zingy GTI and the powerful R are are satisfying and special.

The Golf lineup was voted 2015 North American Car of the Year, and this SportWagen completes the new Golf portfolio. It is all Golf, and all Golfs are good. Even the ones that aren’t sports cars like the zingy GTI and the powerful R are satisfying and special in that Teutonic way. It is tightly screwed together, the seats are a comfortable chair height, and the focus is on the driver. The steering is precise, and the brakes are satisfyingly direct.
The new Golf SportWagen can be ordered with a 2.0-liter turbo-diesel engine making 150 horsepower (TDI) or a 1.8-liter four-cylinder turbocharged gasoline engine making 170 horsepower (TSI).
No matter which engine you choose, the Golf SportWagen is more nimble than any comparable compact crossover, a category that most wagon buyers are probably also considering.

But there’s the elephant in the room. Station wagon. Two words that don’t clinic well with America’s car shoppers. That confounds Europeans, who love their station wagons. Of course, they call them SportWagens (VW), Avants (Audi), estate cars, et cetera, instead of station wagons. And they buy them with turbo-diesel engines.

The Golf SportWagen I drove was the TSI, with the four-cylinder gasoline engine. A lot of American shoppers might prefer it over the excellent turbo-diesel engine in this VW.
It’s paired with a five-speed manual transmission or an optional six-speed automatic. The TDI, the diesel model, has a six-speed manual transmission as standard that’s perfectly geared for maximum performance, with an automatic optional. If you hesitate to consider the diesel, let me suggest that you reconsider that. You get better fuel economy with the turbo-diesel, and you also get more range—about 488 miles between fillups, compared with around 395 for the gasoline engine. Not having to stop and fill the tank on a long drive is a great benefit of a diesel.

The Golf wagon is 1.1 inches longer than the outgoing Jetta wagon, and its wheelbase has grown by 2.2 inches. Yet the wagon is almost an inch lower for what VW calls a more “muscular” look. It may be under $30,000, but it has its share of amenities. Standard on the TSI SE I tested were a panoramic sunroof with power tilt and slide, a cooled glove box, heated front seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and Bluetooth connectivity. It also came with seventeen-inch alloy wheels, and our test car had a Driver Assistance package ($895) that includes forward collision warning and park assist technology.
The new Golf lineup has also been modernized inside. The look and feel are really quite striking, making the SportWagen feel like a much more expensive vehicle.

My husband is a no-frills kind of hunter-gatherer. He combed the country to find a stripped version of the 2013 Jetta SportWagen TDI and managed to find one that had only floor mats and a first aid kit as options. He added a protective metal strip on the rear to easily slide the dog crate in and out of the cargo hold. Surprisingly, he discovered that air conditioning, Bluetooth hands-free phone, and heated front seats were all standard equipment.

Wait until he hears that the standard Golf SportWagen TDI also adds keyless access with push-button start and a rearview camera. As exciting as that is to me, he will be more impressed to discover that the price of the 2015 SportWagen TDI will be almost $2,000 less than our 2013 Jetta version.

Where am I going with this? Yes. After two years, the family Jetta is being readied for the block, and plans are afoot to buy the lower, longer, wider, lighter, more fuel-efficient, more loaded Golf SportWagen TDI S.

images.caption: The Jennings family and their 2015 Volkswagen Jetta SportWagen.

subTitle: A solid full-size sedan.

promoTeaser: A solid full-size sedan.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive full-size sedan
Price range: $27,880–$41,045 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SE, SEL, Limited, SHO
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 288 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.5-liter V-6, 365 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: V-6, FWD: 19 mpg city/29 mpg highway; V-6, AWD: 18/26 mpg; Turbo V-6: 17/25 mpg; four-cylinder: 22/32 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in four categories; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: LED taillamps and dual chrome exhaust
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Lane keeping, adaptive cruise control, heated front and outboard second-row seats
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Impala, Chrysler 300, Toyota Avalon

The attractive and roomy Taurus remains largely unchanged for 2015 except for a few new options: a moonroof, backup sensors, keyless entry, push-button start. There are also three new color choices Bronze Fire, Caribou, and Magnetic. There are four trim levels, some with the option of all-wheel drive—the base SE model is front-wheel drive only and the 2.0-liter four can’t be paired with all-wheel drive. The cabin is roomy, particularly for back-seat passengers. The Taurus has an extensive list of comfort, safety, and convenience options: notable items include rain-sensing wipers, a lane-keeping system, heated rear seats, and a power sunshade for the rear window. Dune cloth is the only seat material option on the SE, but as you work your way up the trim levels, the choices expand to include additional cloth options and leather in Charcoal Black as well as Dune. The sporty SHO model can be had with two-tone leather. More important, the SHO is fitted with a 365-horsepower twin-turbo V-6 and a stiffer suspension. The Taurus is a solid choice for those looking for a nicely trimmed, comfortable full-size sedan.

New for 2015

Power moonroof is now available on the Limited trim.

title: 2015 Chevrolet Express
subTitle: An ultra-customizable work van.
promoTeaserSmall: An ultra-customizable work van.
promoTeaser: An ultra-customizable work van.
metaKeywords: 2015 Chevrolet Express; Chevrolet; Chevy; van; work van; American
metaDescription: An ultra-customizable work van. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Rear-wheel-drive work or 12-to-15-passenger van
Price range: $29,555–$50,635
Trim levels: WT, Diesel
Engines: 4.8-liter V-8, 285 horsepower; 6.0-liter V-8, 329 horsepower; turbo-diesel 6.6-liter V-8, 260 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): N/A
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Trailer sway control
Notable standard features on this model: Enhanced three-layer rear side glass for safety
Notable options on this model: Rear park assist with camera and backup sensors
You might also be considering: Ford Transit, Mercedes-Benz Sprinter, Nissan NV1500/2500/3500, Ram ProMaster

Ready to upgrade your working vehicle from that beat-up minivan to something that will make your ride work for you—and make you look more professional? There are numerous ways to customize the Express so you can take your work on the road. Interior shelving will keep your tools of the trade organized, safe, and easy to access. A rooftop rack can also be added to hold ladders of other bulky tools. The interior can also be configured to seat up to five passengers and with sliding side doors. Want to make opening up your shop easier? Choose an access package that lets you add up to three exterior remote-release, side-access panels you can open with a keyless remote.

Whatever you do, this cargo van can likely hold it. If you can’t fit your gear in or on the Express, it can certainly haul it. The van can handle a 4,145-pound payload and tow up to 10,000 pounds. There are power outlets and USB ports to keep a work laptop or tablet running, and it can be optioned with a 3G Internet connection accessible in or around the vehicle. A cross-traffic alert system, OnStar Directions and Connections, and in-dash navigation are all possibilities with this highly customizable ride.

New for 2015

A household-standard 110V power outlet to plug in your laptop as well as an auxiliary outlet and an available USB port, new exterior colors, exterior LED lighting.

More about the Chevrolet Express

2015 Chevrolet City Express April 1, 2015

You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Chrysler 300, Ford Taurus, Nissan Maxima, Toyota Avalon

If this car’s name seems synonymous with stodgy (or rental car), take another look. This is a lot of slick car for the price. Its lined in quality materials, comfortably seats five, boasts a commodious 18.8 cubic feet of trunk space, and brings along connectivity and technology: built-in 4G LTE and a Wi-Fi hot spot are an option. Chevrolet MyLink connects your phone through Bluetooth so you can access your favorite tunes and apps in the color in-dash display. And behind the eight-inch touchscreen is a lockable compartment where you can stash—and charge—your phone. (Why don’t all cars have this?)

This full-size front-wheel-drive sedan is big enough for the family but priced in the high $20,000s, a reasonable price for an attractive car that feels absolutely nothing like a school bus. It's also up to date in important ways: the 2015 Impala has an optional advanced safety package with forward collision alert, side blind-zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane departure warning.

New for 2015

This is the not-so-strictly-utilitarian small car. It’s got a funky, urban, motorcycle-inspired look to it. And it’s a blast to drive. Despite its diminutive size, the Sonic offers several modern safety features, including forward collision alert, lane departure warnings, automatic crash response, and a rearview camera.

The Sonic offers seating for five plus almost 15 cubic feet and 19 cubic feet of cargo space in the sedan and hatch, respectively. Fold down the rear seats—both lie flat or do a 60/40 split—and the hatch can swallow more than 47 cubic feet of gear. And there is plenty of tech in this little car, too: Bluetooth, music streaming through Pandora or Stitcher SmartRadio, Satellite radio, and more. It’s pretty cute, too with a playfully aggressive exterior that can be painted in mild to wild colors. The interior can be outfitted in equally interesting colors and has smart details like contrast seat stitching and racy gauges. This is a small car you can enjoy both driving and looking at.

New in 2015

New color, 4G LTE with Wi-Fi is standard for 3 months.

More about the Chevrolet Sonic

2014 Chevrolet Sonic: Wild Colors July 25, 2013

pageElements.text:

Trim levels: LS, LT, LTZ
Engine: 5.3-liter V-8, 355 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: FWD: 16 mpg city/23 mpg highway; AWD: 16/22 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Heated and ventilated perforated leather front bucket seats and heated steering wheel (LTZ)
Notable standard features on this model: Up to twelve charging locations, including up to six USB ports
Notable options on this model: Theft Protection package includes glass-breakage sensors, interior motion detectors, and an inclination sensor that measures tilt of the vehicle
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Suburban, GMC Yukon, Ford Expedition, Toyota Sequoia

The Tahoe is big, but that doesn't mean it's not beautiful. This is a full-size SUV, fresh from a complete overhaul, that is as comfortable shepherding people to the slopes or the sea as it is parked in front of a five-star hotel. The Tahoe LTZ has standard heated and ventilated perforated leather front seats and a heated steering wheel. It also has Magnetic Ride Control that is capable of making adjustments every ten to fifteen milliseconds to quell road imperfections. The LS models have room for up to nine passengers. An acoustic-laminated windshield and triple-sealed doors create a luxurious silence inside.

The Tahoe is no slouch when it comes to getting a bit of work done, either. With the second- and third-row seats folded flat, it has nearly 95 cubic feet of cargo space. And folding those seats flat is a five-second task with optional power seat folding. On the safety front, strategically located cameras and radar sensors give you blind spot, parking, and cross-traffic support.

New for 2015

The Tahoe is all-new for 2015.

Price range: $28,990–$63,290 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SE, SE AWD, SXT, SXT AWD, R/T, R/T Road & Track, R/T Scat Pack, SRT 392, SRT Hellcat
Engines: 3.6-liter V-6, 292/300 horsepower; 5.7-liter V-8, 370 horsepower; 6.4-liter V-8, 485 horsepower; supercharged 6.2-liter V-8, 707 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 3.6-liter, RWD: 19 mpg city/31 mpg highway; 3.6-liter, manual: 18/27 mpg; 5.7-liter: 16/25 mpg; 6.4-liter: 15/25 mpg (est.); 6.2-liter: 13/22 mpg (est.)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Transportation Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Seven-inch customizable TFT instrument panel
Notable standard features on this model: Seventeen-inch alloy wheels, infotainment touchscreen, keyless entry, push-button start, multifunction steering wheel, three-mode electrically assisted steering, dual-zone climate control, six-speaker audio system
Notable options on this model: Navigation, rearview camera, heated front and rear seats, heated steering wheel, automatic headlamps, twenty-inch wheels, ventilated front seats, heated rear seats and steering wheel
You might also be considering: Chevrolet SS, Chrysler 300, Ford Taurus SHO

Nothing else in the marketplace quite compares to the Dodge Charger, a large sedan driven by the rear wheels (all-wheel drive is available) and offering amazing performance. It presents the classic argument against prestige brands costing far more. With its supercharged 6.2-liter V-8 generating an almost inconceivable 707 horsepower, the new Charger SRT Hellcat will reach 204 mph. Dodge says it’s the world’s quickest, fastest, most powerful sedan. Even lesser models like the SRT 392 and R/T Scat Pack boast 485 horsepower from their 6.4-liter V-8.

Meanwhile, the list of improvements throughout the lineup shows the Dodge brand’s increasing sophistication. Designers have streamlined the Charger and added LED lighting front and rear, and inside the cabin, the instrument panel now has a seven-inch TFT information display. All models come with an eight-speed automatic transmission, which is operated by an electronic shifter (paddle shifters in top performance models). Electrically assisted power steering offers Normal, Comfort, and Sport modes, as conditions warrant. Buying an SRT model makes you eligible for the SRT Track Experience to explore your car’s potential. A suite of driver assistance and safety features is available. Heated front seats are standard on most models. The optional ten-speaker audio system yields in SRT models to the nineteen-speaker Harman Kardon orchestra. Given the performance potential and value equation, it’s hard to think of a direct competitor for the Charger, and owners can always brag about their edge over much more expensive cars.

New for 2015

The 707-horsepower, Charger SRT Hellcat, 485-horsepower SRT 392, R/T Scat Pack, eight-speed automatic transmission standard on all models, new wheels on all models.

More about the Dodge Charger

2014 Dodge Charger SXT Plus with video October 7, 2013

title: 2015 Lincoln MKC
subTitle: Late to the compact SUV party, but bringing some presents.
promoTeaserSmall: Late to the compact SUV party, but bringing some presents.
promoTeaser: Late to the compact SUV party, but bringing some presents.
metaDescription: 2015 Lincoln MKC: Late to the compact SUV party, but bringing some presents.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Base price: $33,995 (including destination)
This car: $40,675 (including destination )
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature:
Options I can’t live without: Technology package ($2,295): includes adaptive cruise control with collision warning and brake support
Notable standard features on this model: Heated front seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, remote start, reverse sensing, traction control, hill start assist, perimeter anti-theft system
Notable options on this model: Continuously controlled damping suspension ($650); daytime running lights and eighteen-inch premium painted wheels (part of Select Equipment group, $3,230); panoramic sunroof ($1,700); Blind spot monitoring with cross-traffic alert (part of Select Plus package, $1,100)
You might also be considering: 2016 Acura RDX ($36,190); 2015 Cadillac SRX ($38,600); 2015 Infiniti QX50 ($35,995) (all prices include destination charges)

The compact-sport-utility party has been raging for a couple of years now and shows no signs of abating, right on through 2020. Entry-level, hybrid, family-friendly, high-performance, luxurious, odd-looking—whatever your little heart may desire, you can find it. It’s a buyer’s market, no doubt.

This has not been helping the frayed nerves of Lincoln dealers who have been waiting (not so patiently) for brand-new vehicles to fill the showrooms after Ford deep-sixed Mercury in 2011 and left the cupboards bare. Slowly and perhaps a tad too conservatively, Lincoln has refreshed, redesigned, and relaunched six vehicles, four of which are crossovers or sport-utility vehicles.

The Lincoln home page has a big fat tab labeled FUTURE VEHICLES. Until the 2016 MKX and Continental concept pop out of that folder and into dealerships, the 2015 MKC luxury compact crossover remains the news.
There are less expensive, more performance-oriented, more luxurious models, which makes it all the harder to be heard. Still, the all-new MKC has come bringing presents.

This is one tough category in which to trumpet your claim as the new, improved Lincoln. You can be all the New! and Improved! you want and still find you need to elbow your way into the crowd. There are less expensive, more performance-oriented, and more luxurious models, which makes it all the harder to be heard. Still, the all-new MKC has come bringing presents.

The Good:

Exterior design. The MKC cuts a fine figure, one of the most striking in the category, with the Mazda CX-5 and the Volvo XC60 its strongest competitors in terms of looks. It’s the best use yet of the Lincoln winged grille, which disappears altogether on the truly exciting Lincoln Continental Concept unveiled at the 2015 New York Auto Show. The MKC grille takes your eye along the leading edge of the hood, across its Angry Bird headlamps and straight into a deeply creased shoulder line that disappears and reappears as it passes the rear wheel. The doors have a deep concavity that is anchored by a lower sill between front and rear wheel wells, and tied visually to the front end’s lower grille. No matter where you’re standing, the MKC will catch your eye. In a good way.

Gorgeous leather. Although it was hard at night to actually see in our test car’s unrelenting black interior, the stitching is superb. Especially striking are the crossing arc patterns on the door inserts. Without the $1,700 panoramic sunroof, it would be difficult to see in daylight, too. I’d recommend Lincoln’s chic blend of Cream leather with Hazelnut or Ganache Truffle trim instead of boring black. Actually, I’d prefer to eat a box of creamy hazelnut ganache truffles.

Fashion sense. If you question your own, the Lincoln configurator offers the Black Label option, giving you four thematic scenarios: Oasis, Indulgence, Modern Heritage, and Center Stage. (I wouldn’t tell anyone that I used it.) Center Stage comes closest to the feel of our test car, although the Black Label interiors are a generous step above in quality of materials and saturation of color, in keeping with its extra large price tag. Yes, the Black Label’s all-in price of $47,100 kind of grabs you in the throat, doesn’t it? But the long list of included features is outstanding, and Black Label member privileges include premium maintenance, annual vehicle detailing, “anytime” car wash, and remote service pickup and delivery.

Rides like a dream. It certainly helps that our MKC had among its four optional items a control damping suspension worth every one of its $650. It rode like a magic carpet, turned on a dime, and behaved like you’d want all crossovers to behave—like a luxury car.

Technology. The basic MKC comes with a rearview camera. Whenever the newest and most sophisticated safety technologies are available, I say buy them. Blind spot monitoring with cross-traffic alert is the most important part of our car’s Select Plus package, priced at $1,100. I would add the Technology package ($2,295) to get adaptive cruise control with collision warning and brake support. Then there are forward sensing and lane keeping assist, just to remind you that someday, you won’t have to drive at all. Active park assist is also included in the Technology package. It’s brilliant; if you haven’t tried it, you should. Truly magic.

The Decent:

Efficient engines. My tester had the base engine, a turbocharged 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder with six-speed automatic transmission. It makes an adequate 240 horsepower with no drama, but the optional 2.3-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder’s extra 45 horsepower would certainly brighten any MKC owner’s day. The more powerful engine comes with all-wheel drive as part of the $7,045 upcharge over the front-wheel-drive 2.0-liter MKC, and fuel economy drops a tiny bit.

Push-button transmission. Between the right side of the instrument panel and the center console is a vertical row of large push buttons. That would be your push-button start/stop, followed by the transmission gear selector buttons. The very idea of this gear selector was controversial in our offices, but I got used to it quickly. The start-stop button began life at the bottom of the stack until it was discovered that drivers were pushing it by mistake while shifting. The MKC was recalled by Ford to reposition start/stop, which is now at the top where it belongs.

The Not So Much:

Black as an interior color. It’s impossible to see anything when everything is black. Why would anyone but a livery driver spec out a car this way when there are really tasteful combinations of cream and browns to blend with several choices of woods, including open-pore veneers? The black-striped, open-pore wood trim in our test car hinted at what is possible to find in the Lincoln interior design book. (Let the aforementioned Black Label option guide you.)

Sync is not winning any awards. After its multiple updates to make it work better, the Ford Sync infotainment system is now drab to look at. It’s easier to use, but with a recalcitrant phone operator that couldn’t decipher my Midwest twang and refused to make any calls for me unless I barked out the actual phone number, one digit at a time. My husband’s cell phone number is the only one I know by heart.
Matthew McConaughey. You can watch the incongruous MKC ads starring this once-respected actor at www.lincoln.com. You can find the pitch-perfect Ellen DeGeneres sendup here.

The Verdict:

The MKC takes Lincoln much closer to its goal of being the life of the luxury party. Designers have broken whatever fog they’ve been in, delivering stronger, more modern shapes and impressive interiors. Materials are first rate, and safety technology is a leading story. Rethink Sync, and we’ll break out the good champagne.

title: 6 Tips for a Successful Vacation Drive
subTitle: Timing is everything. Here's how to set the pace in your driving days on the road.
promoTitle: 6 Tips for a Successful Vacation Drive
promoTeaserSmall: Timing is everything. Here's how to set the pace in your driving days on the road.

keywords: 6 Tips for a Successful Vacation Drive
metaTitle: 6 Tips for a Successful Vacation Drive - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Timing is everything. Here's how to set the pace in your driving days on the road.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: My strategy for a road trip may be totally different from yours, but it works for me.

Having done my share of big drives, I’ve found 500 to 600 miles per day is about right for a pleasant experience, especially among a group. My goal is to exceed the daily average distance managed in North Africa by George Patton’s infantry without even contemplating the circuit record of 3,362 miles in the 24 Hours of Le Mans, set in 2010 by Audi.  Of course, it’s possible to go farther. But after any more than ten hours in even the greatest car, each minute becomes increasingly unbearable.

Variables can affect my formula: speed limits, unwelcome weather events, seasonal daylight variations, and urban congestion or a blocked highway. But over the years the outline has held up well enough. Here are the basics:

1. Early departure.

An experienced road-tripper friend eats a large meal at the hotel (“Free breakfast included!”) and loads up with fruit and yogurt for the car. On the other hand, I fill the gas tank before sunrise and hit the highway with an energy bar. It’s possible to knock down more than 100 miles while there’s little traffic. Around 9 a.m., I stop for a real breakfast that doesn’t entail pseudo-eggs and semi-lethal coffee.

2. Two-hour blocks.

Most folks remain seated two hours for a movie. Why not the same in a car? At 70 mph, there’s another 140 miles behind you. Then, a stop—try to keep it under ten minutes—to use the restroom, stretch the legs, and someone please walk Fido. “It gives kids a chance to wake up from their electronic coma,” says AAA of Southern California spokesperson Marie Montgomery.

3. Minimal lunch break.

I try to avoid a dedicated lunch stop. Instead, pass around sandwiches, nuts, and fruit. (When alone in the car, my lunch is sometimes an early afternoon milkshake from a drive-through.) A big midday repast affects alertness.

4. Teamwork.

We’re all in this together, from packing bags to route planning. Whether it’s a group of friends or cohesive family unit, everyone shares the same brief. Forgo that superjumbo drink, because we’ll have a stop in forty minutes just for you, throwing the team goal out the window. Be like an astronaut and wait for the space station. Teamwork also includes switching drivers to keep everybody fresh.

5. Side trip.

Congratulations! As long as we’ve exercised self-discipline and made great progress (for example, clearing the large metro area on today’s route before rush hour), there’s twenty minutes available for a scenic overlook or roadside attraction. “Customize your route based on what’s around,” says Montgomery. “If it’s not too far out of the way, why not?”

6. Target locked.

Yes, the summer day is long. But I want to check in to the hotel, which was reserved in advance, by about 5:30 p.m. Doing so brings the opportunity to answer email or splash in the pool. My experienced road-tripper friend jokingly suggests affixing flank steaks to the radiator grille so dinner will be ready upon arrival. But most people prefer to gather for leisurely dining to compensate for the day’s deprivations.

Conclusion:

Following these points avoids the unpleasantness of dragging in well after dark, grimy and worn, like Patton’s army. By dividing the journey into manageable segments, even those who have physical issues or short attention spans can experience the pleasure of long-distance car travel.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive mid-size sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $24,995–$38,165 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SLE-1, SLE-2, SLT-1, SLT-2, and Denali
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 301 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.4-liter, FWD: 23 mpg city/32 mpg highway; 2.4-liter, AWD: 20/29 mpg; 3.6-liter, FWD: 17/24 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 16/23 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: 4G LTE with Wi-Fi hot spot
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Rear-seat entertainment system available in the SLT-2
You might also be considering: Ford Edge, Hyundai Santa Fe Sport, Mitsubishi Outlander

This popular compact SUV is an entry level to what GMC calls its “professional grade design.” The result is a tough-looking vehicle with an oversized grille and squared-off edges. Inside, the Terrain is practical but loaded with available technology like a 7-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, music streaming capability, and Siri Eyes Free. OnStar with 4G LTE and standard built-in Wi-Fi hotspot is standard in 2015. The antenna is built into the Terrain’s body for a better connection than your phone and it can connect up to seven devices in or near the car, making road trip boredom a thing of the past. The Terrain’s Denali edition adds a chrome grille, body-color front fascias, and unique 18-inch wheels. Contrast stitching, a soft-touch instrument panel, and smoked mahogany wood accents dress up the cabin.

The crew will be comfy in the back, too. The MultiFlex rear seat system lets you easily arrange the back to suit your passengers or cargo. It splits 60/40, reclines, and slides almost eight inches, giving rear-seat passengers almost 40 cubic inches of legroom. Dual 8-inch flip-up LCD screens will keep that crew amused—even playing video games if that’s what it takes. Terrain is offered in front-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive models.

New for 2015

OnStar with 4G LTE and a Wi-Fi hotspot. Two new exterior colors: Dark Sapphire Blue Metallic and Cypress Green Metallic.

More about the GMC Terrain

2016 GMC Terrain Denali: Designer Walkaround April 20, 2015

Notable options on this model: Satellite-linked navigation system
You might also be considering: Hyundai Veloster, Mini Cooper Coupe, Scion tC, Volkswagen Beetle

Why can’t a sports car also be an economy car? That’s the question this little number tries to answer. It looks undeniably sporty. It comes with a six-speed manual transmission, and it has a Sport mode that offers more power and enhanced handling. Transmission choices are sporty, too; in addition to the manual, there's a continuously variable transmission (CVT) with paddle shifters. But then there is its alternate personality: the CR-Z has an electric motor and an Econ mode to take advantage of that motor. Yes, this is a hybrid, and an affordable one at that. It also sports some sweet technology, appropriately since it's aimed at the youth market, delivering text messages to the in-dash touchscreen, connecting your phone, playing your own Pandora channel, and letting you take calls through the car’s sound system.

New for 2015

The CR-Z is unchanged for 2015.
