You might also be considering: Audi A8, BMW 7 Series, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

Step inside a Jaguar XJ, and you’ll find yourself surrounded by the trappings of British luxury—premium leather, bold sweeps of wood trim, and a jewel-like analog clock modeled after prestige wristwatches, among other high-end touches. Compared with its more austere and clinical German rivals, the cabin of the XJ is a feast for the senses. But the XJ is not only about luxury. Based on a lightweight aluminum vehicle architecture and powered by supercharged V-6 or V-8 engines ranging from 340 to 550 horsepower, the XJ can be driven with the kind of verve that you might not expect from a full-size luxury sedan.

There are six trim levels and two body lengths, normal (XJ) and long wheelbase (XJL), the latter of which affords more rear-seat room and allows for a true chauffeur-driven experience. However, even the “base” XJ isn’t lacking in either luxury or performance. Its supercharged V-6 hardly feels underpowered, and all-wheel drive is a useful option (and one that can only be had with the V-6). However, if power is your thing, either of the supercharged V8s will deliver it in spades.

All XJs have JaguarDrive Control, through which the driver can select a setting that adjusts the engine response, transmission shifts, and dynamic stability control intervention. There are three drive modes: Normal, for everyday driving; Dynamic, for a more sporting character; and Winter, which enhances handling in low-grip conditions.

The XJ has a long list of standard options, including automatic stop/start for enhancing fuel economy, a rearview camera, a blind-spot monitor, and soft-close doors. An 8-inch touchscreen display for accessing the climate controls, audio, and navigation systems also comes standard. It is serviceable but is not as advanced or intuitive as the systems in the XJ’s luxury competitors.

Despite that last niggle, it’s hard to argue against the XJ, a sedan that delivers luxury accommodations and a dose of driving panache.

New for 2015

There are no mechanical changes to the XJ for 2015.

More about the Jaguar XJ

2015 Jaguar XJL Portfolio AWD April 28, 2015
Why Paul Loves His 2002 Jaguar XJ May 28, 2014

title: 2015 Lexus LX570
subTitle: Luxury goes big and brawny.
promoTeaserSmall: Luxury goes big and brawny.
promoTeaser: Luxury goes big and brawny.
metaDescription: Luxury goes big and brawny. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Eight-passenger, all-wheel-drive luxury sport-utility vehicle
Price: $84,105 (includes destination)
Trim level: LX570
Engine: 5.7-liter V-8, 383 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 12 mpg city/17 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Siri Eyes Free
Notable standard features on this model: Second-row power outlet, 120-volt outlet in the cargo area, power sliding second-row seats and power folding third-row seats
Notable options on this model: Dual-screen, rear-seat entertainment system that enables two video sources to be viewed at the same time on different screens
You might also be considering: Audi Q7, Cadillac Escalade, Land Rover Range Rover, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class

Looking for a vehicle to see you comfortably through the zombie apocalypse? You have found it. Big enough to seat everyone you want to save. Comfortable enough—with delicious niceties like four-zone climate control and heated seats—that you can all stay in the car no matter what comes. Plenty of power outlets to keep your computers, phones, and navigation equipment charges en route. And if you need to head off road to outwit your pursuers, this car can deal. Press a button and Crawl Control will keep an optimal slow and steady pace no matter the terrain. Turn Assist tightens your turning radius by adding brake force to the inside rear wheel. And Active Height Control and the Adaptive Variable Suspension systems work together to raise the vehicle up to three inches and adjust wheel articulation to better accommodate rough conditions. Or if things get really wild, select the type of terrain you need to navigate—Rock, Rock and Dirt, Mogul, Loose Rock or Mud and Sand—to optimize performance.

New for 2015

Siri Eyes Free, Slacker added to Lexus Enform App Suite.

title: 2015 Lexus NX
subTitle: A new luxury compact crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: A new luxury compact crossover.
promoTeaser: A new luxury compact crossover.
metaKeywords: 2015 Lexus NX; Lexus; SUV; crossover; hybrid; Japanese
metaDescription: A new luxury compact crossover. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle/crossover
Price range: $36,330–$43,160 (includes destination)
Trim levels: NX200t, NX200t F Sport, NX300h
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-four-cylinder, 235-horsepower; 2.5-liter four-cylinder/electric hybrid, 194 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 200t, AWD: 21 mpg city/28 mpg highway; 200t, FWD: 22/28 mpg; 300h, FWD: 33/30 mpg; 300h, AWD: 35/31 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Heated side mirrors with integrated LED turn signal lamps
Notable standard features on this model: HD Radio with Bluetooth audio, automatic phone book transfer, the ability to pause live radio for up to fifteen minutes
Notable options on this model: Wireless charging tray, lane-departure alert, pre-collision system, radar-based adaptive cruise control
You might also be considering: Acura RDX, Audi Q5, Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class

Let’s face it, there are a lot of boxy compact SUVs. Lexus set out to bring a bit of luxury styling to this segment. And this small, deluxe crossover is it. It comes in two versions. The NX200t with a turbocharged, 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine and the NX300h hybrid, which brings some seriously peppy driving, thanks to a new transmission and a split battery that distributes its weight evenly, also making for more cabin space.

That signature Lexus grille is extruded to an aggressive and distinctive front and the body ditches the box and embraces sleek aerodynamics instead. And, since this segment appeals to a sporty, young affluent buyer, the interior is loaded with sweet tech. It sports Lexus’ first Wireless Charging Tray so you can drop a compatible phones or device on it and pick up a charge without stopping to locate cables. You control the on board telematics system via the Lexus Remote Touch Interface—a touch pad. And the multi-information display screen features a Lexus-first G-Force meter and boost gauge.

That interior might feel—and look—like a luxury sports car. But it is also designed to hold all the stuff you want to carry. And it will keep you comfortable on your way to the mountains—or the sea. The front seats, inspired by sports car design, are available heated or heated and ventilated. And the safety tech in this car is state of the art: The available lane-departure alert system warns you if it thinks you are veering from a traffic lane. Intelligent high-beam automatically switches to low beam so you don’t accidentally blind other drivers—and switches back when there are no vehicles ahead are detected. The Pre Collision System uses the all-speed Adaptive Cruise Control system’s millimeter-wavelength radar sensor to detect vehicles and warn you and even apply the brakes to prevent or mitigate collisions.

New for 2015

The NX is an all-new vehicle for 2015.

title: 2016 Honda HR-V
subTitle: A small SUV with a big appetite for cargo. Should you buy it? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: A small SUV with a big appetite for cargo. Should you buy it? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: A small SUV with a big appetite for cargo. Should you buy it? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: A small SUV with a big appetite for cargo.

pageElements.text:
2016 Honda HR-V EX-L Navi

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive crossover
Price: $26,720 (includes destination charge)
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 141 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/32 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Artificial shift steps and paddle shifters for CVT
Options I can’t live without: All HR-V features are standard on this model
Notable standard features on this model: Seven-inch touchscreen with navigation, panoramic power sunroof, heated leather seats, push-button start
Notable options on this model: No optional equipment on this top-of-the-line trim level
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Kia Soul, Jeep Renegade, Mazda CX-3, Nissan Juke

Honda is respected in many design and engineering categories, but there’s one area where this company’s achievements regularly cause competitors to scratch their heads: packaging. Specifically, packaging that seems to defy the laws of the physical universe—more interior volume than the exterior dimensions could possibly support.
Think Hogwarts School of Interior Design. It's that magical.

The HR-V is Honda’s latest case in point. It’s the newest and smallest member of the company’s crossover/SUV lineup, which includes the CR-V and the Pilot, and it's also another player in the rapidly expanding marketplace of subcompact crossovers. It shares structural elements with the Fit hatchback, another paragon of interior design, but it’s considerably bigger. However, it's still smaller than the CR-V.

Bigger also applies to the HR-V’s interior, which offers 55.9 cubic feet of capacity with rear seats folded in the all-wheel-drive model I tested. Compare that with the 35.9 cubic feet in the Nissan Juke or the 48.4 cubic feet in the Buick Encore, for example. It is also roomy enough to accommodate a pair of good-size adults in the outboard rear seats. The center position, like all in this class, is sized for small people only.

While roominess is obviously a big plus for a vehicle’s versatility and comfort, other elements of the HR-V’s interior aren’t quite as compelling as its impressive volume. The materials measure up well in quality, but the color scheme seems to have been inspired by a stretch of fresh-laid asphalt. The Black on black on black look might be a little oppressive to some; for them, a gray interior is available with three of the eight exterior color choices.

The seats in our top-of-the line EX-L test car were reasonably adjustable, although it would be good if that adjustability extended to the lumbar support on the driver’s perch. There’s a little more lumbar than some lumbar regions might appreciate.

On the other hand, that driver’s seat is high and the dashboard relatively low, affording good forward sightlines. And in this top trim level, there are enough electronic goodies—navigation and HD satellite radio, for example—as well as leather upholstery. And speaking of radio, why touchscreen controls for volume and station selection were thought to be a good idea is a mystery. Nevertheless, there’s nary a knob in sight on the center stack controls of most trim levels; the LX is the exception.

The HR-V's 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine is shared with the Honda Civic family. Its output of 141 horsepower and 127 pound-feet of torque is a little tepid, making the 0-to-60-mph dash more of a deliberate trot. The continuously variable automatic transmission doesn’t help in hard acceleration, with its wheezing as the transmission works to catch up with the engine. Artificial shift points, seven of them, are programmed into the CVT’s manual mode, but for most of us an automatic transmission is a device to be employed in full auto—set and forget.

There is a manual transmission option, a six-speed, but it’s only available in the lower trim levels (LX and EX), and only with front-wheel drive. Beyond that, CVT models have significantly higher EPA fuel economy ratings: 28 mpg city, 35 mpg highway with front-wheel drive, versus 25/34 mpg for the manual version. All-wheel drive reduces the EPA score to 27/32 mpg.
Pricing is another attractive element in the HR-V story.The first rung on the ladder is just under $20,000 for the basic front-wheel-drive LX.

Speaking of scores, pricing is another attractive element in the HR-V story. The first rung on the ladder is just under $20,000 ($19,995) for the basic front-wheel-drive LX, climbing to our test subject, the EX-L Navi AWD, at $26,720. Between the two there’s the EX ($22,045), and the front-wheel-drive EX-L Navi ($25,470). Add $800 for CVT in LX and EX models, and $1,250 for all-wheel drive.

Surprisingly, for a vehicle that will see service with many young familes, the HR-V’s inventory of safety features doesn’t include a blind-spot monitor, forward collision alert, or lane departure warning, even as options. On the other hand, HR-Vs equipped with HD radio also include Honda’s Lane Watch system, which provides a center dash display of what’s happening on the right side of the vehicle when the driver engages the right turn signal. And all HR-Vs are equipped with a rearview camera.

The Verdict:

The HR-V isn’t the prettiest face in this class, nor can it be called peppy. And the CVT is definitely an acquired taste. But its combination of agility, fuel economy, interior volume, and attractive pricing make it a must-see for shoppers cruising this increasingly crowded class.

images.caption: Lane Watch rearview camera is standard on Honda's 2016 HR-V.

title: It's Here: The First Self-Driving Semi Truck
subTitle: Freightliner Inspiration has autonomous mode. My friends were nearly killed by a semi; I'm for it.
promoTitle: It's Here: The First Self-Driving Semi Truck
promoTeaserSmall: Freightliner Inspiration has autonomous mode. My friends were nearly killed by a semi; I'm for it.
promoTeaser: Freightliner Inspiration has autonomous mode. My friends were nearly killed by a semi; I'm for it.
keywords: It's Here: The First Self-Driving Semi Truck
metaTitle: It's Here: The First Self-Driving Truck - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Freightliner Inspiration has autonomous mode. My friends were nearly killed by a semi; I'm for it.

pageElements.text: If you spend any time at all on the highway, you've probably spent some time worrying whether the semi truck you're passing notices you or not. So here's some great news: the first autonomous truck has just seen the light of day. Don't be alarmed by the image you see here, showing a truck driver checking out an iPad while in a moving truck. This is actually good for road safety.

Daimler’s Freightliner Inspiration Truck is the first autonomous commercial heavy-duty truck with a license to operate on public roads. It made a dramatic debut this week, starring in a huge projection-screen event at the Hoover Dam. We're talking about a 420,000-square-foot image from 60 HD projectors.

I'll tell you why this is great news: because it can be scary out on the highway, and one of the scarier parts is if you're in a small passenger car, riding alongside a lot of massive semis and hoping they're paying attention.

I know this from sad experience. Two people I know, a young engaged couple, found themselves on I-94 in western Michigan, back in the summer of 2011. Their Honda Civic was stopped in a long line of traffic because of an accident farther ahead. Suddenly a semi truck hurtled up behind them, didn’t react in time to stop for the traffic jam, and the truck swerved and its trailer hit the Civic, blasting it to smithereens. My friends were grievously injured; doctors spoke the word “miracle” when they lived. And now, four years later, their recovery is ongoing. It’s actually amazing that they survived at all.
Suddenly a semi hurtled up behind them and didn’t react in time to stop. This is exactly the kind of accident that the Freightliner Inspiration truck could put an end to.

This is exactly the kind of accident that the Freightliner Inspiration Truck could put an end to. The technology on board the truck is called Highway Pilot, and the driver—who does remain in control at all times—can activate it to switch the truck into autonomous mode.

The Freightliner's Highway Pilot system uses some of the same technology already on board some Mercedes-Benz vehicles. It only works when the truck is on the highway. Highway Pilot uses a stereo camera, radar, adaptive cruise control, and lane keeping and collision prevention technology. The system can control the truck’s speed, steering, and braking. It won’t pass other vehicles, change lanes, or pull off at an exit, though; only the driver can do that.

Trucking companies are going to like this because it’s estimated to cut fuel usage by up to seven percent. Truckers should adapt well to it once  they realize it cuts fatigue and drowsiness. Daimler’s study indicates that drivers are 25 percent less drowsy if they are able to perform “interesting secondary tasks” like using an iPad while the truck operates autonomously during part of a highway trip.

My friend who was so seriously injured in the Honda Civic/semi truck accident, reacting to the news of this new technology, told me she wants to see "all that can be done to make trucks safer for all." She even points out that "if and when the truck situation is handled better, it will be better for this country's economy in many directions." Very generous statement from someone whose life was so seriously affected by human error.

And highway travelers like you and me? We should all be very excited that there will someday be much less risk of being hit by a truck out there.

Highway Pilot screen in the Freightliner Inspiration truck.
Interior of Freightliner Inspiration heavy-duty truck.
Freightliner Inspiration truck's big-screen debut at Hoover Dam.

title: Denise McCluggage, 1927-2015
subTitle: God's blessings are many, but one of his greatest to me was last weekend with Denise.
promoTeaserSmall: God's blessings are many, but one of his greatest to me was last weekend with Denise.
promoTeaser: God's blessings are many, but one of his greatest to me was last weekend with Denise.
metaDescription: God's blessings are many, but one of his greatest to me was last weekend with Denise.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Notes from friends:

“My heart is broken, I always felt Our Darling Denise would be with us forever. The day I met Phil, I met Denise, and it has always been a wonderful friendship, such a brain, such humor and goodness. I always loved being in her presence.” —Alma Hill, widow of racing driver Phil Hill

“Where is everybody we have known? Gone to join their friends in the pit lane in the sky? How very sad to get the news about Denise, a brave girl to the end. Dan is trying to digest the news. He and Denise go way back, as you know: Europe, Ferrari, Le Mans, the 'Ring, the late Fifties, Modena. We will miss her! She was a true original and a kind and witty friend.” —Evi Gurney, wife of racing driver Dan Gurney

"Denise McCluggage was a true original, the way she wrote, the way she talked, the way she behaved and the way she lived her life, nothing was ordinary.

"We have been friends ever since she and her great friend Phil Hill picked me up at the airport in Paris in 1958 to drive south to Le Mans together where we all were scheduled to race. Denise was a pioneering racing lady who was not intimidated by famous men on the track, be it the Nurburgring, Sebring, Riverside, or the Targa Florio. She amused generations with her witty observations which she shared in her writings over many decades. I see her in my mind's eye laughing with old pals Briggs, Phil, Shelby, and Stirling. We were young together, we grew old together, I will miss you Denise!" —Dan Gurney
“DENISE WAS A FAST, FUNNY, FABULOUS FEMALE. A GREAT LADY AND WONDERFUL FRIEND.” —Sir Stirling Moss

We all knew things were bad when Denise canceled the Amelia Island Concours weekend in March, where she’d been a judge for umpteen years. Amelia is small enough that she could connect with all her old racing friends from back in the day—Stirling and Susie Moss, Phil and Alma Hill, Dan and Evi Gurney, Coco and Jacqueline Chinetti. She was sick—she had a tumor in her left kidney that her doctor guessed was malignant.
“I was too healthy for too long,” Denise wrote me, “so all this is new and troublesome.”
She weighed the risks of surgery, didn’t like them, and decided not to do anything about it. She stayed home in Santa Fe, and her friends around the globe worried.

It was impossible to communicate with Denise by phone because she couldn’t hear, and her hearing aids were so miserable. It had her musing that she should have listened to Jacky Ickx and worn earplugs when she was racing. Instead, everyone made fun of him, she told me. She also didn’t much like Facebook because she couldn’t figure out what sort of relationship she was having or was supposed to be having with the people who tried to correspond with her there. But she loved a good email exchange.

Her email about the kidney cancer started the nagging feeling that I had to get down to Santa Fe (which might as well be Mars, it's so far from Michigan). I told myself I could wait for the Santa Fe Concorso in September. And then Paul Russell, renowned auto restorer and longtime friend of Denise's, asked me to give a speech at an auto restoration school in McPherson, Kansas. It sounded closer to Santa Fe than coming from Michigan, so I got the idea to go down there. I told Paul, and he immediately said he would go with me.
"I’m not good company," she wrote. "But I love good company." Her special humor and wit had not diminished.

She was counting on it for two weeks, and then the day before we were to leave, she went into the hospital with pneumonia. She emailed me from the hospital. “Antsy to see you guys.” We knew we would not change plans.

Miraculously, as our plane was touching down on Saturday, May 2, she made it back home. She was pretty beat up, but sitting out on her patio ("Tuscany," she called it), and we had a lovely visit. Beverly and Dennis Little, her guardian angels in Santa Fe, came over with ribs and great salads, and we set up in the dining room.
Denise began telling stories, one after another, packed with all her little witticisms that made her eyes sparkle in that way.

And Denise began telling stories, one after another, packed with all her little witticisms that made her eyes sparkle in that way, and made her giggle in the middle of the story the way she always did, like she was so amused by her thoughts right before she shared them. Her humor was so pure and light and made you feel so happy and good to be in that bubble.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/k-vATMnDyPc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

She wore me out! I thought I was going to have to put my head on the table. It was like the time Porsche design chief Tony Lapine and I went to visit Madame Junek in Prague right after the Berlin Wall fell. She stood rooted to the floor in one spot and talked about her life for four hours without faltering as first I, and finally Tony, collapsed into chairs when our stamina ran out.

I never wanted that night in Santa Fe to end, and yet Paul and I felt kind of bad that we didn't leave early and let her rest. He was sitting across from her and told me that he kept looking at her and thinking, "This woman is almost ninety, she has pneumonia, and yet she sounds great, and even her color looks pretty good."

We took doughnuts over on Sunday morning before we left  and found her on her patio in Tuscany, wearing a sweatshirt that read, "With age comes oldness." Her teapot was a ceramic car and the lid was the racing driver's head. She was very frustrated that she wasn't herself. She said, "I have to keep telling myself that I'm sick. I have pneumonia. It feels terrible. That's why they spell it that way. So you can't look it up and see how bad it is." We laughed and she laughed.
We really had to tear ourselves away to catch the plane. And that’s how we left her. Yesterday, only three days later, I heard from Beverly that Denise had passed away at 18:18.
God's blessings are many, but one of his greatest to me was last weekend with Denise in Tuscany.

images.caption: An iconic Denise photo of Stirling Moss, out of gas.
With Denise, humor was never too far from the surface.
It was the best evening! Paul Russell and me with Denise.
Paul Russell, Denise, and me sharing a sunny Sunday afternoon.
Folk art: Wood log cars with racing animals.
Denise's artful juxtaposition of art objects.
More of Denise's collection of curios.
Denise admired folk art and filled her home with it.
Tuscany and its beautiful inhabitant, may she rest in peace.
The always entertaining Denise McCluggage at home in Santa Fe, Saturday night, May 2, 2015.

title: 2015 Nissan Altima
subTitle: The bestseller.

promoTeaser: The bestseller.

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $23,125–$33,175 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 2.5, 2.5 S, 2.5 SV, 2.5 SL, 3.5 SL
Engines: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 2.5-liter: 27 mpg city/38 mpg highway; 3.5-liter: 22/32 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Four-inch LCD instrument panel display
Notable standard features on this model: Premium shock absorbers, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, pushbutton start, air conditioning, dual chrome exhausts, Bluetooth connectivity
Notable options on this model: NissanConnect with Navigation and Mobile Apps, 7.0-inch color display, satellite radio, leather upholstery, 9-speaker audio, 8-way power driver’s seat, 4-way power front-passenger’s seat, heated front seats and steering, wheel, paddle shifters, active understeer control, moving object detection, blind-spot and lane-departure warning, 17- and 18-inch wheels
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Kia Optima, Toyota Camry

Outstanding aerodynamic design and classy details characterize the midsize Nissan Altima. This five-passenger sedan is Nissan’s bestseller, and we know why. It combines good performance—including an athletic ride, thanks to premium shock absorbers—with great fuel economy and high feature content. For example, every Altima has scientifically developed “Zero Gravity” front seats to reduce fatigue, so there’s no “claim to lame.” There’s also a customizable 4.0-inch driver information display that relates audio system or fuel economy data, among other topics. The interior, where quietness is emphasized, is a pleasant, well-designed place with tasteful colors, fabrics, textures, and finishes. The standard 4-speaker sound system can be upgraded to the premium 9-speaker one. Standard Bluetooth connectivity enables hands-free calling and wireless streaming from your smartphone. The popular Altima SV comes with dual-zone climate control, hands-free texting, and leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel. Sophisticated active safety technology is available, with blind-spot and lane-departure warning and moving object detection being bundled with the available Technology Package. The newly available active understeer control lightly brakes the inside front wheel as needed for more effective turning. Under the hood is either a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine or a 3.5-liter V-6, and every model has a continuously variable automatic transmission. The 3.5 SL has paddle shifters with a manual shift mode.

New for 2015

Additional standard infotainment, safety technologies, and improved fuel economy for the 3.5 SL, smart climate control for cars equipped with remote start, Special Edition package includes convenience and infotainment features.

Our favorite standard feature: Smart key with pushbutton start
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth connectivity, multifunction leather-trimmed steering wheel, cruise control, heated front and rear seats, heated leather-wrapped steering wheel, regenerative braking, rearview camera, 16-inch steel wheels, power-operated heated side mirrors, traction and stability control
Notable options on this model: Hands-free texting, 17-inch alloy wheels, high-capacity 6.6-kW onboard charger, quick-charge port, Pearl White paint, automatic LED low-beam headlamps, fog lamps, leather upholstery, navigation, Carwings smartphone app for remote system monitoring and feature activation, rear spoiler solar panel, 360-degree monitor, premium audio
You might also be considering: BMW i3, Chevrolet Volt, Toyota Prius

A friend recently traded his first-generation Nissan Leaf for the second-generation model that was introduced two years ago, so we asked him to describe the electric car’s virtues. He says, “The new Leaf is basically maintenance free and easy to live with. There’s quick acceleration at traffic speeds with no pesky downshifting. It has much better charging (faster) than the first generation, and the heat is much more efficient.” The Leaf seats five and, with the 60/40 split rear seat folded, up to 30 cubic-feet of cargo space. With an 84-mile range, the Leaf is effective as a commuter vehicle. It operates quietly. After applying benefits like tax incentives and access to the freeway’s diamond lane, the Leaf is less expensive, with greater added value, than you might think, especially because it never visits the gas pump. A quick-charge port allows recharging the lithium-ion battery pack to 80-percent level in 30 minutes with a fast charger. Only five hours is needed to achieve a full charge. In addition to being quiet to drive, the Leaf has a high level of standard. There’s a smart key with pushbutton start, a heated multifunction steering wheel and heated front and rear seats, and a rearview camera. Three driving modes are included: Normal, Eco-Mode, B-Mode, which has stronger regenerative braking capability to generate current. One other tip from our friend: the top-of-the-line SL with all the goodies can be a great deal because most buyers are frugal and economical.

New for 2015

Morning Sky Blue paint, hands free texting in SV and SL, new 17-inch alloy wheels for SV trim.

subTitle: The design edge.
promoTeaserSmall: The design edge.
promoTeaser: The design edge.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan Quest; Nissan; minivan; van; Japanese
metaDescription: The design edge. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 7-passenger, front-wheel-drive minivan
Price range: $27,415–$44,065
Trim levels: S, SV, SL, Platinum
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 260 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small overlap front: Poor; Moderate overlap front, Side, Head restraints and seats: Good; Roof strength: Acceptable; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Smart keyless entry with pushbutton start
Notable standard features on this model: Fold-flat second and third rows, rear storage well, rear spoiler
Notable options on this model: Roof rack, towing package, hatch tent, 18-inch wheels, tinted glass, HID headlamps, dual sunroof, power sliding side doors, 5-, 7-, or 8-inch color audio display, blind spot warning, rearview camera, 360-degree view with moving object detection
You might also be considering: Dodge Caravan, Honda Odyssey, Toyota Sienna

Distinctive, modern styling makes the Nissan Quest stand out from the crowd. Under a firm canopy that ends with a jabbing spoiler, there’s a wraparound expanse of tinted glass that makes this minivan an observation platform. A character line rises boldly along the flank to meet the tail lamp. While the visual drama rises, Nissan boasts a low step-in height to the seven-passenger cabin. The occupants are well outfitted with safety features, including side-curtain airbags and stability and traction control, and accouterments like standard second- and third-row climate controls and an available rear entertainment system with 11-inch screen. The versatility of second-row seats is exemplary. Sliding, reclining, and then folding flat with one pull are hallmarks of the second row. The 60/40 third row flattens out with one tug of a strap or, in the Quest Platinum, the push of a button. The rear storage well is a Quest feature. Over-the-road performance is respectable thanks to the 260-horsepower V-6 and continuously variable transmission, which enables towing of up to 3,500 pounds. Amenities include Nissan’s Quick Comfort front seat heaters that initially warm thigh and hip areas before spreading heating to other points. (Naming this feature “The Bum’s Rush” seemed a bad idea.) And Quest boasts a hatch tent. This dealer-installed option connects a roomy a screen tent to the rear hatch for insect-free tailgating.

New for 2015

Quest LE is now Quest Platinum, revised transmission settings, and improved fuel economy.

Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small front overlap: Poor; Moderate overlap front, Side, Roof strength, Head restraints and seats: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity
Notable standard features on this model: Air-conditioning, speed-sensitive electrically assisted power steering, 2-speaker audio system, programmable hands-free calling with voice recognition, 15-inch wheels, stability control
Notable options on this model: Continuously variable transmission, smart key with pushbutton start, hands-free voice activation, NissanConnect with Navigation and Mobile Apps, satellite radio, rearview monitor, variable intermittent wipers, 6-way manually adjustable driver’s seat with arm rest, fog lamps, power-adjustable side mirrors, rear spoiler, 16-inch alloy wheels
You might also be considering: Hyundai Accent, Kia Rio, Mitsubishi Lancer

The Nissan Versa demonstrates that cheap doesn’t necessarily mean nasty. Even for less than $13,000—there are whole lot of motorcycles that cost twice as much—the Versa is equipped with a reasonable level of standard equipment, and this year Bluetooth hands-free calling is added to the list. For no extra charge, the Sentra received quite a makeover for 2015. The front now has larger headlamps and a chrome grille that reinforces the subcompact sedan’s relationship to its larger siblings in the Nissan lineup. Blacked-out B-pillars on the Versa SV and SL models improve the profile view, and a new stinger antenna sits on the roof. Nissan says the rear is more dynamic; we note the new taillamps. The body is highly aerodynamic body, and with the available continuously variable automatic transmission the Versa realizes 40 highway mpg, which is better than a whole lot of motorcycles. Inside the car, updates include a reshaped center stack, a multifunction steering wheel, and new upholstery. The more premium SV has an outside temperature display, and the SL comes with a smart key and pushbutton start and rearview monitor. So it’s obvious, the interior is pretty nice, unlike a whole lot of motorcycles.

New for 2015

Hands-free calling with voice recognition, revised front and rear styling, restyled center stack, and available Graphite Blue and Amethyst Gray paint.

subTitle: Aging gracefully.

Type: Seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $30,865–$37,505 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 273 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2WD: 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway; AWD: 16/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small overlap front: Poor; Moderate overlap front: Good; Side impact: Good; Roof strength: Moderate; Head restraint and seats: Moderate; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth hands-free phone and audio connectivity
Notable standard features on this model: Three-zone automatic climate control, cruise control, power windows and door locks, Bluetooth, 5.8-inch touchscreen
Notable options on this model: Navigation, rear-seat entertainment system, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Buick Enclave, Chevrolet Traverse, Honda Pilot, Hyundai Santa Fe, Toyota Highlander

Mazda describes the CX-9 crossover as the “elder statesman” of its lineup, which might be interpreted as an acknowledgment that an update is past due. Built on the platform of the previous-generation Ford Edge and not redesigned since its 2007 debut, the Mazda CX-9 is nevertheless a viable three-row alternative to a minivan. With 139.4 cubic feet of total passenger volume, the cabin is spacious enough for seven passengers to ride in relative comfort. Or, if you need to haul cargo rather than people, it’s easy to fold the multi-configurable second and third rows flat, resulting in a generous 100.7 cubic feet of cargo space.

Despite its age, the CX-9 looks modern and sporty, thanks to a face-lift a couple of years ago. And, like every vehicle from the “zoom zoom” carmaker, the CX-9’s styling is matched by its handling, with agility and precision that are uncommon for this class of vehicle. The only engine is a refined 3.7-liter V-6 that produces a generous 273 horsepower. That power is put to the ground through a smooth and responsive six-speed automatic transmission.

Any of the three trim levels—Sport, Touring, and Grand Touring—can be specified with either front- or all-wheel drive and come well equipped. Options include such items as a touch-screen navigation system, a rearview camera, heated seats, and an eleven-speaker audio system. The cabin is well made but not remarkable and the 5.8-inch screen is a bit small for such a large vehicle, but wind noise is kept to a minimum, making this crossover a great long-distance highway cruiser.

New for 2015

The CX-9 carries over from 2014 with only two changes: a new accessories package and a new paint color called Titanium Flash Mica.

title: 2016 Mazda CX-5 Grand Touring AWD
subTitle: From those smart folks who brought you the Miata, a sports car that lets you bring the family along.

promoTeaser: From those smart folks who brought you the Miata, a sports car that lets you bring the family along.
metaDescription: From those smart folks who brought you the Miata, a sports car that lets you bring the family along.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive crossover/SUV
Base price: $30,350 (including destination charge)
This car: $34,140 (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sport mode
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/30 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, dynamic stability control, traction control, leather-wrapped steering wheel, push-button start, nine-speaker Bose audio, seven-inch touchscreen display
Notable options on this model: Soul Red paint ($300), Grand Touring i-Activsense package ($1,500), includes radar cruise control, smart brake support, lane departure warning; Grand Touring Tech package ($1,505), includes navigation, LED lights, smart city brake support
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges): 2015 Ford Escape Titanium 4WD ($33,085); 2015 Honda CR-V Touring AWD ($33,775); 2015 Toyota RAV4 Limited AWD ($30,735); 2015 Volkswagen Tiguan S with 4Motion ($29,095)

Does the thought of yet another compact crossover make you tired? Well, feast your eyes on the sculptured flanks of the 2016 Mazda CX-5 and see if that doesn’t help you get your strength back. This small SUV carries the Mazda zoom-zoom philosophy into what is otherwise a pretty utilitarian corner of the auto world.

Crossovers and SUVs are a very popular category, and rightly so: they can just do more than sedans, and people want to multitask these days. The Mazda CX-5 elbows for your attention, crossover buyer, alongside such huge sellers as the Toyota RAV4, the Honda CR-V, and the Ford Escape.
Like them, the CX-5 has generous space for five people and/or a lot of gear or groceries. Like them, it sits high up off the ground, SUV style, with an impressive complement of safety technology.

But here’s where the CX-5 stands out: its light weight, rigid structure, and lovely 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine (in total, part of Mazda’s suite of Skyactiv technologies) make it a fairly sporting beast to drive, too.
It was the first Mazda to use the crouching-predator look that the automaker calls its KODO Soul of Motion design language. As such, it was already gorgeous.

This is the all-new version of the CX-5, which first came out in 2012. It was the first Mazda to use the crouching-predator look that the automaker calls its KODO Soul of Motion design language. As such, it was already gorgeous. Now, the 2016 model gets a new grille and changes to the headlamps and taillamps, including optional LED lighting. A new set of nineteen-inch aluminum wheels further dresses up the crossover.

But looks and style are not necessarily the top criteria when you’re looking to buy a crossover vehicle. Practicality, fuel economy, and interior space are. That’s still good news for the Mazda CX-5, which does well in all three areas.

Both front- and all-wheel-drive versions are available. We tested the top-of-the-line Grand Touring model with all-wheel drive and the more powerful of two engine choices: a 185-horsepower 2.5-liter four-cylinder, teamed with a six-speed automatic transmission. There’s a lower Touring model, equipped with the 2.5-liter engine as well. You can also choose the CX-5 Sport, which has a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that makes 155 horsepower. With that model, you can choose from the automatic or a six-speed manual transmission. The latter choice will improve fuel economy to a truly impressive 35 mpg on the highway, a good achievement for a crossover.

I recommend the 2.5-liter engine, but I wish it had even a teensy bit more horsepower. Having said that, it’s enough, but just enough. No one here is complaining about fuel economy, though.
Even the top all-wheel-drive model with the more powerful engine, which we drove, attains 24 mpg in the city and 30 mpg on the highway (EPA estimates).  That’s on par with others in the segment that aren’t as interesting as daily drivers.

And speaking of driving, Mazda chose the CX-5 as the first to use its new Skyactiv technology, a holistic treatment that brings engine, transmission, suspension, and chassis into harmony for a smooth and responsive driving experience, or what the automaker likes to call “oneness of horse and rider.” If you’re used to the bouncy, jouncy feeling of riding in most SUVs, you’ll be pleasantly surprised at how poised and balanced the CX-5 feels, even on Michigan’s crappy spring roads—and how well it handles going fast. Having said that, it’s not the MX-5 Miata; you’ll still know you are in a crossover.

The interior was brightened by a new-for-2016 Parchment leather seating treatment. It’s a sea of black on black out there, especially in sport-utility vehicles, so this was a pleasant surprise. A couple of teenagers came along for the ride, tried out the back seats, and raved about their cushiness, which bodes well for using this as a family transporter.

Mazda packed the CX-5 Grand Touring model with safety technology: blind spot monitoring, a rearview camera, and rear cross-traffic alert are all standard. The optional i-Activsense package adds radar cruise control with smart brake support and lane departure warning ($1,500). Just a note about that lane departure warning, which was the most annoying safety feature I’ve seen lately—and I’ve tried out many of these systems on a variety of cars. If you get anywhere near an outside lane marker, the warning system emits an edgy rumble in the basso profundo register that makes you think there’s something wrong with your sound system—or your ears. I would never suggest turning off a safety feature, but.

A Grand Touring Tech package ($1,505) on our test CX-5 included smart brake support, which will brake for you if you’re going more than 10 mph and about to run into something. It also added a navigation system, plus a full set of LED lights: head- and taillights, daytime running lights, and fog lights.

You can get a Mazda CX-5 for as low as $22,675. That’s for the front-wheel-drive version, with a six-speed manual transmission and the 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine making 155 horsepower. That’s a lot of fun per dollar. The top version we tested was still under $35,000.

Mazda brought out this new CX-5 in a strong palette of nine colors, including the metallic Sonic Silver and the Titanium Flash Mica that’s also available on the Mazda 3. The Soul Red metallic paint color on the CX-5 we tested costs an extra $300 and is worth it.

The Verdict:

You have to go out and buy groceries, cart sacks of dirt home from the garden store, and take the kids to soccer practice. But why not go out to the driveway to do those things with a song in your heart? Some years ago, Mazda used the tagline “Always the soul of a sports car.” That’s what the Mazda CX-5 has to offer.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, two-door hatchback
Price: $20,164 (includes destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 179 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual transmission
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: 6.1-inch touchscreen audio
Notable standard features on this model: Panoramic tilt and slide moonroof, LED front bumper accent lighting, remote keyless entry, Bluetooth connectivity, Smart Stop technology
Notable options on this model: Only option is carpeted floormats and cargo mat ($184)
You might also be considering: 2015 Ford Focus SE Hatchback ($19,785); 2015 Hyundai Veloster ($18,825); 2015 Kia Forte Koup EX ($19,515); 2015 Mazda 3 iSport Five-Door ($19,765)

It is an interesting fact that people with the least money to spend on a car are often the people who are most excited about getting their hands on one. Luckily, there are a few reasonably priced choices for those people—young people, mostly. It’s for them that Toyota’s youth brand, Scion, makes the tC. This little three-door hatchback offers more driving fun than you might expect for $20,000.

You may not have noticed the tC out on the roads, and that would be understandable: it’s not flashy. In my mind, Scion has been all about the xB, the little boxy four-door that looks more like a treehouse than a car. That’s the one I always notice.

When I saw the 2015 Scion tC in the driveway, my first thought was, not too exciting. But after a longer look, I realized the tC has good bones and is very well put together. The corners have some real shaping that makes it more interesting on second look.

When I climbed inside, I was surprised how well trimmed it was. I like to guess the price of a car before I look at the sticker, so I guessed this one was going to cost closer to $25,000. That’s how good it looked inside. You’d expect a car with a price (including destination charge) of $20,164 to have a monochromatic and heavily plasticized interior, and you would be right because so many of them do. This one doesn’t. Toyota spent a lot of energy on the molding, the surfacing, and the shading of materials. The door trims are carved, with concave pieces that add shadow and light, not just straight black plastic. There’s a pebble-embossed dash trim that’s vaguely reminiscent of carbon fiber, adding depth and patterning. Plenty of entry-level cars have far less attention paid to making the most of inexpensive materials. It looks good here. The tC even has a leather-trimmed steering wheel, which tells you a lot about Scion’s focus on the driver.
Plenty of entry-level cars have far less attention paid to making the most of inexpensive materials.

Every part of the tC used by the driver to control the car—steering, clutch, shifter, brakes, and even seat—is as good as it can be. Our test car had a six-speed manual transmission that worked beautifully with the nice little buzz bomb of an engine, a 16-valve four-cylinder making 179 horsepower and 172 pound-feet of torque. It’s the same four-cylinder engine used in the Toyota Camry, but there is no way you’ll feel like you’re in a Camry behind the wheel of the tC. There’s a decent amount of power available from a stop as well as for merging onto the freeway or passing. It’s always more fun to drive a car with a stick, especially when the stick is as good as this one. The brakes (ventilated in front) and clutch work really well, making the tC a perfect car to use to teach someone—maybe even yourself—how to drive a manual.

Although it’s more on the sporty side, the tC is also a user-friendly car in that it has a reasonably sized back seat and front-wheel drive. (For a swoopier, more sporting rear-wheel-drive Scion, see the mid-$20,000s FR-S.) I climbed into the back seat, the ultimate test for a tall person like me. Thanks to a latch that flips the front seat up and pushes it forward, getting back there was easy, and once in place, I found that the seatbacks are carved out for more knee room. Getting back out was not as simple. Still, this is a back seat that could actually be used on a daily basis.

The Scion tC we tested was a base model with only one option: floor mats ($184). It occurred to me that, without these beautifully executed, thick carpeted mats, the tC would look a lot cheaper. There’s nothing fancy in here: no rearview camera, no push-button start. There is a panoramic sunroof with a latched shade that you operate manually--a clever money saver for Scion, and a boon to the the passengers who forgot to call shotgun.

The Verdict:

The tC makes a good entry-level car for college students or young professionals for another reason: safety. It has stability and traction control, brake force distribution that sends the ideal amount of braking to each of the four wheels, and brake assist. The 2015 tC earned the top five-star safety rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and the Top Safety Pick award from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

If you want something more distinctive, Scion is known for its limited-edition models, and the tC is no exception. The tC Release Series 9.0 is out now. It has a striking two-tone orange-and-black treatment with a center exhaust, a Cartel Customs aerodynamic kit, push-button start, and orange front seatbelts. Only 2,000 were made, priced at $23,960 (including destination charge).

You’ll also see the Scion tC all over the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) show in Las Vegas every October. It’s a tuner favorite for dressing up with custom paint jobs and body modifications. So, if you want to add a little more oomph to your tC, know that you’ll be able to find lots of aftermarket body parts and performance add-ons to make the tC your own personal project car.

title: 2015 Porsche Panamera
subTitle: The Porsche of luxury sedans.

promoTeaser: The Porsche of luxury sedans.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $79,095–$201,495 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Panamera, 4, S, 4S, 4S Executive, S E-Hybrid, GTS, Turbo, Turbo Executive, Turbo S, Turbo S Executive
Engines: 3.6-liter V-6, 310 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 420 horsepower; 3.0-liter V-6/electric hybrid, 416 horsepower; 4.8-liter V-8, 440 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.8-liter V-8, 520/570 horsepower
Transmissions: Seven-speed automatic, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Panamera: 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway; 4: 18/27 mpg; S/4S: 17/27 mpg; 4S Executive: 17/26 mpg; GTS: 16/24 mpg; S E-Hybrid: 25 combined/50 mpg-e combined; Turbo/Turbo Executive/Turbo S/Turbo S Executive: 15/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated by either NHTSA or IIHS
Our favorite standard feature: Front and rear parking sensors
Notable standard features on this model: Bi-xenon headlights, power liftgate, heated front seats, dual-zone automatic climate control, cruise control, automatic stop/start
Notable options on this model: Rearview camera, adaptive cruise control, lane change assist
You might also be considering: BMW 7 Series, Jaguar XJ, Mercedes-Benz S-Class, Tesla Model S

As with the Cayenne, purists scoffed at the idea of a Porsche sedan, but it didn’t take long to turn them into believers. With the handling of a sports car and the practicality of a sedan, the Panamera has cemented its spot in the Porsche model range.

The Panamera lineup is extensive, with no fewer than eleven trim levels. There are rear- and all-wheel-drive models, a plug-in hybrid, and normally aspirated and turbocharged engines. Oh, and there are three different long-wheelbase versions, too. Power ranges from 310 horsepower in the base version to a grin-inducing 570 horsepower in the Turbo S. A seven-speed PDK automatic is the transmission of choice in every Panamera save the S E-Hybrid, which uses the eight-speed Tiptronic S automatic.

The cabin of the Panamera is sumptuous and bears a strong resemblance to that of the 911, at least in the front seats. One thing the Panamera doesn’t have, which can be found in other luxury sedans, is a central controller for the multimedia system. Consequently, the center console is a button-rich environment that can be confusing at first glance. The rear seats are extraordinarily comfortable and supportive, and legroom, especially in the long-wheelbase Executive models, is plentiful. The thick rear pillars hamper rearward visibility somewhat, but options like a rearview camera and blind spot monitoring mitigate that problem.

As with every model in the Porsche lineup, there are lots of performance and appearance options. Peruse the list carefully, because it’s easy to get carried away and send the price skyrocketing.

New for 2015

The fastest, most powerful Panamera to date, the Turbo S, is new for 2015.

Competing against the established players in the compact car segment is tough, but the Elantra succeeds by relying on a combination of appealing style and efficient performance. Its fluid lines, graceful curves, and excellent proportions always create excitement, even though this fifth-generation version was introduced in 2011. The Elantra SE, Value Edition, and Limited have the 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine that produces 145 horsepower. The SE comes with a 6-speed manual transmission. The 6-speed automatic that’s optional here is standard in the Limited. The Elantra Sport and GT, on the other hand, have a 2.0-liter four-cylinder that produces 173 horsepower; the manual transmission is standard, the automatic, optional. All trims come well-equipped with heated side mirrors, remote keyless entry, cruise control, and air-conditioning.

If big, comfy, and Lincoln smooth is what’s on the menu and there are people and things that need to fit in there, here is the MKT. With room for seven and inflatable back seats to pamper the progeny, this is a road machine that will get your there calmly. Lincoln’s Drive Control manages all the elements of the MKT’s performance, from the adjustable suspension and electric power-assisted steering to the AdvanceTrac with roll stability control so you always get the control you need behind the wheel.
More power? The optional EcoBoost V-6 engine brings the horsepower to 365. And it won’t cost you much at the pump to get that power. The EcoBoost engine gets 16 miles per gallon in the city and 23 on the highway. You won’t just be comfy, either in here, you will be entertained and connected. The Sync with MyLincoln Touch system includes standard Operator Assist and local Wi-Fi hotspot so you can connect your laptops and tablets. And the available Navigation System is integrated with SiriusXM Traffic and SiriusXM Travel Link.

title: Volkswagen Microbus Returns as USB
subTitle: A Kickstarter campaign, with VW's blessing, aims to put the classic two-tone Samba on your desk.
promoTeaserSmall: A Kickstarter campaign, with VW's blessing, aims to put the classic two-tone Samba on your desk.
promoTeaser: A Kickstarter campaign, with VW's blessing, aims to put the classic two-tone Samba on your desk.
metaDescription: A Kickstarter campaign, with VW's blessing, aims to put the classic two-tone Samba on your desk.

pageElements.text: Of all the iconic cars in the world, perhaps the most popular with the widest variety of people is the Volkswagen Microbus. You don't have to be a diehard auto enthusiast to see its charm; maybe all you have to be is an old hippie, or an appreciator of clean design.
Sadly, you can't buy a real one these days, at least not new. But you can buy one with 32 GB of memory that fits into your computer, thanks to a new Kickstarter campaign.

The USB's design is based on the Volkswagen Samba, the classic two-tone bus from the Fifties and Sixties. The project, from a pair of auto designers in London, also includes sticky notes and 220-page notebooks imprinted with the VW image. Perhaps the coolest aspect of the USB is that the wheels come off in case you have a slim-line computer.

The two-person team, auto designer David Llop and graphic designer Nuria Enriquez, call their project USB Garage. They got a licensing agreement from Volkswagen to produce the USBs and related paper goods. They’re hoping to do the same so they can make other legendary vehicles including a 1963 Chevrolet Corvette, 1968 Mustang GT500 KR, and 1972 Porsche 911, if they can get the licensing deals set up.
The Kickstarter campaign estimates August for the start of worldwide deliveries. Check it out here.

images.caption: Sticky notes with the same VW Bus Theme.
Volkswagen-worthy design from the USB Design team.
Perhaps the coolest part is the view from underneath.

title: 2016 Honda Pilot
subTitle: Looking for a three-row SUV? Honda makes a case for best in class with the all-new Pilot.
promoTeaserSmall: Looking for a three-row SUV? Honda makes a case for best in class with the all-new Pilot.
promoTeaser: Looking for a three-row SUV? Honda makes a case for best in class with the all-new Pilot.
metaDescription: Looking for a three-row SUV? Honda makes a case for best in class with the all-new Pilot.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven- or eight-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Base price: $30,875 (Pilot LX with front-wheel drive, including destination charge)
This model: $47,300 (including destination charge)
Trim levels: LX, EX, EX-L, Touring, Elite
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 280 horsepower
Transmission: Nine-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Collision mitigation system
Option I can’t live without: Navigation (standard on Elite model)
Notable standard features on this model: Navigation with eight-inch touchscreen and voice recognition, power rear liftgate, panoramic power moonroof, LED headlights, heated and ventilated perforated leather front seats, heated perforated leather second row captain’s chairs, 540-watt ten-speaker premium audio, HD radio, second-row Blu-Ray DVD entertainment, forward collision warning and collision mitigation, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, adaptive cruise control
Notable options on this model: Elite is the top trim level; there are no options
You might also be considering: 2015 Dodge Durango Citadel ($41,990), 2015 GMC Acadia SLT-2 AWD ($45,945), 2015 Mazda CX-9 Grand Touring AWD ($37,505), 2015 Toyota Highlander Limited AWD ($42,435)

The Honda Pilot is the big kahuna of Honda’s crossover/SUV lineup. To those for whom the diminutive CR-V and HR-V aren’t quite enough, the Pilot fills the bill admirably. It has been a favorite among three-row family haulers since its 2003 introduction. The all-new 2016 model, the third generation, is likely to be even more popular.
Wraparound headlights, a slightly laid-back grille, and a steeper windshield angle conspire to make this people hauler more stylish, functional, and aerodynamic.

Every element of the Pilot is new, something that’s instantly visible. Honda went counterculture with the second generation, which had the truckish three-box styling of yesteryear. Although the Pilot sold well despite those chunky looks, the new one has smoother lines, especially up front, where the wraparound headlights, slightly laid-back grille, and steeper windshield angle conspire to make this people hauler more stylish, more functional, and more aerodynamic.

Almost nothing of the second-generation Pilot carries over into the new one. The 2016 edition, based on a platform shared with the Odyssey minivan, is bigger (1.8 inches longer at the wheelbase, 3.5 inches longer overall), distinctly roomier, and much quieter, regardless of road surface, including on gravel.

For 2016, the Pilot’s structural rigidity has increased substantially, according to Honda, an assertion that’s easy to credit after a half-hour behind the wheel; the new Pilot feels as solid as something hewn from a single ingot. The stiffened unibody is all the more remarkable at the scales, where the new Pilot weighs in as much as 286 pounds lighter, according to Honda, depending on trim level.

As with generation two, the redesigned Pilot is propelled by a 3.5-liter V-6. However, much of this engine is new, including its direct fuel injection system, and it delivers 280 horsepower and 262 pound-feet of torque, compared with 250 hp and 253 pound-feet in the previous engine. It achieves this on regular fuel and is rated by the EPA to burn less of it: 19 mpg city, 26 highway in our top-of-the-line Elite model with all-wheel drive, 20/27 mpg in the front-wheel-drive Elite.
Are paddle shifters a big plus in a family vehicle? Only you, the driver, can answer that question.

Those numbers also apply to Touring models. LX, EX, and EX-L versions are one mpg lower in their city ratings. The difference is attributable to transmissions. Lower trim levels are equipped with a six-speed automatic, replacing the previous five-speed. Touring and Elite models send power through a new nine-speed automatic that can be manually managed via paddle shifters. Are paddle shifters a big plus in a family vehicle? Only you, the driver, can answer that question.

In addition to improved efficiency, the combination of increased power and reduced weight add up to a sharp uptick in acceleration—some two seconds quicker to 60 mph, according to Honda. It also adds up to better passing times—less exposure out there in the left lane—particularly with the nine-speed automatic transmission.

There’s added space in the cabin, and indeed It feels much more accommodating in both front and rear. There’s more room for elbows, more room for cargo, and more of Honda’s usual inventive stowage for small objects. The top Elite model has captain's chairs in the second row, so it seats seven; all other Pilot models are eight-seaters. Interior materials are improved, with soft-touch surfaces, a much more contemporary-looking new dashboard, attractively legible instruments, and well-placed switches.

One asterisk: the new center stack and eight-inch display is devoid of anything resembling a button; everything is touchscreen, including the radio controls. Why this is better than an infotainment system with a judicious blend of knobs, switches, and touchscreen controls is a mystery.

On the other hand, the new nav system option is considerably more cooperative than that in the current Pilot, and in the top-of-the-line Elite model we tested, there’s a vast two-panel sunroof, something new for this vehicle. And there’s plenty of support for personal electronics in all but the basic LX model.

The base transmission is a six-speed automatic, found in LX, EX, and EX-L models. We tested the nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters, found in the top Touring and Elite models. These also come with a set of twenty-inch wheels. Spring rates are higher, minimizing body roll compared to the previous generation, and if the ride quality is firm the shock absorber damping smooths the hard edges of patchwork pavement. Steering responses are decisive by the standards of this vehicle class, although the steering itself can be affected by the lane departure assist, yielding a feel similar to running on grooved pavement. However, this feature can be shut off, making driving on winding two-lane back roads more pleasant since the dormant system isn’t reacting to edge lines.

The nine-speed transmission is smooth and all but transparent in highway driving. It’s operated by push buttons, eliminating a bulky shift lever, and there’s no mechanical connection between the buttons and the transmission.

The more traditional six-speed in the lower trim levels has a conventional shift lever. We should also note that handling responses in these models, which roll on eighteen-inch wheels, are a bit less decisive and ride quality is softer, attributable primarily to the higher profile of their tires. Even so, it’s an improvement over generation two. And all of the 2016 models have exceptionally low interior noise levels.

Another noteworthy feature is start-stop technology. It’s increasingly widespread in today’s new vehicles; the engine shuts down at stoplights, and lights up when the driver takes his or her foot off the brake pedal, contributing to improved urban fuel economy.
The nine-speed transmission is smooth and all but transparent in highway driving. It’s operated by push buttons, eliminating a bulky shift lever.

Safety credentials (Honda expects top ratings) are contemporary, and, consistent with the trend toward semi-autonomous vehicles, some of them will intervene on your behalf. Lane keeping assist is one example. Another is a program that tracks the Pilot’s closing rate on the car ahead in low-speed urban traffic, determines whether the driver is paying attention, flashes a warning, and when the driver fails to react, applies the brakes. If the car ahead has stopped, the system can halt the Pilot short of impact up to 30 mph, and mitigate impacts at higher speeds.

Also worth noting: the adaptive cruise control is an excellent safety feature. The Pilot does, however, allow cancellation of its adaptive feature, an option sure to make some drivers happy. For that matter, the entire Pilot driving experience is likely to make drivers happy.

The Verdict:

When it goes on sale June 18, the Pilot’s price schedule will range from $30,875 for a basic front-wheel-drive LX model to our top Elite at a hefty $47,300. All have the same engine. While an all-wheel-drive Pilot Elite rivals many luxury SUVs in terms of hedonism and performance, there are plenty of less expensive models that will satisfy family needs without sacrificing too many of the top model goodies.
If you’re looking for a three-row SUV, the case could be made that this is the best in a strong class of contenders. It’s certainly (for now) the newest.
