Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, hands-free smart liftgate with automatic opening, Proximity Key entry with push-button start, 18- and 19-inch wheels, panoramic sunroof, parking assistance, heated and cooled front seats, heated rear seats, heated steering wheel, eight-inch touchscreen, navigation, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4

The Hyundai Santa Fe Sport is a natty-looking five-seat, front-wheel-drive crossover utility vehicle with all-wheel drive available as an option. It comes with a direct-injection 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine that generates 190 horsepower. A six-speed automatic is standard. But the Santa Fe Sport really lives up to its name when it’s equipped with the available direct-injection, turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder that churns out 265 horsepower. The 2.0T has eighteen-inch wheels, and nineteen-inchers are available. There are three options packages, available with either trim level. The Popular Equipment package includes heated front seats, a 4.3-inch touchscreen, and rearview camera. The Premium package adds leather upholstery and appointments, lane-change assist and blind spot detection with rear cross-traffic alert, and Proximity Key entry with push-button start. The Tech package includes rear parking assistance, a heated steering wheel, cooled front and heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, and an eight-inch screen. The very desirable hands-free liftgate is also included. The Ultimate package offered only with the 2.0T has nineteen-inch wheels, HID headlamps and LED taillamps, and a premium audio system. Electronic chassis controls include selectable steering effort and a smart all-wheel-drive system with active cornering control. Towing capacity is 2,000 pounds for the Sport and 3,500 pounds for the Sport 2.0T. Hill start assist and downhill brake control help to manage the load. This year, improvements to the electrically assisted power steering along with a slightly stiffened suspension enhance the drivability. With the standard suite of electronically regulated active safety features, the Santa Fe Sport is a hit on every level, making it a strong contender in this category.

New for 2015:

Refined steering and suspension systems, daytime running lights, driver’s blind spot mirror, auto up/down front passenger power window, two-tone grille, available power liftgate with hands-free operation.

title: Erik Carlsson, 1929-2015
subTitle: Remembering my friend, the great rally driver and Saab spokesman.
promoTeaserSmall: Remembering my friend, the great rally driver and Saab spokesman.
promoTeaser: Remembering my friend, the great rally driver and Saab spokesman.
metaDescription: Remembering my friend, the great rally driver and Saab spokesman.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Erik Carlsson, March 5, 1929 — May 27, 2015

Erik Carlsson has died. There weren’t words yesterday, and I’m not sure I have words today to describe just how much I loved him. (Like a hilarious Swedish uncle.) Just how talented he was. (One of the greatest rally drivers of all time.) How important he was to Saab, a company he helped make famous by driving its funny little cars to impossible victories in the most grueling rallies of the day, and then by tirelessly traveling the globe as an extraordinary public relations emissary cum driving instructor cum hail fellow well met. The towering, gregarious Erik Carlsson touched an amazing number of people as he traveled from auto shows to dealer meetings to press events around the world, endlessly posing for photographs, stopping to sign autographs, and treating each person along the way as his new best friend.

I fell for it hook, line, and sinker. I met him during the running of the first One Lap of America, a 9,000-plus-mile adventure that I’d entered with Parnelli Jones and Walker Evans. But we didn’t really meet until my first Saab press event—an extended adventure that began in Stockholm; carried on by plane to the Finnish capital, Helsinki; then continued by new Saab 900 to Rovaniemi, where we panned for gold; then took those new 900s to the top of the world—Nordkapp, Norway—where the press corps and its enthusiastic Swedish PR team, led by Carlsson, danced and drank all night with the local Laplanders in celebration of the midnight sun. By the end of that amazing trek, I’d learned a string of choice Swedish swear words, and Erik insisted I fly home to England to meet the family—his wife, Pat, who was Stirling Moss’s little sister, and their teenaged daughter, Susie, an accomplished horsewoman. It was mid-May, and Pat welcomed me with a complete, traditional English Christmas dinner of beef, Yorkshire pudding, roasted parsnips, and Christmas pudding topped with Erik’s handmade brandy butter, which he lit on fire for us. Pat made up a pallet for me in the living room and told me that if I got up before noon, she would wring my bloody neck.
I thought Erik was bigger than life. Well, tiny Pat was even bigger than Erik. I couldn’t get enough of her.

Erik met Pat on the rally circuit, where she was winning rallies driving a big, terrifying Austin-Healey and beating all the boys but Erik. By the time I met her, she had retired. But she was far from retiring. She was now taking Susie to horse jumping events, still chain smoking, swearing like a trucker, and driving that horse transporter like she was on a stage of the Monte Carlo Rally. When they were all home, they were the Bickersons, all shouting, arguing, laughing, swearing, and I felt like I was home, too. I did dishes, helped (watched) Erik muck out stables, and traveled with the girls to the jump events.

Erik assumed I would fit right into the middle of that amazing maelstrom. And I wished I had stayed there. I came for visits several times, until my life got too busy to spend extra days overseas. But I saw Erik every year at the Geneva Auto Show, which always fell around his March 5th birthday. I would deliver a card to him at the Saab booth, where we would catch up on the home gossip, and where there was always a cake and a never-ending stream of his many best friends. I was married in Geneva on March 3,1997—his and Pat’s own wedding anniversary—and the wedding party toasted him with equal enthusiasm.

I always meant to get back to Tring to see Pat again, and to meet Susie’s own new family, but it didn’t happen. Pat died in 2008. I was heartened today by a note from Erik’s sister-in-law, Lady Susie Moss, saying that Erik was cared for in his last weeks by his darling daughter, and that the end was “gentle and peaceful.”
His many best friends around the world can take comfort from that.

Top photo (from left): Erik Carlsson, Pat Moss-Carlsson, Stirling Moss, in Monte Carlo. Inset photo: Saab press group at the top of the world—Nordkapp, Norway—with then new 1985 Saab 900s. Jean Lindamood Jennings is surrounded midpack by the usual sea of male colleagues; Erik Carlsson is far right, wearing hat.


Also see: Obituary at Autosport.com

The Wit and Wisdom of the Moss-Carlsons: excerpts from their book, The Art and Technique of Driving
From Automobile Magazine, June 1995

images.caption: Erik Carlsson (far right) with world media, including me (center).
Erik Carlsson; wife, Pat Moss; brother-in-law, Stirling Moss.

Type: Five- or seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover

Trim levels: MDX, MDX with Technology Package, MDX with Technology & Entertainment Packages, MDX with Advance & Entertainment Packages
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: FWD: 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway; AWD: 18/27 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model: Heated front seats, LED headlights, power liftgate, Bluetooth, power sunroof
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, navigation, rear-seat entertainment system, heated rear seats
You might also be considering: BMW X5, Infiniti QX60, Lincoln MKT, Volvo XC90

It’s no wonder that the seven-passenger MDX is Acura’s bestselling vehicle, as it offers the comfort, performance, style, and practicality that buyers want in a sport-utility vehicle. With three rows of seating, the MDX can carry up to seven passengers. Access to the rearmost row is made easier by a low step-in height and a second row that that moves forward at the touch of a button. When both rows are folded, the cargo compartment expands to 90.0 cubic feet—plenty of room for anything you might purchase at Ikea.

The cabin is well appointed, with leather trim, an ergonomically friendly center console with two display screens, and easy-to-read gauges. The optional navigation system is also user-friendly, although the graphics and technology are starting to look a little outdated.

Standard features include push-button start, LED headlamps, a rearview camera with multiple viewing angles, Bluetooth, satellite radio, three-zone automatic climate control, a power moonroof, and heated front seats. There are lots of high-tech optional features when you order the Technology, Advance, and Entertainment packages, including a rear-seat entertainment system, a premium audio system, forward collision warning, lane-departure warning, and a collision mitigation system.

There is only one powertrain option: a very capable 290-horsepower, 3.5-liter V-6 and a six-speed automatic transmission. Front-wheel drive is standard, but Acura’s all-wheel-drive system is worth a look if you live in an area with inclement weather and/or challenging road conditions.

New for 2015

The MDX is unchanged for 2015.

More about the Acura MDX

2014 Acura MDX SH-AWD July 22, 2013

title: 2016 Nissan Maxima SR
subTitle: Is the four-door sports car reborn? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Is the four-door sports car reborn? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Is the four-door sports car reborn? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: Is the four-door sports car reborn? Here's what we think.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sport sedan
Price: $38,495
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 300 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/30 mpg highway
Trim levels: S, SV, SL, SR, Platinum
My favorite standard feature: Continuously variable automatic transmission
Option I can’t live without: The Maxima offers no free-standing options
Notable standard features on this model: 19-inch aluminum alloy wheels, sport-tuned suspension, dynamic ride control, LED projector beam headlights, NissanConnect infotainment with navigation and eight-inch touchscreen, Bose premium audio, heated and cooled diamond-quilted leather seats with Alcantara inserts, rearview monitor, blind spot warning, adaptive cruise control, forward emergency braking
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Impala, Chrysler 300, Ford Taurus SHO, Hyundai Azera, Kia Cadenza, Toyota Avalon

You’re looking at a car that almost wasn’t. Longest-running of Nissan’s North American nameplates, the Maxima almost came to a full and permanent stop about four years ago, when Nissan execs and product planners were faced with a go/no go decision on the next generation.

We’ll never know exactly how close the Maxima came to extinction, but that’s moot because the eighth generation is rolling into showrooms as we speak, a little bigger, a little better, and a little more deserving of the 4-Door Sports Car label than any of its predecessors.

That label has been part of Maxima’s persona since the third generation, introduced in 1981, although it hasn't been used in Maxima marketing the past couple of generations. But with the attributes of generation eight, Nissan marketers think the time is right to dust off the mantra. 
So. Does the product measure up to the promise? That’s what we’re here to find out.

The Maxima's 109.3-inch wheelbase is unchanged, but at 192.8 inches, the 2016 Maxima is two inches longer and 1.3 inches lower (56.3 inches). Width—73.2 inches—remains the same. Curb weight is down slightly—82 pounds—and horsepower is up slightly, from 290 to 300, allowing Nissan to claim best-in-class power-to-weight.

Thanks to the use of more high-strength steel, Nissan also claims the Maxima’s unit body is 25 percent stiffer, always a plus in the dynamics department. And increased engine efficiency—displacement of the V-6 is unchanged, but 61 percent of its parts are new—begets improved EPA fuel economy ratings, as well as increased horsepower: 22 mpg city, 30 highway, a 15 percent improvement over the previous Maxima.

Like the previous Maxima, the V-6 sends its power to the front wheels via a continuously variable transmission—Xtronic, in Nissan speak—but the engineering team has made extensive upgrades to the transmission’s control software, part of ongoing development to make the CVT feel more like a conventional automatic.
The new Maxima’s exterior has more drama —more sculpting along the sides, a sportier front fascia, and the lower roofline to give the package a more athletic look.

Nissan is aking the Maxima upscale, with enhanced interior appointments and slick new sheetmetal. Inspired by the Nissan Sport Sedan concept car from the 2014 Detroit Auto Show, the new Maxima has a more dramatic exterior—more sculpting along the sides, a sportier front fascia, and the lower roofline to give the package a more athletic look.

Inside, all five Maxima trim levels will include navigation as standard equipment. Nissan marketing troops tell us the instruments and driver-oriented dashboard layout were inspired by the Blue Angels F/A-18 fighter jet, an assertion we’ll have to take on faith since not many of us have ever been in an F/A-18 cockpit, Blue Angels or otherwise.

In addition to expanded telematics and connectivity, the instrument panel also includes a new display—Driver Attention Alert—that flashes up when various sensors conclude that the driver isn’t paying attention to the driving, suggesting the driver take a break. Judging by what we see in the daily traffic stream, we suspect this display will activate frequently.

Another new safety feature, one that’s becoming widespread in the industry, is autonomous braking. When the car’s forward radar sensor concludes that a collision is imminent, it will apply the brakes and stop the car. The system will operate regardless of whether the adaptive cruise control is active.

We accumulated our Maxima preview seat time in an SR model, the sportiest of the five grades, with firmer suspension tuning and the benefit of a damping system that auto adjusts continuously to road, speed and driver inputs. The SR also rolls on slightly more aggressive all-season tires, with the option of summer performance rubber (as a dealer-installed accessory).

The Maxima offers multiple operating modes, and in the normal setting its responses aren’t particularly sporty, nor is the electric rack-and-pinion particularly accurate or tactile. But this changes markedly in Sport mode: the steering firms up, as does the suspension, and Maxima’s agility index goes from ordinary to eager.

We should add that the responses of the other Maxima models are a bit softer than those of the SR, although far from spongy. We should add further that even though the SR is a bit firmer than the other Maximas, ride quality in all is smooth, and interior noise levels are exceptionally low.

As you’d expect, a little less mass and a little more horsepower add up to a little better acceleration. The 2015 Maxima sprinted to 60 mph in a wink or two less than six seconds. The new Maxima should trim that down to about 5.5—not exactly face-distorting, but not exactly slow, and certainly near the front of its competitive pack.

But the most impressive element in the new Maxima’s powertrain story is the operation of its continuously variable transmission. CVTs have become increasingly popular with carmakers, especially Nissan, because of their positive impact on fuel economy. But they have also exhibited operating traits—a sense of clutch slippage during acceleration while the transmission catches up with the engine—that can be a turnoff for many drivers.
The Nissan chip wizards have baked seven simulated shift points into the computer’s control computer, giving this CVT the feel of a conventional automatic.

The Maxima’s updated CVT all but banishes that trait. The Nissan chip wizards have baked seven simulated shift points into the computer’s control computer, giving it the feel of a conventional automatic. In the SR model, the experience is enhanced by paddle shifters, yielding a prompt sense of engagement going up or down.
Because of fuel economy benefits, Nissan has been developing CVTs for a long time. This is the first one your humble narrator can imagine himself living with, and it’s the best in the business.

The Maxima straddles the line between mid- and full size, and its pricing, ranging from $33,235 (up $1,120 from the previous base model) to $40,685, puts it in a section of the market carmakers call “premium”—not quite luxury, but luxurious nevertheless. Purists will find it pretty easy to belittle Nissan’s 4-Door Sports Car theme, but let’s be realistic: that’s just marketing, and it’s tongue in cheek, at least to some extent. But in this eighth generation, the Maxima wears the term “sport sedan” more comfortably than ever before and stands even closer to the head of a very attractive class.

title: 2015 Infiniti Q70L
subTitle: This is the extended-wheelbase version of the delightfully sinuous luxury sedan. Is it your size?
promoTeaserSmall: This is the extended-wheelbase version of the delightfully sinuous luxury sedan. Is it your size?
promoTeaser: This is the extended-wheelbase version of the delightfully sinuous luxury sedan. Is it your size?
metaDescription: This is the extended-wheelbase version of the delightfully sinuous luxury sedan. Is it your size?

pageElements.text:
2015 Infiniti Q70L 3.7 AWD

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive luxury full-size sedan
Base price: $54,405 (including destination charge)
This car: $62,755 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 330 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/24 mpg highway
Models available: Q70L 3.7 (3.7-liter V-6), RWD or AWD; Q70L 5.6 (5.6-liter V-8), RWD or AWD
My favorite standard feature: Heated and ventilated front seats
Notable standard features on this model: Power sliding moonroof, dual-zone climate control, heated rear seats, rearview camera, rain-sensing wipers, memory seats and steering wheel, LED headlights, fog lights, and taillights
Notable options on this model: Technology package ($3,300) includes rear collision intervention, forward collision warning, blind spot monitoring and intervention, intelligent cruise control, distance control assist, forward emergency braking, and pre-crash seat belts; Deluxe Touring package ($3,900) includes Japanese white ash wood trim, semi-aniline leather-appointed seats, Bose studio surround premium audio, power rear sunshade; Premium package (no extra cost) includes navigation, eight-inch touchscreen, heated steering wheel, around-view monitor with moving object detection
You might also be considering: 2016 Audi A6 Premium Plus Quattro 3.0 TFSI ($58,325); 2015 Cadillac CTS 3.6 AWD ($55,965); 2016 Lexus GS350 AWD ($52,700); 2015 Mercedes-Benz E350 4Matic ($55,600) (all prices include destination charges)

So much of the point of the Infiniti Q70 is beauty. This mid-size luxury sedan is the flagship of the Infiniti lineup—and it looks the part. If you like an eye-catchingly curvaceous body style in a car, you will catch your breath every time you glance at this one. “Sinuous” doesn’t begin to describe it.

But the point of the Q70L goes a little further. If car ownership is about more than just looks for you—in this case, if you want to carry up to three adults in the back seat of your car in luxury and comfort—then luckily for you, here is the extended-length version (the L is for Longer).

It's kind of funny, but true, that Infiniti thinks Americans will choose this new, extended-length version as an alternative to a sport-utility vehicle. But it's true; the Nissan luxury brand wants you to choose the Q70L if a regular sedan just isn't roomy enough for you, but you're not quite convinced you need to have a big fat SUV instead. Infiniti makes some of the best-looking large SUVs, but this is definitely a whole different look and feel.
Go look at sedans these days; the back seat is sometimes an afterthought. Hardly ever is there actually room to put three grownups. This car has it.

Are you intrigued by this idea of getting extra back-seat space? It's an idea that's popular in Europe and in China, but Americans like space, too. Why extended length? Imagine the luxury of 5.6 inches of added legroom in the rear seats, and 5.9 inches of added knee room. Go look at sedans these days; the back seat is sometimes an afterthought, sometimes a definite two-seat-plus-toss-your-bag-in-between space. Hardly ever is there actually room to put three grownups. This car has it.

If this sounds like a car that you could be chauffeured in, that’s no mistake. The Q70L was rolled out first in China, where chauffeuring is much more of a thing than it ever will be in the United States. A Q70L was displayed in April at the Shanghai Auto Show in a Bespoke Edition with quilted white leather seats and trim, intended to appeal to people who plan to employ a driver.

If you want to follow the corporate-limousine theme into Europe, examples are more available than you might think, though they are usually offered at a high price. There’s the Porsche Panamera Executive ($126,595), the Jaguar XJL ($78,950), the BMW 740Li ($78,950), the Mercedes-Benz S550 ($95,325), and the Audi A8 L ($138,825), for instance. All have rear legroom in the 40-inch-and-up category. Light that cigar and stretch out those designer shoes.
If you are mainly seeking that kind of space, the Infiniti QX70L is practically a bargain. Like those others, it is gorgeous and cushy, but it has a pretty reasonable $54,405 opening price.

If you want more power, you can get the V-8-powered version of the Q70L, which starts at $65,455 and gets you 416 horsepower. Both engines are teamed with a seven-speed automatic transmission with a manual shift mode.

The door design with its musical clef styling offers an unusual application of wood and metal trim. This kind of design is one of the hallmarks of an Infiniti, and a reason to consider buying one.  The wood is a 3D sculptural sweep instead of just a strip of wood. On the dash in the center console, the wood is folded in; you won't see this kind of attention to detail on most other cars, and certainly not in this price range.

The Q70L 3.7 AWD we tested had a Deluxe Touring package ($3,900) that included Japanese white ash wood trim, semi-aniline (buttery) leather seating, and a sixteen-speaker Bose audio system. On one level, this kind of luxury is excessive, but in this car it's utterly tasteful and seamless. A Premium package, at no extra charge, added navigation with an eight-inch touchscreen, front and rear sonar, Nissan's AroundView monitor that gives a bird's-eye camera view of what's all around your car, and the finest luxury item ever for people in Northern climates: a heated steering wheel.

In addition to the looks and the luxury, the highly recommended Technology package ($3,300) offers a full slate of active safety features: to predict and intervene with collisions at the front or rear; to warn and intervene in case of something in your blind spot; to warn you when you’re departing your lane and push you back in; to keep you at a safe following distance with distance control assist and smart cruise control; to prepare you with pre-crash seatbelts and forward emergency braking. Adding the Touring and Technology packages takes this Q70L from its low-$50,000s base price into the low $60,000s. But one important reason to buy a new car these days is to get all the great new active safety technology that just wasn't available a few years ago.

The Verdict:

Infinitis are not for everybody, but that's not a bad thing if you like to stand out. Do you want a mid-size luxury sedan that's fun to drive and doesn't look or feel like a boat? There is no shortage of $50,000-plus rear-wheel-drive luxury sedans on the market, most of which come with an all-wheel-drive option. People shopping in this category might be looking at the old favorites from Lexus, BMW, and Mercedes-Benz. If that's you, don't make a knee-jerk decision without going further afield and checking out the Infiniti Q70, too.

What sets the Infiniti apart is its design, which goes beyond competence and verges on artistry. What sets this particular Infiniti apart is the extended length, making it completely workable for people who actually want to put adults into the back seat.

images.caption: Looks are a large part of the point of the 2015 Infiniti Q70L.

title: 2015 BMW X3
subTitle: The Goldilocks of crossovers.
promoTeaserSmall: The Goldilocks of crossovers.
promoTeaser: The Goldilocks of crossovers.
metaKeywords: 2015 BMW X3; BMW; sport-utility; crossover; SUV; diesel; German
metaDescription: The Goldilocks of crossovers. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $39,350–$46,050 (includes destination)
Trim levels: sDrive28i, xDrive28i, xDrive35i, xDrive 28d
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter 4-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbo-diesel 2.0-liter 4-cylinder, 181 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter 6-cylinder, 300 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy: sDrive28i/xDrive28i: 21 mpg city/28 mpg highway; xDrive35i: 19/26 mpg; xDrive28d: 27/34 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth audio
Notable standard features on this model: USB audio connection and Bluetooth audio streaming, iDrive infotainment system, automatic stop/start, power folding heated side mirrors, 8-way power front seats, adaptive cruise control
Notable options on this model: Heated front and rear seats and steering wheel, rearview camera, blind-spot monitoring system, surround view camera, keyless entry and hands-free hatch
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, Land Rover Range Rover Discovery Sport, Mercedes-Benz GLK-class, Volvo XC60

With the addition of a new turbo-diesel engine, BMW has figured out a way to give car shoppers the roominess and cargo capacity of a crossover with the performance and fuel economy of a sedan. The 2.0-liter 4-cylinder diesel engine produces 180 horsepower and 280 lb-ft of torque and it more than adequately powers this compact “Sports Activity Vehicle.” But if diesel isn’t your thing, the other available powerplants are a 240-horsepower, 2.0-liter 4-cylinder and a V-6 that produces 300 horsepower, but expect far lower fuel economy. All engine options are paired with the standard 8-speed automatic transmission. On the interior, the X3 has a few standard technology features, such as the iDrive infotainment system and Bluetooth audio, but most of the advanced safety features like the head-up display, adaptive cruise control, lane-departure warning, and collision avoidance systems cost extra. Rear seat passengers can stretch out a bit more than most compact or midsize sedans, with 36.5 cubic inches of legroom at their disposal. Cargo capacity behind the rear seats is 27.6 cubic feet and maxes out at an impressive 63.3 cubic feet with the seats folded flat.

New for 2015

Minor interior and exterior refresh and changes to standard features and options packages.

title: Make J.D. Power Surveys Work for You
subTitle: What the Initial Quality Study can do to help you pick your next car—and what it can’t.
promoTitle: Make J.D. Power Surveys Work for You
promoTeaserSmall: What the Initial Quality Study can do to help you pick your next car—and what it can’t.
promoTeaser: What the Initial Quality Study can do to help you pick your next car—and what it can’t.
keywords: Make J.D. Power Surveys Work for You
metaTitle: Make J.D. Power Surveys Work for You - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: how to shop for a car
metaDescription: What the Initial Quality Study can do to help you pick your next car—and what it can’t.

pageElements.text: If you're shopping for a new car, you are probably all over the Internet looking for information. Thanks for stopping off here, by the way. We're here to help. And that's why we are calling to your attention the latest of the many studies and reports you'll find about customer satisfaction and vehicle quality. It's one of the biggies, the 2015 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study, or IQS.

This survey ranks automotive brands and individual models, according to how many problems were reported by new-car buyers in their first ninety days of owning or leasing. This well-established survey is now in its twenty-ninth year.

The study surveys some 84,000 purchasers, with results covering February through May of this year. That seems like a lot, but keep in mind that the IQS is highly subjective. The person answering the survey gets to declare what they consider a problem, and you might be surprised at what these problems entail.

We're not talking a bunch of transmission failures here (although there were surely some serious issues). The biggest source of complaints is actually infotainment: especially problems pairing phone to car using Bluetooth, and getting the car to recognize your voice. (I can identify, as someone who uses voice recognition on my phone and has been frustrated by Siri’s crazy misinterpretations.) Those things are irritating, but I wouldn’t want to decide what car to buy based on whether the infotainment system knows what I’m saying every time. Neither should you.

What can you learn from the IQS? Since infotainment is causing so much distress among new-car buyers, make sure you fully understand the information and entertainment technology in any car you’re planning to buy or lease. Make the salesperson go over it with you in exhaustive detail before you drive off. Play around with the navigation, voice recognition, Bluetooth phone pairing, and other complicated stuff so you don’t have to go back in your first ninety days of ownership to get help with it.

Of course, it still can be useful to know which vehicle had the fewest problems reported in the category you're looking at. It can also be helpful to look at which auto company ranks highest and which lowest. This year, the big news is that the Korean automakers Kia and Hyundai did much better, while Japanese automakers dropped below the industry average for the first time, putting them on par with U.S. automakers and below the European average. Overall, J.D. Power notes, initial quality went up three percent last year, so that's good news for consumers. Now, suppose you need to make a short list of potential new cars to buy. You might want to pay attention to where your preferred brand came out in the IQS.

The average among automakers was 112 problems reported per 100 vehicles in the first ninety days of ownership. The top-ranked automaker was Porsche, with only 80 problems reported per 100 vehicles. Kia was second, with 86, and Jaguar third, with 93. Hyundai placed fourth, with 95 problems per 100 vehicles, and the number-five spot was claimed by Infiniti, with 97. BMW placed sixth, well ahead of average with 99 problems per 100 vehicles. BMW of North America's president and CEO, Ludwig Willisch, said the IQS shows “how well our dealers are doing in demonstrating the functions of the new vehicle,” but he added that "the clear challenge [is] to improve and simplify technology.”

Here is the 2015 IQS detailed breakdown by brand.
Down at the bottom, Fiat was last among thirty-three brands, with 161 problems reported per 100 vehicles. We asked Berj Alexanian of Fiat Chrysler how Fiat is responding to that last-place finish.

He told JKC that Fiat's poor showing was in part because of "a bit of a disconnect" because the Fiat lineup was designed “specifically for global markets. We’re still bringing them into line with American priorities,” he said. Specifically? "There will be changes to our infotainment systems between 2015 and 2016 model years," he said.

Michael McHale, Subaru director of corporate communications, commented on his brand's rating of 142 problems per 100 vehicles, fourth from the bottom. He said that IQS problems reported in Subarus, "as for many makes," were largely about "connectivity and voice recognition. This is new technology and we are continually improving our offerings and expect our new product scores to improve next year."
Should you just go buy the product of whatever company had the fewest reported problems? A smarter move would be to consider this study as one of several tools.
The IQS also ranks vehicles by category. Here were the cars and SUVs at the top of each category.

City Car: Chevrolet Spark
Small Car: Hyundai Accent
Small Premium Car: BMW 2 Series
Compact Car: Nissan Sentra
Compact Sporty Car: Mazda MX-5 Miata
Compact Premium Car: BMW 4 Series
Compact Premium Sporty Car: Porsche Boxster
Mid-size Car: Chevrolet Malibu
Mid-size Sporty Car: Dodge Challenger
Mid-size Premium Car: BMW 5 Series
Mid-size Premium Sporty Car: Porsche 911
Large Car: Chrysler 300
Large Premium Car: Lexus LS
You also shouldn’t rely on a single source of information, obviously, nor take your inspiration from what people thought only for the first three months of ownership. Here are some other resources:

Owner Satisfaction. Consumer Reports takes a much bigger survey of new-vehicle owners with its annual Owner Satisfaction study. Pro: It covers more people and a longer term of ownership, surveying 350,000 vehicles from one to three years old. Con: The respondents are all CR subscribers, not a cross-section of the general population.

Vehicle Dependability. J.D. Power also does a Vehicle Dependability Study that comes out in February. That one reports problems experienced in the past year with three-year-old vehicles. J.D. Power says that reliability complaints again lean heavily toward infotainment systems and technology.
Visit the survey specialist's website to see all the J.D. Power automotive surveys and rankings.

2015 Subaru Outback. Subaru was fourth from last in the 2015 J.D. Power IQS.

title: 2015 Ford Focus SE
subTitle: What America drives...and why.
promoTeaserSmall: What America drives...and why.
promoTeaser: What America drives...and why.
metaDescription: What America drives...and why.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Ford Focus SE

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Base price: $19,285 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $21,970
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 26 mpg city/38 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Chevrolet Cruze LS Automatic ($19,695)
2015 Honda Civic Sedan SE ($20,810)
2016 Hyundai Elantra SE Automatic ($18,250)
2015 Mazda 3 i SV ($18,815)
2015 Toyota Corolla LE ($19,390)

Fun-o-Meter: 6

Your heart isn’t pounding when you look at the simple, clean lines of this 2015 Ford Focus, is it? That’s okay. A compact car at a reasonable price, and one that gives you choices as to engine, body style, and amount of sportiness: such a car has enough to recommend it without trying to be sexy, too.

And yet, there is something quite sexy about being able to buy a new car in the $20,000-and-under range that doesn’t feel cheap. That explains why so many people make the Ford Focus their choice. Ford claims for it the title of world’s best-selling nameplate, with more than 12 million sold worldwide since its initial launch in 1998. It’s very popular in Europe, where a diesel version is available, and in the U.S. it’s the second-best-selling car, after the mid-size Fusion, in the Ford lineup (not including the perennial #1 F-150 pickup, of course).

Speaking of sexy, the Aston Martin-esque looks of the Ford Fusion are hinted at in the small but fierce grille at the front end of the Focus. If looks are important to you, aesthetically the five-door hatchback model is the sexy-looking one, as well as more versatile than the 2015 Focus SE sedan we tested. Still, 60 percent of buyers choose the sedan version, which has a shallow but serviceable trunk. The Focus comes as a base S sedan, while the SE and upper-level Titanium are available as sedan or hatchback versions. Above them is a sportier ST and, coming at the end of the year, a hot-hatch SR version. As with several Ford products, an electric model is for sale, too. Versatility has its rewards.

The base engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 160 horsepower. This would be more interesting if there wasn't a brief clunk in the driveline when I accelerated from a stop. It is just frequent enough to be annoying. It is likely an aberration.
There is something quite sexy about being able to buy a new car in the $20,000-and-under range that doesn’t feel cheap. That explains why so many people choose the Focus.

For your $21,970—the out-the-door price of the Focus we tested—you get an SE Sport package that slightly glams up the exterior, including a rear spoiler, foglamps, and a set of seventeen-inch aluminum wheels. You also get a six-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters, a $1,095 option over the standard five-speed manual.

What’s more interesting in the Focus lineup is the turbocharged EcoBoost engine, new for 2015. It’s a surprisingly peppy 1.0-liter, 123-horsepower three-cylinder first seen on the subcompact Fiesta, teamed with a six-speed manual transmission. It’s good for 40 mpg on the highway, only a little better than the 38 mpg on the Focus SE we drove, which had the six-speed automatic PowerShift dual-clutch automatic transmission. If you choose the SE Appearance package ($1,995), that transmission comes with SelectShift capability that helps deliver better fuel economy and operates automatically but feels more like a manual transmission.

If you’re looking for a little (or a lot) more excitement from your Focus, there’s the ST hatchback. It makes 252 horsepower from its turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder EcoBoost engine, comes only with the six-speed manual transmission, and starts at $25,245. This is the one you want. Perhaps you could consider skipping that daily megatoobig cappufrappe to help pay the extra $3,275 freight that the ST costs over the SE, because the ST looks better and feels better. (You will, too, if you switch to green tea.)

I drove the ST in Switzerland recently and loved it. But, when all is said and done, if the 252 horsepower from the ST hatchback isn’t quite enough for you, coming later this year is an all-wheel-drive version, the hatchback RS, with a 2.3-liter EcoBoost turbo four-cylinder that makes 315 horsepower.

Ford has come under some criticism for its Sync infotainment system, which people have called hard to use and non-intuitive. The automaker has responded by bringing out a fab new Sync 3 for a handful of new 2016 models. I tried it in late June and was astounded by how good it is, as different as night and day, actually. I’d even say it’s worth waiting for—it comes out at the end of 2016 for the Focus and most other Fords—if navigation and entertainment are important to you. The MyFord Touch package on the 2015 model costs $1,495 and includes ten-speaker Sony audio, SiriusXM satellite radio, and dual-zone climate control in addition to navigation and the eight-inch touchscreen.

The model we tested doesn’t come standard with a touchscreen. It and other lower-end models have a 4.2-inch non-touch screen. It’s okay but looks awfully outdated compared with the big, flashy screens you’ll see on other economy cars from the likes of Chevrolet, Honda, Toyota, and Hyundai. It does, however, have a rearview camera in it, which is standard equipment starting with this 2015 model. It also has Bluetooth to pair your phone, which worked flawlessly.

Now this is a compact car, so don’t get any ideas about transporting a large family or a lot of stuff in it on a regular basis. I know someone who rejected a Focus in favor of the larger Fusion based strictly on the need for comfortable legroom for her lanky teenage son in the back seat. The trunk swallowed up $225 worth of groceries with no problem but was not deep enough to take a broom, which had to ride inside the car instead. And, no, the broom would NOT come in handy if I ran out of gas.

The Focus SE I tested came with a frighteningly light-colored beige cloth interior, called Light Stone, that seemed to have Stain Me written all over it. Right on cue, I spilled an entire 16-ounce cup of coffee and the carrier it was riding in, upside down, but luckily it spilled on the (black) (rubber backed) floor mat, which washed right out. A leather interior is an option, as is a charcoal cloth interior. I’d prefer that: boring but safe. Then again, that beige cloth was mighty nice-looking.

And speaking of safe, a Technology package ($795) on the Titanium model includes blind spot monitoring with cross-traffic alert and lane-keeping alert, a reasonable price for this soon-to-feel-indispensable active safety tech. Small but very useful blind spot mirrors on the side mirror frames are standard and appreciated on the SE.

The Verdict:

The Ford Focus does not overwhelm you with luxuries, but there is one: the luxury of choice. You can go basic, and get the car we tested: a reasonably sized, competent, not unattractive car that works for every day. You can go upscale a bit, with the Titanium model, and add some active safety features, plus heated leather front seats, keyless entry, and touchscreen infotainment. Or you can indulge yourself with the sportier and much more powerful ST hatchback. I think I understand why so many people all over the world have chosen the Ford Focus.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class
subTitle: A fresh look for the luxury four-door coupe.
promoTeaserSmall: A fresh look for the luxury four-door coupe.
promoTeaser: A fresh look for the luxury four-door coupe.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five5-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive coupe or convertible
Price range: $66,915 – $107,475 (includes destination)
Trim levels: CLS400, CLS550, CLS63 S AMG
Engines: Twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 329 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.7-liter V-8, 402 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 5.5-liter V-8, 577 horsepower
Transmissions: 7- or 9-speed automatic
Fuel economy: CLS400 RWD: 20 mpg city/30 mpg highway; CLS400 AWD: 19/26 mpg; CLS550 RWD: 18/27 mpg; CLS550 AWD: 18/25 mpg; CLS63 AWD: 16/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Active air suspension
Notable standard features on this model: LED headlamps, 14-way power front seats with memory, heated front seats, 8-inch display with control dial, Bluetooth audio, navigation, multi-color ambient lighting
Notable options on this model: Rearview camera, pushbutton start, ventilated seats, power rear-window sunshade, active blind-spot and lane-keeping assist, rear spoiler, illuminated door sills, Bang & Olufsen premium sound system
You might also be considering: Audi A7, BMW 650i, Porsche Panamera

The luxury-car market is getting a bit crowded these days, and Mercedes Benz is hoping that the 2015 CLS-Class’s exterior and interior refresh, new engine options, and lower price point keep buyers’ eyes from wandering over to the BMW and Audi lots. It’s available with three powerful engines: a 329-horsepower, twin-turbo V-6; a 402-horsepower twin-turbo V-8; and a 577-horsepower, twin-turbo V-8, all paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission, save for the rear-wheel-drive CLS550, which gets a new nine-speed automatic. The optional Comand enables unrestricted Internet browsing using the new eight-inch LCD screen withyour paired phone’s data plan and only while the vehicle is stationary. Two navigation systems are offered in the CLS: the CLS400 navigation system uses Garmin, while the CLS550 uses Google Maps. Two executive-styled seats make the most of the rear, and new interior lighting gives this coupe a dramatic ambiance.

New for 2015

Redesigned front fascia and bumpers, front and rear, revised interior, package revisions, nine-speed automatic transmission added to the rear-wheel-drive CLS550, expanded engine choices.

title: Review: The Greatest Race
subTitle: A children’s book for all of us from Dwight Knowlton, author of The Little Red Racing Car.
promoTeaserSmall: A children’s book for all of us from Dwight Knowlton, author of The Little Red Racing Car.
promoTeaser: A children’s book for all of us from Dwight Knowlton, author of The Little Red Racing Car.
metaDescription: A children’s book for all of us from Dwight Knowlton, author of The Little Red Racing Car.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: “Years ago, there was a race. Perhaps the very greatest race.” These are the opening sentences of Dwight Knowlton’s newest children’s book, a spellbinding read that choked me up several times, and I know the story!

It seems impossible that Knowlton could deliver a second children’s book as captivating and beautifully illustrated as The Little Red Racing Car, a story about a father and his young son’s journey in finding a decrepit Maserati in an old barn and then restoring it together. Not only is his artwork lush, with unusual angles and wonderful details, Knowlton can also spin a yarn that will entrance young kids and old ones alike.
The Little Red Racing Car was fantastic and a coveted member of my permanent book collection. The Greatest Race now takes its place beside it. Forever.

Sounds like a tall order. But he’s done it again, with The Greatest Race: The Record-Breaking Win of the 1955 Mille Miglia. Automotive fans and historians will know this is the race that Stirling Moss famously ran in a 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300SLR with co-driving journalist Denis Jenkinson. We know they mapped the entire 1,000 miles and invented the pace note roller so Jenks could give Moss explicit directions allowing him to drive at top speed. We know they won.

But I’m not sure most of us know how harrowing the drive was, how dangerous and fraught with disaster, how very close they came to losing it all more than once. Knowlton captures the drama of key moments, the crashes and off-road excursions. Here is an example:

“Stirling and Jenks sped from Brescia to Vicenza at more than 160 mph. They were so intent on overtaking the slower cars ahead that they failed to see the big Ferrari of Castellotti closing in behind! They blasted through the streets of Padua with the 4.3-liter Ferrari on their tail.

“Stirling deftly tossed the car left, then right. Jenks looked ahead—THEY WERE GOING TOO FAST! Stirling fought the brakes and the wheel. The car skidded, bouncing off straw bales. They made the turn—but the red Ferrari roared past, painting black stripes on the road in front of them.”
What did the black stripes tell Stirling Moss?

It is all there, and more, in simple declarative sentences accompanying simple evocative drawings. There is no talking down to the reader. Instead, the book is sprinkled with technical information throughout, which will undoubtedly serve to whet many appetites for more.
As the book went on, I felt anxiety and a lump in my throat. I am serious!
The Little Red Racing Car was fantastic and a coveted member of my permanent book collection. The Greatest Race now takes its place beside it. Forever.
I would like to see a crowdsourced effort to pay for the next book from Knowlton. I nominate the amazing story of Denise McCluggage. Anyone with me?
The Greatest Race is a hardcover book, available for pre-order on Dwight Knowlton's website, priced at a very reasonable $23.99.

A look inside The Greatest Race.

title: Pro/Con: Smartphones in the Car?
subTitle: Molly says it's all good to chat and drive. Laura aspires to zenlike silence. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaserSmall: Molly says it's all good to chat and drive. Laura aspires to zenlike silence. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Molly says it's all good to chat and drive. Laura aspires to zenlike silence. Whose side are you on?
metaKeywords: talking on the phone in the car
metaDescription: Molly says it's all good to chat and drive. Laura aspires to zenlike silence. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Molly Says: I Never Stop Talking, Even When I'm Driving

When I pop into my car for the twenty-minute drive home after work, I immediately start dialing.
Obviously, I haven’t actually dialed a phone in twenty years, but, thanks to my bestie Siri, I bark my parents’ names into the phone before I even start the car.

Hands-free dialing is my touchstone with my parents, who live five states away. Then I call my daughter to see what is happening with her. This call is sometimes a long one, but it could just as easily be a voicemail. I almost always call my husband to plan the evening. I figure no need to waste these precious moments, and the drive is easy.
The combination of Bluetooth connectivity and Siri is essential for my productivity, safety, and sanity.

Everyone complains about other drivers being on their cell phones. Well, I must confess that I consider my vehicle my own personal phone booth. The technology available in modern cars seems to be right out of the science fiction books of my youth. Cars are taking giant leaps in becoming more autonomous, but our attention is still very much required to pilot a vehicle safely down the road. My very favorite giant leap forward for mankind is the proliferation of Bluetooth technology in cars. Being able to sync my personal phone with my car is literally a lifesaver. The combination of Bluetooth connectivity and Siri is essential for my productivity, safety, and sanity as I run around town, crawl down the highway in congested traffic, or chew off miles on very long road trips.

When I am alone in a car and I start to get drowsy, I awaken Siri and begin the hunt for life forms. I need someone to have a lively conversation with, to while away the miles and reinvigorate me. There is always a friend who I need to catch up with, and in the car is the perfect time. Obviously, if I am dangerously tired I will stop and take a break.

I always try to dial through Siri or at a stoplight. I anxiously keep my eyes on the light to make sure I am still engaged in driving. My personal motto is driving first, phone second. I will hang up mid-sentence if the driving gets dicey. And I will not read or respond to a text or email. Not once have I responded to the ding on my phone. I admit that at a stoplight I will read a text, but my admirer will have to wait for my response.

I know a lot of drivers are now using their smartphones to run the music in their cars. I can barely switch the climate control in vehicles as I fly down the highway, so that is not happening for me, either. If a car has a touchscreen to use Pandora, I can manage that while driving. As for Google Maps, I use it only if I put the destination in before driving.

Now when it comes to how I want my daughter to interact with her phone while driving, my opinion is flip-flopped. Turn it off until you reach your destination. However, I am no dummy I know she is going to use her phone. I had an aftermarket stereo with Bluetooth technology installed the very first week we bought her a used Passat.

Laura Sky Brown: Let's All Shut the Phones Off, At Least Once in a While

Let us have a moment of silence for...a moment of silence. I have just come from a week driving through eastern Canada, where I had no Wi-Fi, no data, and no international calling plan on my iPhone. That's right: days of enforced non-talking on the phone, non-texting at stoplights, and non-Internet surfing while parked in restaurant parking lots. With two college student kids in the car with me, also not talking, texting, or surfing by phone.
It was glorious.
I would enjoy it so much if the other people driving to my left, my right, and particularly right behind me would take vows of phone silence at rush hour.

As much as I appreciate (and, often, need) the convenience and security of a phone, I wish more people would shut theirs off occasionally. It's a good thing to have only the road ahead to focus on. In fact, I would enjoy it so much if people driving to my left, my right, and particularly right behind me would take vows of phone silence at rush hour.

Bluetooth, letting you pair your smartphone to the car and receive and send hands-free phone calls, is a great invention. I pair my phone with most vehicles I test drive and certainly have it set up with my personal car. But there's a difference between having it available in case of need and treating the car like a rolling continuation of the office. I believe in waiting until I'm parked to have most conversations. People driving in front of me, you're welcome.

There's a reason a lot of people love to go on Sunday drives and take extended road trips. I certainly do. It's the opportunity to close yourself in to the well-loved interior of your vehicle and go out and explore. Driving is less of an adventure than it was 100 years ago, of course: you don't have to worry about breakdowns and flat tires, the roads are usually in drivable condition, and there's an Interstate going close to almost anywhere you want to be. But hang on to the last shred of the pleasure of roaming, and turn off roaming on your smartphone as often as you can. Some things just need to remain sacred.

title: 2016 Hyundai Tucson AWD Limited
subTitle: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?
promoTeaserSmall: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?
promoTeaser: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?
metaDescription: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?

pageElements.text:
Base price: $23,595 (base SE model; prices include destination charge)
This model: $32,195
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Engine: Turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Turbo powertrain
Features I can’t live without: Auto-opening liftgate
Notable standard features on this model: 19-inch alloy wheels; LED headlights; LED foglamps, daytime running lights, and taillights; eight-inch touchscreen; navigation; panoramic power moonroof; tilting/telescoping steering column; leather-wrapped steering wheel; heated leather seats; power front seats; premium audio; Hyundai BlueLink car care and emergency telematics; heated side mirrors; hands-free power liftgate; blind spot detection; lane change assist; rear cross traffic alert
Notable options on this model: No options
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Jeep Cherokee, Mazda CX-5, Nissan Rogue, Toyota RAV4

The Tucson is Hyundai’s offering in a very competitive and rapidly growing field of compact crossover sport-utility vehicles, To date, the Tucson has been an also-ran in this area of the U.S. new vehicle market, a segment dominated by the Ford Escape, Jeep Cherokee, Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4, and in particular the Honda CR-V, the perennial bestseller.
The Tucson could change the CUV sales picture, thanks to a sweeping redesign that touches every area of the vehicle. It will begin appearing in dealerships this month.
However, the third-generation Tucson could well change the CUV sales picture, thanks to a sweeping redesign that touches every area of the vehicle. It will begin appearing in dealerships this month.

Like all the entries in this class, the Tucson is basically a front-wheel-drive compact passenger car with bigger dimensions, particularly in the vertical. Bigger is a word that definitely applies here. At 64.8 inches, the new Tucson isn’t quite as tall as the preceding generation, but the wheelbase has been stretched 1.2 inches to 105.1, overall length from 173.2 to 176.2, and width from 71.7 to 72.8. By comparison, the larger, three-row Hyundai Santa Fe sport-utility vehicle sits on a 110.2-inch wheelbase and is 66.9 inches tall, counting the roof rails.

What this yields is more cargo space behind the rear seats—up 5.3 cubic feet to 31.0—and of course to more interior room in general, which is what SUVs are all about. And obviously it never hurts when that increased interior volume is augmented by improved materials, which is the case here.
Hyundai claims a huge increase in structural rigidity—48 percent—thanks to much more extensive use of high-strength steel in the body shell (like all these vehicles, the frame and body are unitized). Stiffer structure pays dynamic dividends—more on that later—as well as improved crashworthiness, one of several safety upgrades.

Like the 2015 Tucson, the new 2016 version offers two engine choices. However, only one is a carryover from 2015, the 2.0-liter four-cylinder. Rated for 164 horsepower and 151 pound-feet of torque, it’s paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and is offered only in the base SE model.

EPA fuel economy ratings for the front-wheel-drive Tucson are 23 mpg city, 31 mpg highway (22/26 mpg with the optional all-wheel-drive system, as on the model we tested), a slight improvement over the 2015 version. 
Higher trim levels—Eco, Sport, and Limited—are equipped with a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine mated with a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. Shared with Hyundai’s Sonata sedan, this combination delivers generally better fuel economy—up to 26/33, with the Eco model—and, with 175 hp and 195 pound-feet of torque, brisker getaways. It’s one of the best engine/transmission combos in Hyundai’s lineup.

Our hands-on experience was confined to top-of-the-line Limited models, primarily the all-wheel-drive version, which is rated for 24 mpg in the city and 28 mpg highway. Opting for the front-drive model bumps the ratings to 25/30 mpg.

From a cosmetic perspective, the new Tucson’s increased dimensions, wider stance, improved proportions, and bolder sheetmetal character creases create a strong curbside presence. It’s another example of Hyundai’s Fluidic Sculpture styling idiom—the press materials characterize it as a “modern, sensual design”—highlighted by a big, bright execution of Hyundai’s trademark hexagonal grille and a generous sprinkling of LEDs.

Sensual may be a little hard to see in a vehicle that, like its contemporaries, is basically a streamlined cargo box, but if the Tucson doesn’t grab attention like a new Bentley, it does look new and a little more athletic.
That athletic appearance is backed by improved dynamics.

And we hasten to add that the Tucson’s athleticism is tempered by comfort. The suspension system has been completely overhauled, and its tuning is skewed toward compliance, rather than sports car agility, a priority that makes sense in this type of vehicle.

The electric power steering delivers a tactile response, reducing the amount of guesswork when you're bending the Tucson into a turn. Torque vectoring (all-wheel-drive versions only), which transfers power to the outside rear wheel in hard cornering, helps to keep the vehicle on the proper line, even if the driver finds him or herself entering a curve that abruptly tightens up.
Other compact crossovers may respond to rapid back-and-forth maneuvers with more zeal (the Mazda CX-5 comes to mind), but that’s the trade for creamy ride quality.

Fast cornering is accompanied by a fair amount of body roll, and there are other compact crossovers that respond to rapid back-and-forth maneuvers with more zeal (the Mazda CX-5 comes to mind). But that’s the trade for creamy ride quality.
The Sport version, new to the lineup, may be a little quicker on its feet, but we’ll withhold judgment on this question until we log some seat time in that and other trim levels.

Power from the 1.6-liter turbo is respectable, and the near-seamless operation of the seven-speed automatic makes the most of it. The Tucson will never provoke acceleration brownouts or facial distortion, but its straight-ahead performance stacks up well in this class, and there’s enough thrust on tap to dilute the anxiety in passing on two-lane highways.

While the new Tucson is competent in all dynamic areas, its standout strength versus competing CUVs may be quiet operation. We were pleasantly surprised by the low interior noise levels during our touring in eastern Minnesota and western Wisconsin, along the beautiful Saint Croix River. The route had a lot of smooth pavement but also included some stretches of gravel road, and the level of interior noise on the rough stuff was commendably low. Quiet operation is a key component of comfort, and the Tucson may well be best in class.
Quiet operation is a key component of comfort, and the Tucson may well be best in class.

The Verdict

As usual, Hyundai’s price-content component adds up to a very strong value story, comparing very favorably with key competitors right across the board. Pricing starts with the basic SE at $23,595, then the Eco ($25,045), Sport ($27,045), and Limited ($30,795). The top-end model is the Limited Ultimate ($33,545). Add $1,400 for all-wheel drive.

The Limited Ultimate has every feature in the Tucson’s extensive inventory—luxury is steadily trickling down into the small vehicle classes—but even the basic SE is far from stripped down, even though it lacks the all-wheel-drive option. Adding $750 gets the SE Popular, with more standard features and access to all-wheel drive.
Safety features are comprehensive and competitive—Hyundai expects the Tucson to achieve the coveted top rating from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

And as usual, Hyundai has come up with an interesting gizmo, an auto-opening rear hatch, already appreciated on the Sonata and, as Jean showed in a video review, on the Genesis. Here’s how it works. The driver steps around to the rear of the locked Tucson, with keyfob in his or her pocket, stands there for three seconds, and the hatch opens. It took Jean three tries to make it pop, but it’s an interesting variation on a feature that is almost certain to become universal.

The bottom line: in terms of build quality, road manners, style, features, and luxury content availability, this new Tucson should be perceived as a real compact crossover contender. Add Hyundai’s unique ten-year, 100,000-mile warranty, and the case is even stronger.

title: 7 Decisions before You Buy a Car
subTitle: Don't go out shopping until you've considered some essentials.
promoTitle: 7 Decisions before You Buy a Car
promoTeaserSmall: Don't go out shopping until you've considered some essentials.
promoTeaser: Don't go out shopping until you've considered some essentials.
keywords: 7 Decisions before You Buy a Car
metaTitle: 7 Decisions before You Buy a Car
metaKeywords: build and price a new car
active safety features in a car
metaDescription: Don't go out shopping until you've considered some essentials.

pageElements.text: Have you ever sought advice from an expert while car shopping? Based on the lion’s share of questions I’ve been asked by confused car shoppers, the most common has been—no kidding—“Which car should I buy?” That’s actually a great first question, because it gets you to sort through the big stuff like, “I need a four-door car that’s good in the snow,” and filters you down to the short list of choices that really meet your needs—and fulfill your desires.

And that’s important, because there’s nothing worse than driving off the lot with a new car, only to feel disappointed with your choice within only a few weeks or months. Sometimes the difference between joy and frustration comes down to a few simple choices.

So, before you go to the dealership and start test driving, make sure you’ve looked at both the big picture (How much can you afford? What body style do you want?) and the small (Is lack of a heated steering wheel a deal breaker?). The automakers all have websites where you can Build and Price a car and figure out what comes standard, what’s in an option package, and what you can’t get at all. A few hours spent playing around, once you’ve thought about your needs and wants, will be fun—and will get you closer to the car that will bring you long-term joy.
Here are seven things to consider as you make your short list.
A few hours playing around on carmakers' Build and Price web pages will be fun and will get you closer to the car that will bring you long-term joy.

1. How much help do you want with safety?

Intrigued by blind spot monitoring and cross-traffic alert technology? You should be. If you want the latest in active safety, look for vehicles that have some or all of the following: a rearview camera; adaptive (sometimes called “intelligent”) cruise control; driver attention and lane-keeping assistance; and parking assistance. Use the Build and Price menu on the automaker’s website to learn what features are standard and what are extra-cost options. Many automakers lay out their menu of safety features on a special web page, and here are some of those.
Acura, Audi, BMW, Buick, Chevrolet, Honda, Hyundai, Mercedes-Benz, Nissan, Subaru, Toyota, Volvo

2. Do you know whether you want front-, rear-, or all-wheel drive?

We explained the differences, advantages, and disadvantages in our article Drive Systems: An Explainer. People who drive on snowy and icy roads may have all-wheel drive as the first item on their wish list. More and more vehicles, both cars and sport-utility vehicles, are available with full-time all-wheel drive, such as the Cadillac SRX, Hyundai Tucson, and Subaru Outback. Those who prioritize power and performance will be making rear-wheel-drive cars their first choice. (The Ford Mustang, the Mazda MX-5 Miata, and the BMW 3 Series are all examples of rear-wheel-drive models.) Front-wheel-drive cars (including such cars as the Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, and Mazda 6) offer a good balance of comfort and handling as well as ease of driving in the winter.

3. How important are screens?

Is touchscreen navigation essential to you, or is your smartphone handling that job? Do you want a 4G LTE wireless hot spot? How about rear-seat entertainment for kids? YouTube is a good resource for how-to videos about infotainment systems. Figure out whether you want to get a higher-end model to get the most out of infotainment on your car.

4. How important is fuel economy?

This can be a real tradeoff. If you value savings more than day-to-day comfort, you’ll probably be looking at some of the smaller, more frugal models that get 40 mpg or better. If you’re deeply concerned about the environment or just enjoy being an early adopter, an electric or hybrid vehicle might be for you. For most people, you’ll want to balance miles per gallon against enjoyment and a pleasant driving experience. Don’t kid yourself about this and get a vehicle you and your family can’t happily live with. Visit fueleconomy.gov to compare some of your preferred models on the basis of their city and highway ratings. Don’t forget to do the math. If you don’t put on that many miles, a small savings in fuel cost is not worth passing on a car that truly makes you happy.

5. What does visibility mean to you?

If sitting up high and getting a clear view out large side and back windows is important, that will dictate a certain style of vehicle, like an upright wagon or crossover. A low-slung sporty car might be a non-starter. If you have gotten used to a rear windshield wiper, make sure you’re getting the type of vehicle that will offer you that—most sedans don’t. As for an impeded view from side pillars, you’ll need to test drive to be absolutely sure what the view looks like for everyone who will drive it. Your tall, lanky teenager might have less trouble seeing out the back, while a shorter person might have more of an issue.

6. Is ground clearance a big deal to you?

Ground clearance is the space between the road and the underside of your vehicle. People who live in snowy places, out in the country, or in mountainous areas probably care about this a whole lot more than city dwellers. It’s summer right now, with clear roads for everybody. Picture your driving and parking situation in the worst weather of the year, and on the worst roads you’ll come across, when you shop for a new vehicle. Some sport-utility vehicles have ground clearances of ten inches or more, and some (Jeep, for example) have an adjustable suspension that lets you choose a ride height.

7. How much do you want various body parts warmed or cooled?

If you live in a cold climate and you’ve never experienced a heated seat or steering wheel, you. have. not. lived. That’s just our opinion, but think carefully when you shop. Do you feel it’s worth an upcharge to get ventilated seats? If you live in a hot, muggy place, you probably do. If you’re going to transport pets in the wayback of a three-row crossover or SUV, you’ll want extra ventilation outlets. An independent heating and cooling control back there will be welcomed by two-legged passengers in the third row as well. If you want heated seats in the second row for your kids or other passengers, make sure the models you’re looking at offer that. It is almost always an option, not a standard feature, and frequently heated second-row seats aren’t even available.
