contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/oQioo4nc04I" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Taking inspiration from my favorite dog commercial this year (it’s from Subaru, no surprise), I’ve thought long and hard about how each of my dogs would spend a Dream Weekend. As if their lives weren’t already about as dreamy as we can make it for them!

Robert Garcia de Padua, 7

Bob is a Grand Champion Chesapeake Bay retriever, permanently retired from his show dog career, mostly because he became way too interested in the handler in front of him in the ring. Waayyyyy too interested, if you know what I mean. Bob is a simple dog with a great big heart. He’s a classic water dog, the colder the better, who loves to hunt birds. I think this would give him most joy:
● Take him to a very cold river or pond and let him swim as long as he wants. It will be for a solid hour. He swims in circles, pounding the water with his paws making bubbles. Then he swims around and around biting them. When they’re gone, he periscopes up, looks around, goes under and looks, then starts again.

● He would like Ray’s bone, Stella’s squeaky toys, and Stella’s green alien. She already bit off all of the legs, so there’s nothing left (including the squeaker) to ruin. He doesn’t care. He wants it. He stole her orange squeaky pig and tore it to shreds.
● Let him keep that pound of frozen sausage he “found,” defrosted, and ate.
● Go to Iowa with Tim to hunt pheasants and ducks. Just Tim. Not me. Not Stella. Especially not Ray.
● Lose his virginity. Please.
● Give him another shot in the show ring. Bitches in heat there.
● Let him climb up on the couch just once, and watch TV with Jean. Make Ray stay on the floor.

Stella Mae Jennings, 14

Stella is a garage-bred Chessie (pure but only purty to us), with a dicey disposition that has mellowed with age. She has earned her place as house dog. Her list is simple, so there is no reason in her stubborn mind why we can’t make this happen:
● Unlimited time with her squeakies and green alien. Until they are finally demolished. Usually by Bob. ● Her favorite dog bed, located under a sunbeam.

● Lying in bed under the fan.
● Hunting pheasants in South Dakota + me - Bob and - Ray.
● Only dog in the house. Only dog ever.
● No other dogs or humans within fifty feet of Jean.

● Never again have to get in the Suburban.
● Stay home with Jean. Make Jean stay home.

Cecil Ray Hartwick, 5

He's a mix of mostly black Labrador and Bull Mastiff and a smattering of unbelievable breeds (Bedlington Terrier, Schipperke, Catahoula Leopard Dog) affectionately dubbed Ray the Stray by his uncle Mark in Louisiana after he was found in a ditch in Mississippi. We arbitrarily gave him Bob’s birthday, since he arrived without one. This is a dog that knows what he wants at all times. He made his own list:

● All-toy access: Stella’s squeakies, Bob’s bones.
● Anything that is in Bob’s mouth, including hunks of bark from the woodpile.

● All-lap access: while Tim is reading in the lounger, while Jean is on the couch watching TV.
● No humans ever sitting in his favorite chairs.
● Never ever having to see the vet again. Ever.
● Hunting pheasants in Iowa + Tim - Bob.

● Lying in a ditch full of water or tub full of water.
● Chasing deer. Rabbits. Raccoons. Porcupines (grrrrrrr). Bears. Et cetera...
● Let him out to pee just ONE TIME without putting him on the tie-out. Suckers.

images.caption: Bob scopes out lobby of Mercedes-Benz from front seat of an S-Class.
On East Coast tour following auspicious showing at Westminster Kennel Club show, Bob stops by Rolls-Royce to check out Phantom legroom.
Ray wants Bob's stick. A rare stalemate.
Stella wants a ride in Toyota 4Runner SR5. Who wouldn't?
Ray's leather couch, pillow, and afghan. Another lazy day at the cabin.
Rare photo of all three dogs sitting still: Stella, Bob, and Ray.
Ray after reading the Sunday funnies.
Ray and Stella coming from the lake. Bob still making bubbles.
Bob and log. Ray has already stolen the bark.
Jean and Ray, together on the couch watching a Detroit Tigers ball game.

title: 2015 Volvo S60
subTitle: A well-balanced premium mid-size sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: A well-balanced premium mid-size sedan.
promoTeaser: A well-balanced premium mid-size sedan.
metaDescription: A well-balanced premium mid-size sedan. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $34,675–$47,875 (includes destination)
Trim levels: T5 Drive-E, T5 AWD, T6 Drive-E, T6 AWD R-Design
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; supercharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 302 horsepower; turbocharged 2.5-liter inline five-cylinder, 250 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter inline six-cylinder, 325 horsepower
Transmissions: Six- or eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Turbocharged 2.0-liter: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway; supercharged 2.0-liter: 24/35 mpg; 2.5-liter: 20/29 mpg; 3.0-liter: 18/26 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: City Safety collision-avoidance system
Notable standard features on this model: On Call (similar to GM’s OnStar), power seat with adjustable lumbar, dual-zone climate control, LED running lights, rain-sensing windshield wipers
Notable options on this model: Rearview camera, navigation, adaptive cruise control, collision warning, and lane-departure warning
You might also be considering: Audi A4, Cadillac CTS, Infiniti Q50, Lexus ES350

There are a lot of choices when it comes to premium mid-size sedans, but it’s hard to beat the Volvo S60 when it comes to balancing practicality, safety, comfort, and driving enjoyment in a stylish package. It accelerates swiftly, handles sharply, and is in general very enjoyable to drive. The main problem buyers will have when it comes to the S60 is figuring out which boxes to tick on the order form.

A glance at the features list opens the door to a seemingly bewildering array of powertrains and options, as there are four trim levels to choose from, each of which has two or three “sub” trim levels, plus several options packages. The T5 can be had with either front- or all-wheel drive, a 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder or a 250-horsepower, turbocharged inline five-cylinder, and in Premier or Platinum editions. Likewise, the T6 is available with front- or all-wheel drive, but its four-cylinder engine is supercharged and produces 302 horsepower. There is also a 325-horsepower, turbocharged inline six-cylinder on the R-Design model (only available with all-wheel drive), which can reach 60 mph in 5.4 seconds and still get 26 mpg on the highway. All four-cylinder S60s come with an eight-speed automatic transmission, while the five- and six-cylinder models get a six-speed automatic.

All S60s come with a generous list of standard equipment, including front and rear park assist, power heated sideview mirrors, a leather-wrapped adjustable steering wheel, power front seats with adjustable lumbar, dual-zone climate control, and a 60/40-split rear seat. City Safety, Volvo’s safety system that automatically brakes the car to avoid or mitigate a collision at speeds of less than 31 mph, is also standard across the board. Safety has always been one of Volvo’s strengths, and we think it’s worth your while to consider the Technology Package, which includes adaptive cruise control, active collision warning, lane-departure warning, active pedestrian and cyclist detection, distance alert, and active high beams.

New for 2015

Both four-cylinder engines—one turbocharged and one supercharged—are new, as is the 8-speed automatic transmission. In addition, all 2015.5 models (built after June 2014) have new standard and optional features, including automatic start/stop and a Harman Kardon Sound Package.

title: 2015 Volvo XC60
subTitle: Striking a compelling balance.
promoTeaserSmall: Striking a compelling balance.
promoTeaser: Striking a compelling balance.
metaKeywords: 2015 Volvo XC60; Volvo; crossover; SUV; sport-utility; Swedish
metaDescription: Striking a compelling balance. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $37,125–$51,675 (includes destination)
Trim levels: T5 Drive-E, T5 AWD, T6 Drive-E, T6 AWD, T6 AWD R-Design
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; supercharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 302 horsepower; turbocharged 2.5-liter inline five-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter inline six-cylinder, 300/325 horsepower
Transmissions: Six- or eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.0-liter: 24 mpg city/31 mpg highway; supercharged 2.0-liter: 22/30 mpg; 2.5-liter: 18/25 mpg; 3.0-liter: 17/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick+; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: City Safety collision-avoidance system
Notable standard features on this model: LED running lights, dual-zone climate control, Bluetooth, 40/20/40-split flat-folding rear seats, 18-inch alloy wheels, leather-wrapped steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Blind-spot information system, adaptive cruise control, pedestrian and cyclist detection, lane-departure warning
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Cadillac SRX, Lexus RX

Mid-size crossovers are all the rage these days, and the competition is tough. The Volvo XC60 needs to compete against such vehicles as the popular Lexus RX and the upscale Germans—the Audi Q5 and BMW X3—not to mention American upstarts like the Cadillac SRX. Even against such a stellar group of competitors, however, the XC60 stands out, striking a compelling balance of performance, comfort, and utility.

As with the rest of the 2015 Volvo lineup, the XC60 has new turbocharged four-cylinder engines using what Volvo calls Drive-E technology. The smaller engines used forced induction to produce similar horsepower to the previous normally aspirated six-cylinder. In addition, an eight-speed transmission helps put the power to the ground with barely perceptible gear changes. These new engines also feature ECO+, which utilizes automatic stop/start and other fuel-saving measures to improve fuel economy by up to five percent.

The two four-cylinder engines are available only with front-wheel drive. If you insist on AWD for your crossover (and many people do), you will have to make do with the carryover five- and six-cylinder inline engines. These powerplants still produce enough power to move the XC60 along at a good page, especially in the T6 AWD R-Design, which is good for an impressive 325 horsepower.

The XC60 is a great example of modern Scandinavian design adapted to the automobile. The floating center stack and swathes of supple leather make the cabin a place where you will be happy to spend your daily commute. And for those times when you need the versatility of a cargo hauler, the XC60 offers 30.8 cubic feet of space behind the second row, and a generous 67.4 cubic feet with the seats folded.

New for 2015

Both four-cylinder engines—one turbocharged and one supercharged—are new, as is the eight-speed automatic transmission. In addition, all 2015.5 models (built after June 2014) have new standard and optional features.

title: 3 Pet Carriers Pass New Safety Tests
subTitle: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety answer the question: Is your dog's crate or carrier safe in the car?
promoTitle: 3 Pet Carriers Pass New Safety Tests
promoTeaserSmall: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety answer the question: Is your dog's crate or carrier safe in the car?
promoTeaser: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety answer the question: Is your dog's crate or carrier safe in the car?
keywords: 3 Pet Carriers Pass New Safety Tests
metaTitle: 3 Pet Carriers Pass New Safety Tests - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety answer the question: Is your dog's crate or carrier safe in the car?

pageElements.text: If you’re a responsible pet owner, and we know you are, you want to make sure your dog is safely contained inside the car, whether in a harness or some kind of carrier or crate. But that protection only goes so far, because there are few guidelines to help you know for sure that you’re choosing the safest carrier you can get. Until now.

The nonprofit Center for Pet Safety, partnering with Subaru, just completed testing of several major brands of travel crates and carriers. This is a follow-up to last year’s study of harnesses used in the car. With crates, you want to know: Do they hold up in a crash, or will they collapse and turn your pet into a projectile inside the car?

Two tests were carried out: one set on heavy-duty crates that claim to provide crash protection and cost less than $1,000, and one set on more affordable travel-style plastic carriers that cost less than $150.

2015 Top Performer: Crate

Gunner Kennel G1 Intermediate
Price: $449 to $599; the test used the G1 Intermediate size with eight-inch tie-down straps ($485 for the set)
Sizes: Medium for dogs up to 75 pounds; Large for dogs up to 95 pounds (available in December)
Comments from Subaru: "Far and away the most impressive....able to withstand the most significant forces generated in CPS testing with a combination of strong structural support and integrity."

2015 Top Performer: Carrier

Petego Jet Set Forma Frame Carrier
Price: $144 to $160
Sizes: Small (to 13 pounds); Medium (to 17 pounds); Large (to 22 pounds)
Comments from Subaru: "Used an innovative ISOFIX-Latch connection, to snap the carrier firmly into place and fully contain the test dog throughout the crash test."

2015 Top Performer: Carrier

Sleepypod Mobile Pet Bed with PPRS Handilock
Price: $179.99
Sizes: Fifteen pounds and under
Pet Passenger Restraint System (PPRS) Handilock closure is free to Sleepypod customers until Dec. 31, 2015.
Comments from Subaru: "Snugly straps into the seat and showed no evidence of damage after crash testing."

Crates that got poor or failing results in the crash tests, which of course used dummies rather than actual animals, were: the 4Pets Proline Milan, MIM Variocage, Ruff Tuff, and Midwest Wire Kennel.

Carriers with poor results included the Kurgo Wander Carrier, Petego Pet Tube, Pet Mate Vari Kennel Carrier, Snoozer Roll Around, and Pet Mate Compass Carrier.

See the Center for Pet Safety website for details on the 2015 Crate Study and the 2015 Carrier Study.

images.caption: Tester examines the Gunner Kennel, named a 2015 Top Performer in Center for Pet Safety/Subaru testing.
The top-rated Gunner Kennel, tied down in a pickup truck.
Center for Pet Safety/Subaru testing in progress.
Subaru and the Center for Pet Safety used weighted and instrumented crash test dogs.
Crash test dummies, dog testing style.
Crashworthiness being evaluated during the Subaru/Center for Pet Safety study.
Petego Jet Set Forma, a Top Performer among lower-priced carriers.
Sleepypod's Mobile Pet Bed. Inset: Pet Passenger Restraint System (PPRS) Handilock closure.

title: 2015 Dodge Viper
subTitle: Track ready, street legal.
promoTeaserSmall: Track ready, street legal.
promoTeaser: Track ready, street legal.
metaKeywords: 2015 Dodge Viper; Dodge; SRT; supercar; sports car; coupe; American
metaDescription: Track ready, street legal. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive coupe
Price range: $86-990-$115,885 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Viper, GT, GTS, SRT TA 2.0 Special Edition
Engine: 8.4-liter V-10, 645 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 12 mpg city/20 mpg highway
Safety rating: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Launch control (because you’ll need it)
Notable standard features on this model: Keyless entry, infotainment system with 8.4-inch touchscreen, three-mode electronic stability control, rearview camera, 12-speaker Harman Kardon audio system
Notable options on this model: Two-mode suspension, five-mode electronic stability control, leather-trimmed seats, six-way power driver seat, 18-speaker Harman Kardon audio system
You might also be considering: Audi R8, Chevrolet Corvette, Nissan GT-R, Porsche 911

Dodge dropped the price of its fifth-generation Viper, opening another door to the 600-horsepower club. This car’s price cut is meant to turn heads as much as its curves do to get buyers shopping for the most performance under $100,000. What they’ll find is that its muscular and aggressive body—with its aluminum doors and carbon fiber hood, roof, and deck lid—are not just for looks: they improve aerodynamics and stability as much as style. All models are equipped with the standard 8.4-liter V-10 engine that produces 645 horsepower and 600 pound-feet of torque and are paired only with a six-speed manual transmission. The top track speed of the Viper is rated at 206 mph, and it launches from a stop to 60 mph in around three seconds. But getting there presents its own challenges, so launch control is a standard feature, and the five-mode electronic stability control system on the GT model (standard is three-mode) will keep you on the track and out of the ditches. The interior can be described as mission control chic. The deep racing seats of this two-seater set the tone for serious performance driving, and the traction and launch control button mounted on the steering wheel give it that track car feel. Creature comforts like heated and ventilated seats and a telescoping steering wheel are absent, but technological conveniences such as the Uconnect 8.4-inch touchscreen infotainment system with navigation, satellite radio, and voice command Bluetooth connectivity are standard. Tradeoffs. On the upside, Uconnect features a special set of SRT performance screens to help you monitor that redline, which you should definitely be pushing since this beast can take it.

New for 2015

A lower price and a 5-horsepower bump.

title: 2016 Hyundai Sonata
subTitle: Hyundai's ultra-versatile mid-size car has a flavor for just about anyone.
promoTeaserSmall: Hyundai's ultra-versatile mid-size car has a flavor for just about anyone.
promoTeaser: Hyundai's ultra-versatile mid-size car has a flavor for just about anyone.
metaDescription: Hyundai's ultra-versatile mid-size car has a flavor for just about anyone.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $21,150 - $33,525 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: SE, Sport, Eco, Limited, Sport 2.0T, Limited 2.0T, Hybrid, Hybrid Limited
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower, turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 178 horsepower; turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 245 horsepower, 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 202 horsepower, with synchronous electric motor and 9.8-kilowatt-hour lithium-ion battery
Transmission: Six-speed automatic, seven-speed dual clutch automatic
Fuel economy: SE: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway; Sport: 24/35 mpg; Limited: 24/35 mpg; Hybrid: 24 miles of range on electric only; 93 MPGe (electric + gasoline mode); 40 mpg combined
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Cruise control
Notable standard features on this model: Remote keyless entry, tilt and telescopic steering wheel, driver’s blind spot mirror
Notable options on this model: Dual fully automatic climate control, heated steering wheel, hands-free Smart Trunk opener
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry

The only thing longer than the fuel range in the Hyundai Sonata is the list of trim levels. The SE, Sport, and Limited will most often come with the 2.4-liter four-cylinder, and the Eco gets the 1.6-liter four-cylinder. In the Sport 2.0T and Limited 2.0T, the turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder delivers a wild ride. Finally, the Hybrids bring even more efficiency to the party with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder that is paired with lithium-ion battery and electric motor. The one thing all of these models have in common? Impeccable value. The price starts at just over $20,000, and for that money you have access to standard features like remote keyless entry, cruise control, and driver’s blind spot mirror. For a bit more cash you can enjoy a heated steering wheel, hands-free Smart Trunk opener, and other less necessary options. Tree huggers on a budget will smile at the Hybrid models’ price tags. Affordability does not trump safety here, though, and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration gave the Sonata five stars.
New for 2016: Driver’s knee airbag

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/okYPzvfjcnw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

2016 Honda Pilot Touring AWD

Type: Seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: LX, EX, EX-L, Touring, Elite
Base price: $30,875 (base LX with front-wheel drive; prices include destination charge)
This car: $43,700
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 280 horsepower
Transmission: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/26 mpg highway (AWD); 20/27 mpg (FWD)
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus

Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Chevrolet Traverse ($31,870)
2016 Ford Explorer ($31,646)
2015 Nissan Pathfinder ($30,395)
2015 Toyota Highlander ($31,045)

Fun-O-Meter: 6.5

Another SUV? Yes, another SUV! But this big three-row SUV is from Honda, and for a lot of buyers, that makes all the difference. The Pilot has been on the market since 2003, selling in the comfortable six figures every year, satisfying the kinds of customers who love the Accord and CR-V but need to carry seven (or even eight) people and similar quantities of stuff.
Now, for 2016, the Pilot has been completely redesigned—both outside and in—and is more than prepared to do battle against its numerous strong competitors, chief among them the Ford Explorer.

The Pilot is available in five trim levels, from the affordable LX (which starts at $30,875) to the luxuriously over-the-top Elite ($47,300; all prices include destination charge). In between are the EX ($33,310), the EX-L ($36,785), and the Touring ($41,900). Both front- and all-wheel-drive models are available, although the Touring is only available with all-wheel drive.

All Pilot models have a new 3.5-liter V-6 engine that offers 30 more horsepower, at 280 hp, over the 2015 model. A six-speed automatic transmission (up from five speeds last year) is standard on the LX, EX, and EX-L, while the Touring (the model I drove) and Elite get a nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. Dreamy.
A full suite of advanced safety technologies, which Honda calls Honda Sensing, gives you the camera and radar sensors that drivers will soon wonder how they lived without.
The Pilot has a windshield-mounted camera and wave radar on the grille to help spot potential collisions—with vehicles or even pedestrians—before they happen.

As on all Hondas, a multi-angle rearview camera is standard on all models. The Honda Sensing system is optional on the EX and EX-L, and standard on Touring and Elite models. On the tech list are collision mitigation braking, road departure mitigation, forward collision and lane departure warning systems, plus lane keeping assist and adaptive cruise control. The Pilot has a windshield-mounted camera and wave radar on the grille to help spot potential collisions—with vehicles or even pedestrians—before they happen. This helps explain why the Pilot was given a prestigious Top Safety Pick Plus designation from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

What, you ask, is “road departure mitigation,” and why do you want it? This feature alerts and helps to assist the driver if the system determines a possibility of your vehicle unintentionally crossing over lane markings at speeds between 45 and 90 mph. A message will appear in the display panel, followed by steering wheel vibrations. If you’re not clued in by that point, braking may be applied automatically if the lane lines are solid and continuous.

This may not be your cup of tea, so how about the choice of four driving modes—Normal, Snow, Mud, or Sand—for the all-wheel-drive Pilot? All-wheel drive does not turn the Pilot into a Jeep, but does give you a leg up in slippery conditions via a drive mode selector button just below the transmission gear selectors. (Even the front-wheel-drive Pilot has the Snow setting.) A little extra amusement is the animated snow, mud, and sand swirling around the wheels of the Pilot icon on the dash. This is Intelligent Traction Management, Honda style.

The Elite model justifies the $4,800 more it costs over last year’s top model, the Touring, by adding several things that are firsts on a Honda: twenty-inch wheels, ventilated front seats, heated second-row seats, a heated steering wheel—my favorite luxury item in the winter—and a panoramic glass sunroof. It also has second-row captain’s chairs, cutting maximum passenger capacity to seven from eight.

Honda’s infotainment system, HondaLink, is as always straightforward, intuitive, and clean-looking. On the Pilot LX, HondaLink has a teeny five-inch LCD screen, but all other models get an eight-inch touchscreen, so much better in every way.
Navigation is optional on the EX-L and standard on the Touring and Elite.

As I said before, the interior is completely updated, but beyond its styling, what really makes this model say “2016” is its controls. The rear entertainment system (standard on Touring and Elite, optional on EX-L) is Blu-Ray. The Pilot has push-button start. Coolest of all is the transmission gear selector, a sort of video game in which you operate a different-looking and different-feeling square for each gear.

Fun was clearly not the basic demand of the Pilot’s engineering team, or the steering  and braking would have a crisper response. But the quality of the ride was impeccable, and the overall feeling of quality and specialness within make the Pilot a real threat in this category.

Honda has a lot of die-hard fans, and one reason is this company’s ability to meet the real needs of real people in its own inimitably cheerful, accessible way. Further proof of that came when I opened the power liftgate on the Pilot Touring to discover an enormous 82-quart cooler fits back there with both back rows occupied with happy campers. Party time!

2016 Honda Pilot: view from the back.

title: 2016 Acura MDX
subTitle: Make your crew swoon.
promoTeaserSmall: Make your crew swoon.
promoTeaser: Make your crew swoon.
metaDescription: Make your crew swoon.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five- or seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $43,785 - $58,000
Trim levels: MDX, MDX SH-AWD, Tech, Entertainmennt, Advance, and AcuraWatch Plus packages
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmissions: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy: MDX: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway; MDX with Advance package: 20/27 mpg; MDX SH-AWD: 18/26 mpg; MDX SH-AWD with Advance package: 19/26 mpg
Safety rating: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Our favorite standard feature: Siri Eyes Free
Notable standard features on this model: Jewel Eye LED headlights, speed-sensitive wipers, sport seats with leather-trimmed interior, tri-zone automatic climate control, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Lane keeping assistance, adaptive cruise control, navigation, rear entertainment system
You might also be considering: BMW X5, Infiniti QX60, Lincoln MKT, Volvo XC90

Say goodbye to the minivan and hello to the 2016 Acura MDX, an upscale crossover that seats up to seven. It's the SUV for people who need that three rows of seats but refuse to skimp on the comforts of life. With the MDX, no need to do without. Sitting behind the wheel will put a smile on your face for any number of reasons. Perhaps it’s the fact that you are operating a vehicle with, as of this year, a nine-speed automatic transmission hooked up to a 3.5-liter V-6 that produces 290 horsepower. Or maybe you’re enjoying the standard Siri Eyes Free technology; or the leather-trimmed interior; or the automatic climate control; or the rearview camera. Really, the list could go on. For an extra chunk of change you can also get your hands on optional features that will make your trip safer and easier. Among them you'll find an impressive slate of active safety technology including lane keeping assistance and the foundation stone of active safety, adaptive cruise control. Speaking of safe, the MDX earned five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and was a 2015 Top Safety Pick Plus, top accolade from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. This SUV/crossover may not steal your heart with its exterior, but every other aspect will make you and your crew swoon.
New for 2016: Nine-speed automatic transmission

title: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car
subTitle: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.
promoTitle: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.
promoTeaser: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.
keywords: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car
metaTitle: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.

pageElements.text:
1. Milewiz

$4.99 per month
This is a FitBit for your car; using this, you can effortlessly let your phone track how many miles you’ve driven.

Pro: If you are a business person and need to keep track of the miles you’ve driven, this app is your new best friend. When driving your personal car for professional business, you can receive up to 57.5 cents per mile in tax deductions. And don’t worry about filing away a paper log or tearing apart your house looking for said paper log in the event of a tax audit. Milewiz’s records are totally electronic, so even five years down the road, you will have access to an accurate report of your mileage.

For those receiving reimbursements or driving a company car, Milewiz will simplify the process of tracking your expenses. The app logs the miles you’ve driven and provides a template for you to input other costs like tolls, parking, and gas. Finally, it throws together all the trip information under a heading of your choice with tags that include where you went and whom you saw. Can you say comprehensive?

Con: The question you need to ask yourself: Is it worth it? Milewiz costs $4.99 per month or $49.99 per year. Even though the first twenty drives each month are free, $50 can be a steep price for someone who only occasionally needs to track miles. If your business commutes are relatively short and regular in length, you can probably log your miles the old-fashioned way.

Available for: iOS 7.1 or later
iOS

2. Autosist

Free
This is an all-in-one app for keeping records on your vehicle(s).

Pro: Type A people, rejoice! This app allows you to electronically file away all of your automotive receipts, documents, and logistical information. Last week’s gas receipts, your registration, and your tires’ sizes are all at the tip of your fingers. Glove boxes have the tendency to become black holes for important paperwork, but Autosist will help you find exactly what you need at a moment’s notice.

If you have a hard time remembering when your car last had an oil change or when you last visited the dealership, fear not. Any evidence of these services such as receipts and other paperwork can be filed away and found later. Best of all, Autosist is free.

Con: The issue with Autosist is the same problem all digital filing services have. If the app goes down or becomes obsolete, what happens to your information? How will you get to it? You simply do not have the same type of access to electronic documents as you do to hard copies. So if you download this app, maybe keep the old shoe box of paperwork as a backup.
Available for: iOS 6.0 or later; Android 3.0 and up

iOS
Android

3. DashCommand

$9.99
For the true tech geek (or those who aspire to be), this app lets you create a custom menu of information about your car in real time, everything from diagnostics to average fuel economy.

Pro: If you take care of your own car maintenance or if you just want to know a bit more about what’s going on under the hood of your car, say hello to DashCommand. This app gives you more detailed information about your engine, like range, average fuel economy, and torque. The data appear on an intuitive easy-to-read interface, and anyone from a professional racing driver to a recently licensed sixteen-year-old will be able to understand the infographics. It costs $9.99, which is not bad for such a helpful tool.
Con: You should buy a mount for your phone if you plan on using this app while driving. Even so, it could become a source of distracted driving.
Available for: iOS 5.1.1 or later; Android 2.1 and up; Windows 95 through Windows 8

iOS
Android
Windows

4. Waze

Free
This is a crowdsourcing app that lets you find out from other drivers about traffic and problems along your route.

Pro: The map app on the iPhone uses a red line to indicate traffic on your route, but you have no idea whether that means a mile of slow-moving cars, a closed exit, or an eight-car pileup. The Waze app gives you traffic and road information in real time that is provided by other users like yourself. This will help you decide if you should take the freeway or hop off onto the side streets. Additionally, this app can give you valuable information such as telling you if cops are ahead and indicating where you can find cheap gas. Waze is free.

Con: Receiving real-time updates from fellow drivers can be more than a bit distracting when you are on the road. Also, what is to stop you from going 90 mph when you know the nearest cop is fifteen miles away? Keep in mind that the “crowd” doesn’t know everything at all times.
Available for: iOS 6.0 or later; Android varies by device; Windows 10

iOS
Android
Windows

5. Carrr Matey

Free
This pirate-themed car app makes finding where you parked your car smooth sailing.

Pro: If the mere thought of searching for your car causes a groan to rise in your throat, get ready to turn that frown upside down. Carrr Matey is a no-cost lighthearted app that pulls you out of the rough waters of confusion and drudgery. You are the captain; your car is the ship; and a compass leads you back to your parking spot. This app also lets you set a parking timer, use a map, share location with friends, and keep a travel log. Aside from the unbelievable practicality, Carrr Matey provides some much-needed fun.
Con: If you want your app to get to the parking spot without kidding around, you won’t see the fun in this.
Available for: iOS 5.0 or later; Android 1.5 and up

iOS
Android

6. CamOnRoad

Free
This app does what people in Russia do: record what happens around the car while driving. This is a dash cam that works through your smartphone, which sits in a dash-mounted phone holder.

Pro: You’ve probably heard that the use of dash cams in Russia is prevalent due to the preponderance of hit-and-run accidents. It’s useful to have video of what really happened to document accidents for insurance claims. That could be useful in the United States, too, but Americans will largely use them for navigation and fun. CamOnRoad is a free dash cam application that transforms your smartphone into a DVR with GPS navigation features. In other words, no need to mount a video camera in the car. It makes following navigation instructions much easier and allows you to travel more safely. Plus, it is just plain cool.

Con: Using your phone constantly for an extended period of time will obviously drain its battery, so you will have to buy a mount that charges your phone for you, or your car will have to have charging capabilities. The temptation to get distracted while fiddling with the dash cam or looking at the screen will be great.
Available for: iOS 7.0 or later; Android varies by device

iOS
Android

7. iOnRoad

$4.99
This app will turn your smartphone camera into another set of watchful eyes on the road.

Pro: iOnRoad uses your phone’s camera to detect vehicles in front of you and other surrounding danger, and it warns you when you get too close or veer off the road. If you have ever longed for a personal driving assistant, now you can have one for $4.99. The app also scans speed signs, locates your car once you’ve parked, and records your drives. From avoiding a collision to saving yourself from a speeding ticket, iOnRoad will help you in more ways than one.

Con: Again, you need to buy a separate mount for your smartphone if you want to use this app. iOnRoad is only $4.99, though, so shelling out some extra money for the mount might be worth it. Also, you should never fully rely on your car or phone’s technology to keep you safe. You still need to pay attention to the surrounding environment.
Available for:  iOS 8.0 or later; Android 2.2 and up

iOS
Android

title: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall
subTitle: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.
promoTitle: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall
promoTeaserSmall: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.
promoTeaser: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.
keywords: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall
metaTitle: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.

pageElements.text: It may still be hot and muggy where you are, but make no mistake: cold weather is coming. With it come icy highways, road salt, dry air, and general unpleasantness.

Of course cold weather can be beautiful and enjoyable, too, but only when you are well prepared for it. Just as you’ll enjoy a cross-country ski adventure the most if you’re correctly dressed for the weather, you’ll appreciate the cold months of driving the most if your car is ready for it.
Right now, before cooling temperatures make it more of a challenge, have a look at these seven areas to take care of, and make sure you’re ready for winter.

1. Protect your car’s exterior. Early autumn is the perfect time to work on your car’s body: the weather is not too hot, not too cold. A careful cleaning, followed by a coating of wax or sealant (synthetic wax product), will help protect the paint job against the ravages of winter and help keep salt and road gunk from doing too much damage to your paint job. A protective coating is very helpful even if you only do it once a year, in case you’re not the kind of person who normally obsesses over car finishes.

2. Do a thorough interior cleaning. The dry air of winter will be no friend to your leather upholstery. Lexol and Meguiar’s are two of the best known makers of leather conditioning products for the car. These are best applied at temperatures above 60 degrees Fahrenheit, so September is perfect. Aside from keeping the leather from cracking, you’ll be happier when you’re sealed into your vehicle this winter if you start with a clean, crumb- and debris-free car interior; all the easier to keep on top of the salt and grime that will get tracked in as the weather intensifies. Need better floor mats? This is a good time to put in some heavy-duty winter mats.

3. Check the battery. In any vehicle that’s more than five years old, the battery could need changing. You don’t want to find that out when your car suddenly won’t start in the dark in February. Besides, a battery is one of the cheapest updates you can make on a car. Get it checked at your next oil change, or sooner.

4. Check the brakes. What is more important, really? Brakes will be called upon to do extra duty on slick roads. John Nielsen of AAA points out, “Brake components that are badly worn, or a brake system in need of hydraulic fluid, may not provide the level of control needed for safe winter driving." Don’t wait to hear that metallic sound that tells you your pads need replacing; have your mechanic look over your brake pads and rotors this fall.

image.altText: Fall Clean Snow Tire Goodyear Ultra Grip Ice WRT

pageElements.text: 5. Take a serious look at your tires. Snow tires are an excellent investment in the North. All-season tires are okay, although not as desirable as mud-and-snow tires in cold climates. Whatever tires your vehicle is wearing, it's time to replace them when the tread depth gets down below 4/32”. Also, check your tire pressure regularly as the weather changes, because your tires will lose a pound of air pressure for every ten degrees the weather drops. Once a week is not too often. If you have a spare tire, check its pressure, too.

6. Get your coolant system flushed out. This is an every-other-year kind of thing, but that doesn’t mean it’s unimportant. Fluids are the life blood of your vehicle, and a freshly flushed compartment with fresh antifreeze can help your car keep working well in extreme temperatures.

7. Change the wiper blades. Every fall and every spring is a good schedule to replace the wipers. If you’re anticipating a harsh winter where you live, get special winter wiper blades that can stand up to more abuse from snow and ice. Look forward to swapping them out in the spring for another fresh pair just in time for April showers. This is a small expenditure that reaps great quality-of-life benefits.

title: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show
subTitle: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.
promoTitle: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.
promoTeaser: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.
keywords: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show
metaTitle: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.

pageElements.text: How much do Europeans like Jeeps? This year, a whole lot: Jeep set an all-time summer sales record with small but significant numbers (in the mid-four figures) that added up to a 163 percent increase for the year through August. A lot of that sales bump came from the all-new Renegade, so Jeep's Mopar division wisely showed off a modified version of the Renegade at the Frankfurt Auto Show this week. There was also a Cherokee and a Wrangler specially modified for the occasion.
Not intended for sale, these are Jeep's way of showing off some of what Mopar can do. They're fun to look at, though.

Jeep Renegade Trailhawk
The rugged yet cute 2015 Renegade made its debut at the 2014 New York Auto Show. Here at Frankfurt, the Mopar-ized Renegade Trailhawk is decked out in special Anvil paint with special edition stickers on the sides. It gets special seventeen-inch wheels, a pair of rear tow hooks, black mirror caps, and skid plates underneath. Mopar touches include special pedals and floor mats. More photos in the gallery at the end.

Jeep Wrangler Rubicon Sunriser
Check out that sunrise-colored matte orange paint job, the four-inch suspension lift kit, and the double tow hooks on the front bumper. There's an engine skid plate and bead-lock wheels that guard against "unintended tire removal" during rock, sand, or mud maneuvers. (Always a good thing.) The trend toward LED lighting gets a nod with daytime running lights and rear lights, as well as between the A-pillar and the windshield. Inside you see the same matte orange teamed with black leather. See additional photos in the gallery below.

Jeep Cherokee KrawLer
The Cherokee goes by Jeep code name KL, thus the capital letters in this show Jeep's name. Get it? The KrawLer is modified to look and work like an extreme off-roader, based on the top Trailhawk model with the addition of a heavy-duty suspension, off-road tires, skid plates, rock rails, and wide fenders. It has Jeep's Active Drive Lock four-wheel-drive system with low range and a rear differential lock, and it features the FCA corporate nine-speed automatic transmission. Cosmetically, that paint job is matte green designed to look military, and the interior has a Quartz Grey theme.

title: Pro/Con: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone?
subTitle: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?
promoTitle: Pro/Con: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone?
promoTeaserSmall: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?
keywords: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone?
metaTitle: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text: Molly Jean Says: What's Your Hurry? It's Fine to Go Slow

It is not my fault that you are in a hurry. The Constitution does not protect your right to drive at the speed limit at all times. I make it a priority not to get a speeding ticket. Especially on two-lane roads, I do not speed. I may want to actually, God forbid, drive more slowly than the posted speed. The beauty out the window as I drive through rural Michigan sometimes is worthy of a slow roll.
Sharing the road does not mean dictating that everyone must have the exact same driving style. Take a moment to remember that you are only in charge of your own vehicle.

Once a tailgater looms in my rearview mirror, I will pull over at the next available opportunity to let them continue along. For all I know, that person is a doctor speeding to save someone’s life. No judgment here. But I would appreciate a moment to find a safe place to pull over.

Conversely, when I am in a hurry and come up on a Sunday driver, I have an inner dialogue that reminds me that perhaps that driver is not comfortable driving faster. I often think of my own mother, who is a perfectly capable driver but prefers to amble along. It helps me back off and wait for the opportunity to pass. Sometimes it is frustratingly long, but seriously it adds up to minutes, not hours.

Sharing the road does not mean dictating that everyone must have the exact same driving style. Take a moment to remember that you are only in charge of your own vehicle, and you don’t know why a person is driving slower.  Breathe deeply and enjoy the countryside until you can safely pass. Namaste.
Laura Sky Brown Says: Get Out of Your Personal Bubble (or Power Trip) and Follow the Posted Speed, Damn You
Namaste my foot, Molly.

I spend about forty-five minutes each day commuting back and forth to Jean Knows Cars World Headquarters on a two-lane paved country road. Most of the way, the posted speed is 50 mph. It is beautiful, winding through a small town and past woods and farmland. I enjoy the scenery very much. What I don’t do, however, is slow down to 30 mph and let a funeral cortege of other cars stack up behind me. If I’m the only car on the road, I might let my prevailing speed creep downward while I daydream a little. But I am always very aware if I’m in a line of cars, and I keep to the posted speed limit when someone is on the road behind me.
I enjoy the scenery very much. What I don’t do, however, is slow down to 30 mph and let a funeral cortege of other cars stack up behind me.
Molly fervently disagrees with me on that; she believes the speed limit is the maximum speed, not the only speed you can go on a surface street.

She might have the letter of the law on her side, but she’s wrong anyway. There’s a social contract that people need to follow when they share road space. I think some people tend to inhabit a little world of their own when they drive, even (especially?) on the back roads or around town. People who will not drift anywhere below the speed limit on the freeway will let themselves be lulled into it in the countryside or town. At that point, they’re just being bad neighbors.

A good driver is aware of the traffic around him or her and ensures that he or she is not blocking other people’s progress. Of course I don’t mean little old ladies who are genuinely uncomfortable going the speed limit. The rest of you, step it up, would you?

I remember my first year as a licensed driver, feeling very comfortable going the posted speeds on all roads and thinking that the speed limits were very well chosen. Into the second year of driving, I began to realize that those speed limits were chosen to be the comfort zone for the worst, least experienced drivers. Translation: Just about anyone should be capable of comfortably hewing to the posted speed limit on most days. Speed limits certainly are not dangerously high anywhere I’ve ever driven. So quit daydreaming, talking on your phone, adjusting your radio dial, or going on some kind of first-guy-in-the-line power trip, and go the speed limit if there are cars behind you, for God’s sake. image: istock/Thinkstock

title: 2016 Buick LaCrosse
subTitle: Good old American luxury at a value price.
promoTeaserSmall: Good old American luxury at a value price.
promoTeaser: Good old American luxury at a value price.
metaDescription: Good old American luxury at a value price.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive full-size sedan
Price: $31,065 - $35,900
Trim levels: 1SV, 1SB, 1SL, 1SP, 1SR
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder with eAssist, 182 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 304 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.4-liter: 25 mpg city/36 mpg highway; 3.6-liter, FWD: 18/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 17/26 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model: Leather-wrapped steering wheel, dual-zone automatic climate control, remote keyless entry, eight-inch full-color information center, eight-way power driver seat, remote start
Notable options on this model: Side blind zone alert, lane change alert, leather seating, cruise control
You might also be considering: Lexus ES350, Lincoln MKZ, Toyota Avalon

The 2016 LaCrosse embodies all that is Buick: luxury at a value price. Starting at just over $31,000, this full-size sedan has all the bells and whistles. Coming standard are a leather-wrapped steering wheel, dual-zone automatic climate control, full-color information center, and remote start. So for those chilly days, you can get the heat flowing before you ever sit foot in your car. The options on this model are geared towards safety. Side blind zone alert, lane change alert, and other camera sensing features come in a package that will allow you to breathe a little easier behind the wheel. There are two engines: a 2.4-liter four-cylinder with eAssist and a 3.6-liter V-6. The one feature that is not explicitly listed but completely changes the game for this vehicle is space. And a lot of it. The LaCrosse provides ample room for family, camping gear, or whatever your heart desires.

New for 2016: Updated IntelliLink system with new display screen and two USB ports, 20-inch wheels available on premium AWD models, Exterior colors: Dark Sapphire Blue Metallic, Graphite Gray Metallic and Ebony Twilight Metallic

Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: sDrive35i: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway; xDrive35i: 18/27 mpg; xDrive35d: 23/31 mpg; xDrive50i: 14/22 mpg; xDrive40e: 55 MPGe

Our favorite standard feature: Memorized settings for steering wheel and climate control
Notable standard features on this model: Leather-wrapped steering wheel, front and rear parking sensors, universal remote transmitter
Notable options on this model: Leather-trimmed dashboard, soft-close automatic doors, heated seats and steering wheel
You might also be considering: Porsche Cayenne, Audi Q7, Mercedes-Benz GLE-Class

As if the X5 lineup didn't offer enough choices, BMW has added a plug-in hybrid to its X5 lineup for 2016, and it’s just as stylish, spacious, and powerful as the other X5s. The gasoline-powered wagons’ engines range from 255 to 300 horsepower, and on the hybrid you’ll get a combined output of 308 horsepower. A green machine that goes from 0 to 60 mph in 6.5 seconds? Tempting. Moving away from the eco-friendly perks, though, the X5 offers 23 cubic feet of cargo space and collapsible seats, perfect for families or heavy packers. Although BMW will tempt you with options that can rack your bill up to close to six figures, the standard options should curb your cravings. Front and rear parking sensors, leather steering wheel, and 14-way power driver and front passenger seats with lumbar support all come standard on the X5. The bad news is you will have to pay for a rearview camera, head-up display, and blind-spot detection. That’s okay, though, you can wipe your tears with seats’ Canberra Beige leather.
New for 2016: xDrive40e, BMW’s first plug-in hybrid Sports Activity Vehicle

If the technology-loaded 7 Series makes you want to be a passenger, the 2016 4 Series will demand that you take the driver's seat. It’s menacing, athletic, and sleek, and what it sacrifices in back seat comfort it makes up for in performance. To enhance the car’s raw abilities is the dynamic handling package, which offers variable-assist sport steering and adaptive suspension. Speed-sensitive steering comes standard, as do dynamic cruise control and rain-sensing windshield wipers. The 435i xDrive has 16 cubic feet of cargo space, and with the 40/20/40 split configuration of the rear seats, you can have access to even more space in the trunk.

New for 2016: Tough-looking Sport Line appearance package is standard on all 4 Series models.

Technology is the story in what's new for Cadillac's big luxury sedan, the 2016 Cadillac XTS, this year. Apple CarPlay gives you access to many of your smartphone apps on the Cadillac's Cue infotainment screen. There's also inductive wireless phone charging for that phone. There's OnStar with 4G LTE on-board Wi-Fi that lets you and your passengers use wireless Internet on up to ten devices. Best of all, there's Surround Vision to give you a 360-degree view above and around your XTS. It's part of the optional Driver Awareness package, which pulls out all the active-safety stops with lane keeping and blind spot assistance, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision alert, and the famous General Motors Safety Alert Seat to buzz you on the upper leg when you're straying from your lane.

But this Cadillac is also about space and comfort: the 40 inches of rear-seat space and the 18 cubic feet in the trunk will make this feel like the full-size sedans of old (almost). For those interested in Cadillac's increasingly strong reputation for performance, there's the Vsport with its twin-turbo V-6 making 410 horsepower.

More about the Cadillac XTS

Review: 2014 Cadillac XTS Vsport

title: 2017 Range Rover Evoque Convertible
subTitle: Five cool things about Land Rover's new droptop.
promoTeaserSmall: The convertible form of the Evoque has to be seen to be believed.
promoTeaser: The convertible form of the Evoque has to be seen to be believed.
metaDescription: The convertible form of the Evoque has to be seen to be believed.

pageElements.text: The smallest, arguably most stylish Land Rover product is the Evoque crossover, and soon you'll be able to get it in a convertible version. It's not unprecedented for the British off-road specialist to offer softtops, but traditionally they have been military-style Defenders. This one is, in the words of design chief Gerry McGovern, intended for a "natural urban environment."

So it's a little amusing that it has made a couple of video appearances showing how rugged and capable it is in environments far off the beaten track. Very stiff upper lip. The Evoque convertible will be officially unveiled at the 2015 Los Angeles Auto Show next month. It goes on sale in the United States next spring.

1. It can wade in water a half-meter deep—and has wade sensing to tell you how deep you're plunging, so you don’t get out of your depth, so to speak. Fly-fishing while strapped in to the back seat, anybody?
2. It passed its final road-testing program at the Land Rover Experience Centre on Eastnor Castle Estate, handling steep inclines and muck in a very Land Roverish way, as this video shows.

3. The Evoque was the first vehicle to drive through the twenty-six-mile underground Crossrail tunnel network, currently under construction 131 feet below the streets of London, to test its capability in challenging terrain. Will you ever drive yours in an uncompleted underground tunnel? Unlikely, but what a cool stunt. The top was down, in case you had to ask.

4. Land Rover put out six full-scale wireframe sculptures of the Evoque convertible in front of Harrods department store and Burberry’s flagship store in central London to whet appetites. Now those are the customers who seem the most likely to go for this droptop SUV, and they’re the least likely to drive it through tunnels and into bogs. The wireframe sculptures are going to tour other cities prior to next month's Los Angeles Auto Show unveiling of the production model.

5. It's still a Land Rover, despite its citified looks, equipped with body modifications to make the convertible sturdier, plus hill descent control, four-wheel drive, and a terrain response system, among other features that mean you really could take it just about wherever you want.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: This was my commentary in the weekly Jean Knows Cars newsletter, sent via email to a discerning group of readers. Want to be one of them and read it every week? Simply send your email address to me at feedback@jeanknowscars.com. Thanks!

I just made my first appearance on the BBC ​yesterday,​ talking about you-know-what. I am amazed at how much there is to say on the subject of #dieselgate. The Congressional hearings began​,​ and it becomes even clearer why the V​olkswagen​ AG bosses still standing after the first purge let Michael Horn stay on as Scapegoat in Chief of VW USA. As ​C​ongress gets in line to take a bat to Horn, he stands tall and offers them no target. The company lied to him, he is shocked, and he apologizes from the bottom of his heart. Hit him, beat him, excoriate away. He will be the hero at the end of this saga, mark my words.

As I thought about the enormity of it all, ​JKC ​creative director Molly Jean insisted that we not call for VW’s demise. Bad karma, first, and​ also​ bad for the global economy. She’s right. When Detroit was foundering​,​ and ​C​ongress called for GM to ​be hoist ​with​ its own petard, our esteemed legislature didn’t understand that if GM shut off the lights, the Tier 1 suppliers would fall. When the suppliers failed, Ford would not be able to build cars no matter how much money it had socked away. We don’t want VW to fail​;​ we want them to go to their bedrooms without supper for a few years.
Just as U.S. consumers have begun to show a fragile acceptance of diesel engines, VW has most probably killed it dead for some time to come.

Just as U.S. consumers have begun to show a fragile acceptance of diesel engines, VW has most probably killed it dead for some time to come. Funny when you think about it: VW is the very reason we even have such a bad opinion of diesels. Are you old enough to remember the ​late​​-​1970s VW Rabbit Diesel? Who can forget following one on the highway, its black clouds of belching particulates, the rear covered in an oily black film?

The German government has raided VW headquarters. Some ten important engineers have been suspended, two of whom are among the most respected engine development chiefs in the industry. It’s going to be a long winter.
Love, Jean

title: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini
subTitle: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini
promoTeaserSmall: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.
promoTeaser: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.
keywords: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.

pageElements.text: The winter is ahead of us, but so is the promise of spring, and if you’d like to fantasize about roaring down a country lane with the sun on your head and your hair blowing in the wind, that’s only natural. Just in time to make that dream come true comes a new version of the Mini Convertible, this one with a choice of two BMW turbo engines. That’s good news for droptop fans, since the two-seat Roadster is going out of production.
Here are five cool things about the new Convertible, which goes on sale in March:

1. Four seats. Heaven forbid we mention “practicality” in the same breath with “convertible,” but this is a droptop you can use every day and run errrands in. In fact, this Mini is 4.5 inches longer, 1.7 inches wider, and 0.8 inch taller than the one it replaces. For those who think Minis are outgrowing their name, you might have a point. But: groceries! Friends! Kids! (Those seats can be had in Malt Brown diamond-stitched leather, by the way.)

2. The sport version (Cooper S) with a six-speed manual transmission. We think that is the way to go. Its engine is a turbocharged four-cylinder making 189 horsepower. Sounds more fun than the Convertible’s standard three-cylinder turbo with its 134 horsepower, doesn’t it?

3. The Always Open Timer. This lets you keep track of how many hours you’ve spent styling and profiling with the top down. Presumably this is for the kind of people who measure their daily steps, carbohydrate intake, and REM sleep cycles. But it’s also the kind of frivolity that makes Mini so much fun.

4. You can get the soft top with a black-and-gray Union Jack woven into it. Whether you opt for that or the standard cloth top, it’s all electric and opens in eighteen seconds at speeds up to 18 mph. You can also slide the roof open part way for a sunroof feeling.

5. There’s a rain warning app. It comes with the optional 8.8-inch infotainment screen (a 6.5-inch screen is standard). That screen is huge inside the bulbous interior of the Mini Convertible, and who doesn’t want to know when it’s about to be time to put that top back up?

images.caption: 2016 Mini Convertible's power soft top goes up or down in 18 seconds.
2016 Mini Convertible with optional woven Union Jack top design.

title: Is the Walker Always Right?

promoTeaser: Laura: The driver is the bad guy if a walker gets hit. Molly: Blame is shared. Whose side are you on?

metaTitle: Pro/Con: Is the Walker Always Right? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Laura says the driver is the bad guy if a walker gets hit. Molly says blame is shared. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura Says: People Were Here before Cars

Isn't it annoying that you have to watch out for those pesky pedestrians when you drive? I am like you; I have sighed with impatience at having to wait for people to slowly mince across an intersection when I'm in a hurry. I have been pissed off when college students (they're thick on the ground in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where I live) blithely step out into the street without looking.
The only thing that mitigates my disgust is remembering the time when I, too, was a college student and did the same thing.

Molly Jean and I were just arguing about this because we were reading about three—three!—bad accidents that happened in our town in the past week. All took place under rainy and/or dark conditions, true, but they all also happened on main roads, not back streets. One person was hospitalized when she was hit while crossing at the light on Main Street downtown just before 7 a.m. Another person was killed while riding a bicycle in the bike lane of a well-lit multi-lane street at 2 a.m. In the third case, a fourteen-year-old crossing a dark road on Halloween with friends is in critical condition after being hit and dragged for two miles in the undercarriage of a car. That driver is still on the loose almost a week later.

What do all of these have in common? The person driving the car. The person who was so unobservant, so detached from the experience of driving, that he or she not only ran into a human being in a place where people were to be expected, but then drove away, in at least one case completely oblivious to having done so.

Of course pedestrians need to watch for cars. Of course it's in their control to avoid almost any vehicle by just not stepping out into the road until they're absolutely sure no cars are coming. But people were here before cars, their bodies are more vulnerable than cars' exteriors, and if you're driving, you need to watch out and expect them to appear, even at night, even in the rain, even in an unexpected place.

Sit back for a minute and think about what you're doing when you are driving a car. You are behind 2,000-plus pounds of metal with an engine, rolling down the road capable of dealing death and destruction to the small, fragile bodies of human beings. Get the hell off your phones, and never stop thinking about exactly what you're doing when you are driving and whom you could hurt.
Molly Says: It Doesn't Matter Whose Fault It Is If You're Dead

I follow two separate mantras when it comes to pedestrian safety. When I am the driver, I work very hard to be vigilant when it comes to scanning for pedestrians. However, when I am a pedestrian I take full responsibility for my own safety.

Sometimes I feel like the pedestrians in Ann Arbor are playing a game of Frogger. I frequently see pedestrians who blindly cross the street without considering that the two-ton vehicle that is piloted by a human could possibly barrel into them. It does not matter if you are in a crosswalk or jaywalking; it makes sense to make eye contact with a driver before you proceed to cross a street. As we all learned in middle school, assuming makes an ass out of u and me, and in this case it could also have dire consequences.
I frequently see pedestrians who blindly cross the street without considering that the two-ton vehicle that is piloted by a human could possibly barrel into them.

I agree that a responsible driver is always on the lookout for bipeds. But in the real world, drivers make errors all the time. Accident statistics support the fact that humans driving cars make mistakes. It is also not a stretch to say that in car versus homo sapiens, the car wins. Every. Single. Time. Raise your hand if you have ever had a close call that was your fault. I have accidentally run a stop sign, almost pulled out to pass a car on a highway directly into another car, and, yes, I have failed to see a pedestrian in my blind spot. Each incident left my hands shaking but also made me double down on my own safety when I am a pedestrian.

My parents gave me advice to use as a young driver and reminded me that it applied when I was a pedestrian as well.

"Here lies the body of Johnny O'Day
Who died preserving his right of way.

"He was right, dead right, as he sailed along
But he's just as dead as if he'd been wrong."


This simple poem nails my perspective on the pedestrian question. I try to walk at least four miles a day, and my husband and daughter are big walkers as well. I live right near a very busy intersection within walking distance of downtown. I taught my daughter to walk down a block to a quieter intersection where there is less turning traffic. People are in a hurry when they are in their cars. I have witnessed dozens of accidents at this intersection as drivers desperately try to make a light. At that exact moment, pedestrian safety has slipped their mind as top priority. Agreed, it should be part of a driver’s mind set at all times, but it is not.

I find the most dangerous crosswalks are the ones that are on high-traffic four-lane roads. On multiple occasions, I have seen cars coming up to a line of cars that have stopped at a crosswalk, going into the open lane, and zipping through the crosswalk, nearly missing a pedestrian. It is especially dangerous in towns with high numbers of tourists who are not expecting a crosswalk mid-block. I have held my breath more than once when I am stopped at a crosswalk and a car darts around me. Again, the prudent pedestrian should peek around and make sure all lanes are safe before they proceed.

Drivers are increasingly distracted by technology. Add in a driver who is lost or looking around for his or her destination, and an oblivious pedestrian doesn’t stand a chance. Crossing gets even tougher with darkness, and rain adds a Molotov cocktail to the mix. One of the recent pedestrian accidents in Ann Arbor was a woman allegedly crossing during early morning rush hour, during a rainstorm, with an obstructed view behind a black umbrella. It was a recipe for disaster, and it breaks my heart. I just wish we could time-travel back to the moment before she stepped off the curb. Her eyes meet the driver’s eye, and she safely proceeds across the street.

I wholeheartedly agree that drivers must be on the lookout for pedestrians. And those who want to lay the responsibility solely on drivers, I wish you the very best. But to anyone I love, please presume that the driver of the car does not see you.

You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4

The restyled 2016 Chevrolet Equinox is undeniably more attractive, but the compact crossover segment is very competitive and very crowded. All the better for people searching for a five-passenger front- or all-wheel-drive carryall like this one; you can keep looking until you find exactly the one for you. One of the charms of the Chevy is that it has OnStar with 4G LTE and is a rolling wireless hot spot, which should appeal to families and commuters. And the Equinox undoubtedly appeals to many; General Motors sells about a quarter-million of these every year.

Chevrolet's excellent MyLink infotainment system includes a standard rearview camera on all models; navigation is an option. People in cold climates will appreciate the adaptive remote start (standard on LTZ, optional on LT), which will turn on the front and rear defrosters, heated seats, and outside heated mirrors in outside temperatures at 45 degrees or lower.

New in 2016

Restyled front, including new chrome-accented dual-port grille and projector beam headlamps
LT and LTZ models get LED daytime running lights, side blind zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert
Rearview camera now standard on all models

Trim levels: Stingray: 1LT, 2LT, 3LT; Z06: 1LZ, 2LZ, 3LZ

Engines: 6.2-liter V-8, 455/460 horsepower (Stingray); supercharged 6.2-liter V-8, 650 horsepower (Z06)

Fuel economy: 6.2-liter, manual: 17 mpg city/29 mpg highway; 6.2-liter, automatic: 16/29 mpg; 6.2-liter supercharged, manual: 15/22 mpg; 6.2-liter supercharged, automatic: 15/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated

Notable options on this model: Corvette Museum Delivery that includes a Corvette Museum logo plaque personalized with your name
You might also be considering: Audi R8, Jaguar F-Type, Porsche 911, SRT Viper GTS

There is a reason the Corvette is the stuff of legends. In either 450-horsepower Stingray or supercharged 650-horsepower Z06 form, this is a car meant to be driven fast and intensely. It's also desirable to look at, particularly the convertible version with an electronic remote-opening top and a removable carbon fiber roof panel that fits under the hatch. Like other Chevrolets, the Corvette has OnStar with a 4G LTE wireless hot spot, plus the excellent MyLink infotainment screen, now connected to your smartphone via Apple CarPlay. In the realm of active safety, all Corvettes get a rearview camera, but the nannying ends there. That's not what you're after when shopping for a sports car like this.

The Z06 is ready for the track, with a Performance Data Recorder to record HD video and round out your quantified life. The optional Performance package ($7,995) comes with a Z07 performance suspension with magnetic selective ride control, a set of carbon-ceramic Brembo brakes, nineteen-inch front and twenty-inch rear summer tires, and carbon fiber ground effects and splitter. Adding to the street cred are optional red brake calipers and a performance "aggressive sound" exhaust.

For a thrill of a different sort, you can add a $5,000 Engine Build Experience and watch your Z06's supercharged LT4 engine being built at the Bowling Green, Kentucky, assembly plant.

New in 2016

Curb-view front parking camera (optional, Stingray 2LT/3LT)
Magnetic Ride Control (optional, some Stingrays)
Enhanced Chevrolet MyLink with smartphone projection technology and Apple CarPlay
Three new design packages (Twilight Blue, Spice Red, and Jet Black Suede), plus two new tintcoat exterior colors (Racing Yellow and Long Beach Red Metallic)
New carbon fiber hood option
Flat-bottom steering wheel
