contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, five-passenger, front- and all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Release date: Early spring 2016
Estimated price: $23,000
Competes against: Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4, Ford Escape, Hyundai Tucson
What’s most interesting: Can’t stop looking at that face!

Kia has once again shown its knack for shrewd product development as it unveiled the 2017 Sportage, a compact crossover that appeals in every way. The fourth-generation Sportage combines just the right levels of performance, feature content, and style.

Innovative design stands out foremost. Because crossover vehicles look pretty much alike in profile view, intensive effort went distinguishing the new Sportage’s front. Notice those four-element LED foglights at each corner? Kia insiders call them “ice cubes.” Along with the signature tiger-nose grille and new projector-style headlamps, the Sportage has an unmistakable face. It also has an assertive stance, with a long wheelbase, wide body, and nineteen-inch rims on the SX Turbo. As Kia Motors America president and CEO Justin Sohn says, the 2017 Sportage “isn’t just another box on wheels.” Inside, where boxes would be loaded, cargo capacity behind the second row increases by 17 percent and about 10 percent with the second row folded.
As a value-oriented brand, Kia loads on the feature content. Owners will appreciate the smart liftgate that detects the key fob.

Kia’s savvy approach also applies to performance. The Sportage LX and EX have a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine that produces 181 horsepower. The SX Turbo’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder produces a zesty 241 horsepower on regular unleaded fuel. A six-speed automatic transmission is included in all models. Fuel economy figures weren’t released.

As a value-oriented brand, Kia loads on the feature content. Owners will appreciate the smart liftgate that detects the key fob. Heated and ventilated leather seats and a heated steering wheel are available. The UVO3 infotainment system offers apps like geofencing, to keep young drivers within prescribed boundaries, and a parking minder, letting you use your smartphone to find the vehicle. In other words, along with extensive active and passive safety measures, nearly every demand is satisfied.

title: 2016 GMC Yukon XL Denali
subTitle: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.
promoTeaserSmall: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.
promoTeaser: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.
metaDescription: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Eight-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive extended-length sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: XL SLE, XL SLT, XL Denali
Base price: $51,635 (base XL SLE 2WD), $71,940 (Denali 4WD) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $76,600
Engine: 6.2-liter V-8, 378 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/20 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Cadillac Escalade ESV Standard AWD ($79,565)
2016 Ford Expedition EL Platinum AWD ($67,220)
2015 Infiniti QX80 AWD ($67,345)
2016 Lincoln Navigator L AWD ($70,330)
2016 Toyota Sequoia Platinum ($65,715)

Fun-O-Meter: 7

There are stylish cars, there are big utility vehicles—and then there’s the 2016 GMC Yukon XL Denali, a prime example of both. This supersize sport-utility vehicle offers understated but absolute luxury to the buyer who doesn’t need a posh nameplate.

Its appeal is borne out by the demographics of the GMC Yukon XL buyer. This is no nouveau-riche mobile. It’s for the confidently prosperous driver. True to its standing as the sibling of the hard-working Chevrolet Suburban, the Yukon XL, sitting on its extended 130-inch wheelbase, is a vehicle for women who need to haul horse trailers. It’s for people who tow boats. Or, like me, people who need to haul around a dog pack’s worth of kennels and hunting gear. (We have the Chevy, the working girl’s less expensive version.)

GMC says the median income of the Yukon XL Denali buyer is $239,000, and the average age is forty-six, with two-thirds of buyers classified as “professional.” Almost a quarter of those are women. Tellingly, the most important reasons for buying this massive SUV are ride comfort, passenger capacity, and the need for a “family oriented vehicle.” Yukon Denali buyers cited the exterior styling, overall quality, and previous experience with the model as their deciding factors.

GMC’s global head of design and user experience is Helen Emsley, a talented salt-of-the earth Brit. She made a name as the woman who designed the stunning interior of the new Chevrolet Corvette Stingray, the best interior it has ever had. GMC consciously focused on creating a unique front and rear for the Yukon XL, with distinct C-shaped (C as in GMC) design cues. That shape is most noticeable in the taillamps and, on the XL Denali we tested, in the unique high-intensity-discharge headlamps.

“We’re trying so much, now, at GMC, to do the different materials...to get the depth,” Helen told me at the New York Auto Show this spring, when we walked around the Denali version of the smaller GMC Terrain. “We didn’t want to just bling it and chrome it out.” Having said that, the Yukon XL Denali does get a chrome grille, but it is mercifully light on meaningless bling.

The Yukon XL offers a more premium experience than the Suburban. Its materials, quiet and subdued look and feel, and details like the simple, elegant stripe of wood trim on the doors all speak to the kind of luxury that goes without saying. Twenty-inch wheels are standard on the XL Denali, while, as on the model we tested, twenty-two-inch wheels and tires are an option.

The Yukon XL Denali also has a stronger, more sophisticated presence on the road than the Suburban. That’s not all down to looks. The Yukon XL Denali’s 6.2-liter V-8 makes 420 horsepower and 460 pound-feet of torque, while the top-end Suburban LTZ has a 5.3-liter V-8, making 355 horsepower and 383 pound-feet of torque. That’s, in part, what you’re paying the extra $4,000 for when you choose the Yukon XL Denali. The Suburban gets slightly better fuel economy as a result: 15 mpg in the city and 22 mpg on the highway, compared with the Yukon XL Denali’s 14/20 mpg.

Although the Yukon XL was all new for 2015, this year’s model still gets a few changes, notably Apple CarPlay—the latest must-have connectivity feature—as well as a standard hands-free liftgate on the SLT model and the addition of lane-keeping assist. A small quality-of-life improvement is the addition of a capless fuel filler on all models.

Other quality-of-life items include optional illuminated and power-operated side assist steps and a hands-free liftgate, standard on SLT and Denali models, that opens or closes by waving your foot under the rear bumper. Its height can be easily programmed by turning a knob, then manually adjusting and setting the desired height. What’s even more to love? The controls just inside the rear cargo compartment, which let you fold the split-folding third-row seats up and down without lifting more than a finger.

Electronically speaking, there is something that more vehicles will surely be getting soon: a wireless phone charging pad, sitting on the center console. (Some phones need a special case to make them wireless charge ready.) There’s also OnStar with 4G LTE, making the XL Denali a wireless hot spot.  Infotainment is via an eight-inch touchscreen with GM’s clear, easy-to-operate Intellilink, including navigation. On the model we tested, the Open Road package ($2,860) added a rear-seat entertainment system and a power sunroof. Our test vehicle also got the twenty-two-inch aluminum wheels with painted inserts ($1,495) and an extra-cost paint job: Midnight Amethyst Metallic ($395).
The distance-to-end-of-parking-spot visual image that shows up in the instrument panel: very useful when parallel parking a vehicle that’s 224 inches long.

Active safety features include forward collision alert, which shows an icon in the instrument panel that represents the vehicle in front of you. It’s green until you get too close, when it turns amber. You can set its sensitivity to Far, Medium, Near, or (pay attention now, purists) Off. There are also lane keeping assist with lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, side blind zone and lane change alert, and front and rear parking assist. The distance-to-end-of-parking-spot visual image that shows up in the instrument panel: very useful when parallel parking a vehicle that’s 224 inches long.

You can notice the more upscale feeling in the added sound-deadening efforts. The Denali has GM’s Active Noise Cancellation, which, using the audio system speakers, programs the sound in the cabin to improve the quiet feeling. It works. More mechanically, the doors are inlaid into the body-side openings to cut wind noise, and the windshield and front door glass is laminated for quiet. The result is a pleasantly hushed interior environment for such a huge vehicle.

For those who need a more normal-size SUV, there’s the regular GMC Yukon, twin of the Chevrolet Tahoe. It’s still classified as full size, and you can still seat eight (nine, if you configure it correctly), but its shorter 116-inch wheelbase and starting price of $52,360 may be more to some drivers’ tastes.
We utility-vehicle drivers are waiting for a diesel version of the Yukon, the Suburban, or both, but neither GMC nor Chevrolet has made that commitment.

The Verdict:

We utility-vehicle drivers are waiting for a diesel version of the Yukon, the Suburban, or both, to get better fuel economy, more torque for pulling the load, and less expensive maintenance. But neither GMC nor Chevrolet has made a commitment to diesel engines in anything but their newest mid-size pickups, not in the huge SUVs.

And when I say huge….owning one of these is the same kind of decision as choosing to drive a minivan. You would only choose to buy it if you really need the size, capacity, and usefulness of one. But if you need that 7,900-pound towing capacity and/or those eight seats—and you want to do all that with elegance—the Yukon XL Denali deserves serious consideration.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, five-passenger front- or all-wheel-drive crossover utility vehicle
Release date: Mid-2016
Estimated price: Upper $30,000 to mid-$40,000 range
Competes against: Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class, BMW X1, Acura RDX
What’s most interesting: Voluptuous styling

The Infiniti QX30 is made of the same basic pieces as its competitors, but how they’re put together adds up to something special. This new entry in the premium compact crossover segment has style—all the way from its boldly thrusting mesh grille to the crescent cut that zigzags across the rear pillar. Infiniti executive design director Alfonso Albaisa points out the long hood, the cabin that’s slid back on the chassis, and what he calls the “cool gestures” of the body’s flowing lines and dramatic creases. He refers to the body’s “muscles.” Bottom line: If you’re looking for straight and flat, go to Land Rover.

The all-wheel-drive QX30 AWD, sitting at the Los Angeles Auto Show with the front-wheel-drive Q30S—which made its debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show earlier this fall—are greater than the sum of their parts, but the parts aren’t bad. This crossover starts with a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that makes 208 horsepower. A seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission transmits that output, and the driver can exercise manual control with paddle shifters, if so desired. The QX30 promises to be involving and entertaining en route and will always make a splash upon arrival.

Albaisa also says the body’s “artistry” translates into “tailoring” inside the cabin. Again, there’s nothing pathbreaking inside, but it’s all put together so marvelously. In the QX30, it's Nappa leather or cloth. In the Q30S, the white leather inserts in the front seat cushions reappear on the upper parts of the rear seats. “We’re not just wrapping something in leather,” he says. It’s more like being wrapped in splendor.

Of course, the Q30 Sport and QX30 AWD will be available with a suite of the latest safety and driver assistance features, including predictive forward collision warning. And look to the Infiniti Q30 for high-level infotainment content. We opened the cargo cover, where we thought a spare tire might be, and found a whopping Bose subwoofer instead. So it’s assured the phrase “tinny sound” will never be applied here.

title: 5 Packing Tips for Holiday Trips
subTitle: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.
promoTeaserSmall: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.
promoTeaser: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.
metaTitle: 5 Packing Tips for Holiday Trips - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.

pageElements.text: Going on a long drive on the way to holiday festivities? Road trips are a different story in December than in August. Back then, you packed light: bathing suits, sunglasses, a cooler to keep drinks chilled. In the winter, you might be headed for the sun, but in many parts of the country you’ll also face the possibility of bad weather and resulting driving challenges. Add in the traffic snarls that are a risk in all parts of the country during the holiday season, and you know you’d better prepare yourself for anything.

As veteran road trippers—and Northerners—we are experts on the subject. We also travel with dogs and children regularly, so we’ve worked out a plan to make our drives easier. Here are our top five tips for everyone heading out to Grandmother’s house this Christmastime.

1. Keep your road-management supplies accessible. If there’s any chance of snow, have a shovel, a bag of kitty litter for traction, and a good ice scraper on board. Pack them last, so you don’t have to take all your luggage out of the car to get to it when you need it. Another tip that we hope you won’t need: ensure you have a spare tire on board. You’d be surprised how many newer cars don’t come with them. Again, make sure it’s accessible without unpacking the whole car. Last but not least, have a road service plan, and bring the membership card and phone number to call if you need it.

2. Have weather-appropriate gear for everybody who is riding in the car. It doesn’t matter that it’s not snowing and the roads are clear; things can change quickly. If you’re in a colder climate or headed to one, everybody in the car needs to have a coat, boots, gloves, and a hat. If you don’t ever need them, no big deal. If you need them desperately and don’t have them, that could become a very big deal.

3. Expect something to go wrong, and be ready for it. Blankets, a basic first aid kit, flashlight and batteries, and bottled water make up the bare minimum of supplies you should have in the car in the winter. Even better, bring along nonperishable foods for everyone, including for any pets who are riding along. Granola and chocolate bars aren’t damaged by the cold and give a quick energy boost. If you are lucky enough to be traveling with small children, don’t forget extra baby formula, foods they can eat, and utensils to feed them with.

4. Keep control of your chargers, batteries, and electronic equipment. There’s nothing worse than arriving at your destination and realizing you don’t have a phone charger with you—unless it’s being stuck in a traffic jam for hours, while realizing you didn’t bring a phone charger. If you’re traveling with several family members, a communal tech bag is a good way to make sure cords and batteries don’t get misplaced during the journey and make it home with you at the end.

5. Remember what you’re in the car to do. It’s easy to get caught up in the stress of holiday travel and forget that, presumably, you are traveling with your loved ones and heading out to see other people you care about. Don’t let the pursuit of the destination make you forget that. Take advantage of the time you’re confined together in the car, and try to enjoy one another’s company. Sometimes the best thing to pack is a sense of humor. Leave enough time to work around unavoidable delays on the road, plan for problems, and bring your patience. Everyone’s holiday will be better if you do, especially yours. And it will leave you in the right frame of mind to start planning next summer’s road trip early in the New Year.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/CZP7eQ2c-ng?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

If you love new technology, you'll appreciate Honda moving into the future, bringing Honda Sensing, a suite of advanced safety technologies, to cars for the people. Four Hondas offer Honda Sensing; we have three of them here. And some of the individual features are available as stand-alone options across a variety of new Hondas.
So, here are my picks for Honda Sensing's five coolest features.

1. Adaptive cruise control is a foundation technology. The future of autonomous cars is based on this important tech, using cruise control to help monitor and automatically adjust your place on the Earth in relationship to the car in front of you—always helping to keep you at a safe distance.

2. Forward collision warning uses a small camera mounted at the top of the front windshield to monitor vehicles in front of you. If you do nothing when forward collision warning sends you an alert, in comes...

3. Automatic braking. That's the function of collision mitigation braking, as in, "Don't make me have to stop this car for you!" Collision mitigation braking uses a millimeter wave radar sensor and front-mounted camera to help bring your Honda to a stop when the system determines that a collision is unavoidable.

4. Road departure mitgation works on roads with solid lane markings indicating the outer edge of a roadway, left or right. If your vehicle drifts too close to a solid line without your turn signal on, your steering wheel will vibrate like crazy, and if that doesn't get your attention, it will use your steering to pull you back in the lane.

5. Lane departure warning and its buddy, lane keeping assist, are for the wanderers out there. Lane departure warning can read solid and dashed lane markings, and it doesn't like it when you change lanes without signaling. It beeps and it flashes to get your attention until you go back where you belong.
As its name suggests, lane keeping assist is more serious. If you begin to drift out of the center of the lane without using the turn signal, it will automatically steer you right back to center.
Find videos and more Honda Sensing safety technologies at automobiles.honda.com/sensing.

title: 9 Brightest Looks in Lights
subTitle: The traditional headlamp is an endangered species as light design becomes an essential part of the look of new vehicles.
promoTeaserSmall: At the North American International Auto Show, these were the headlight stylings we noticed most.
promoTeaser: At the North American International Auto Show, these were the headlight stylings we noticed most.
metaDescription: At the North American International Auto Show, these were the headlight stylings we noticed most.

pageElements.text: It’s so much fun to look at cars on the brightly lit stands of an auto show, and the Detroit show, happening right now, is no exception. It’s almost as much fun as watching cars go down the road—during the day, anyway. Recently, the trend toward LED headlamps and taillights has made car spotting almost as much fun at night. The headlamp design has become even more essential as part of the overall look and feel of a new vehicle, and that was very apparent in the new models on the show stand.

The North American International Auto Show is open to the public Jan. 16-24. President Obama was there on Jan. 20. If you can’t get there, or even if you can, enjoy our choices for the most interesting light treatments at the show.

1. Acura Precision Concept
Acura calls its front fascia design “Jewel Eye,” which is nowhere more apparent than in the Jewel Eye Constellation headlamps on this concept coupe. Can a car exude sex appeal in the dark? This one could.

2. Audi H-Tron Quattro Concept
The H-Tron Quattro appeared at Detroit as a showcase for autonomous driving technology that will show up on the next Audi A8, but also for lighting of the future. On this concept, it’s a full set of matrix laser organic LED (OLED) lights, the kind often used on large light displays. It breaks down the light into hundreds of thousands of pixels, giving you a high-resolution image of the road ahead but not blinding the people coming toward you. In back of the H-Tron concept, there’s a staggered layout of nine light units as taillights and three more units below. Matrix Laser OLED lighting is also used for instruments in the cockpit. Some of this is intended to make its way into upcoming production Audis. All very futuristic, but may we also compliment the horizontal lines on the headlamps and the way they carry the grille design all the way to the edges of the H-Tron.

3. 2016 BMW X5
The X5 SUV is an example of how BMW integrates up-to-the-minute lighting choices into its traditional front design with the double kidney-shaped grille and two pairs of round headlamps. That BMW look is now available 24 hours a day. Adaptive Xenon headlamps are standard, as on this top model, the xDrive 50i, and they’re surrounded by LED accent rings that are flat on the bottom and overlap at the top. LED front foglamps are standard, too. Optionally, you can get adaptive LED headlamps with automatic high beams, which dim automatically when a car is coming toward you. You can tell the difference by looking for horizontal lights in the center of the light rings on the LED version.

4. 2017 Cadillac XT5
One great thing about Cadillac’s current product lineup is its sense of fun. Not content to be cutting edge, which they are, these cars and SUVs have charisma and confidence, too. A little well-placed frivolity really adds excitement to a luxury vehicle, don’t you think? Witness the signature LED “light pipes” that make the front end pop on this all-new luxury crossover, by day or by night. Full LED headlamps are an option.

5. 2017 Chrysler Pacifica
Chrysler’s all-new take on the minivan features what the automaker is calling “face-of-Chrysler headlamps.” Their teardrop shapes undulate smoothly on either side of the grille, with the lower foglights as counterpoint. True to the functional personality of a minivan, rather than wearing dressy LED lights, they are high-intensity-discharge (HID) lamps that produce about three times as much light as traditional headlamps. LEDs serve as accents on the Pacifica, in the form of fog lamps and taillamps.

6. 2017 Genesis G90
Hyundai is nothing if not ambitious, and the Korean automaker has really gone for it by starting up its own high-end brand, Genesis. In place of the Hyundai Equus, the flagship now becomes the Genesis G90, and like the European and Japanese luxury sedans it’s squaring off against, it has LED headlamps as part of its design. The top V-8 model gets a full set of LED headlamps that compete with the massive grille for attention in front. Even more sparkling are the standard LED daytime running lights on the lower front. The back has vertical LEDs as well.

7. 2017 Infiniti Q60
Do these headlamps look like eyes to you? That’s intentional: they are “designed to emulate the shape of the human eyelid,” Infiniti says. Infiniti was going for an “in motion” look with this new sport coupe, and the LED headlamps help with that, featuring Light Guide technology that spreads the lighting evenly across the road as you drive. Blink!

8. 2017 Lincoln Continental
The headlamps on this ultra-luxurious sedan, along with the Lincoln-logo grille, are said to represent the future of Lincoln design, indicating a future that is clearly elegant but understated. They’re not the end of the LED drama, either. The “Lincoln Embrace” is the mood lighting that detects you’re approaching the car and turns on front and rear LED lights, the area around the front doors, and then the interior in a flowing, gradual progression. Classy.

9. Nissan Titan Warrior Concept
LED light design is for more than the luxury-sedan market. The boomerang-shaped LED headlamps are so important to the design of the Titan Warrior concept truck that they were the first part anyone saw, shining through the cover even before this off-roading design study was revealed at the Detroit auto show. The custom LED lights up front are joined by a set of integrated LED off-road lights on the roof.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Trim levels: T5 (FWD), Momentum or Inscription; T6 (AWD), Momentum or Inscription
Prices: Not yet released
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 250 horsepower (T5); turbocharged and supercharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 316 horsepower (T6)
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi A6 Premium ($47,125)
2016 BMW 528i ($51,195)
2016 Mercedes-Benz E350 ($54,025)

You know Volvo as a safety-focused automaker, and one with timeless—some might say staid—design, and there is no better proof of both than its new flagship, the 2017 S90. The look is pure, and not a bit frumpy. On board is a full complement of the very latest semi-autonomous driving technology. The S90 premieres Volvo's second-generation Pilot Assist, which will be able to manage every aspect of your driving—steering, acceleration, deceleration, and braking—at speeds up to 80 mph, while the S90 remains under your control. The S90, on sale later this year, will be the first car on the U.S. market to offer this much semi-autonomous technology, and it will be standard on every S90.

Pilot Assist is already available on the critically acclaimed 2016 Volvo XC90, but that (first generation) version works only at speeds up to 30 mph. The S90 is available with front- or all-wheel drive, with a turbocharged four-cylinder engine making 240 horsepower or with a turbocharged and supercharged four-cylinder that makes 316 horsepower. A hybrid version is also in the works.

In this video, design manager Orjan Sterner points out some of the fine points.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Price range: $49,950 – $62,850 (includes destination)
Trim levels: V-6 Premium, V-6 Luxury, V-8 Luxury
Engine: 3.8-liter V-6, 311 horsepower; 5.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 17 mpg city/28 mpg highway (V-6); 15/23 mpg (V-8 models)
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Heated and ventilated front seats
Notable standard features on this model: LED lighting, 9.2-inch high-definition touchscreen with navigation, panoramic sunroof with sun shade
Notable options on this model: LED headlamps with Dynamic Bending feature, soft-close doors, quilted Nappa leather seats, 16-way driver’s seat, ventilated rear seats (Luxury models)
You might also be considering: Infiniti Q70, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

Kia has been making economy cars for a while now, but that does not imply that up here, in luxury-sedan territory, it can't build a car worthy of contending against the usual European and Japanese luxury suspects. The K900 is an impressive, and well-priced, alternative to those in the rear-wheel-drive luxury sedan category. It starts just under $50,000 and comes with a plethora of impressive safety and comfort features, from heated and ventilated front seats to gorgeous LED lighting. The K900 made its debut with a V-8, and that's still available, but this year a V-6 was added, making 311 horsepower and increasing fuel economy slightly, from 23 to 28 mpg on the highway.

The Luxury models get options such as a head-up display, quilted Nappa leather seating, premium nineteen-inch chrome wheels and tires, and advanced smart cruise control. V-8 Luxury models have standard rear cross-traffic alert and lane departure warning systems, while these two active safety features are available as options on the V-6 Luxury. Bragging rights with the neighbors are in the cards thanks to the Smart Power Trunk, which flips open the trunk if you've got the key fob within a few feet of the deck lid for more than three seconds. Another new feature this year is Smart Shift and Drive, which puts you in Eco, Normal, or Sport mode automatically based on the way you're driving. Sort of a personal trainer for your commute.
Suffice it to say, if you want a rear-wheel-drive sedan that's luxurious yet interesting, this one merits a look.

New for 2016

All-new 3.8-liter V-6 engine is standard
Image upgrade with a new front grille, rear bumper, taillights, eighteen-inch wheels, and chrome trim
Paddle shifters
Automated Emergency Braking (V-6 and V-8 Luxury models)
Smart Shift and Drive
Automatic Smart Power Trunk (opens when key fob is nearby)
High-definition 9.2-inch touchscreen

More to Read

Should You Buy It? 2015 Kia K900
